(9)  To place any solid waste, industrial waste, noncombustible refuse or hazardous materials in an underground container for pickup. 
(10)  To do any act prohibited or fail to do any act required by the regulations effecting the collection and disposal of solid wastes or other waste within the city. 
(11)  To deposit flammable liquids, hazardous wastes or explosives in any refuse container. 
(12)  To place or caused to be placed in any container dangerous or explosive substances such as strong acids or alkalies, unexploded gun shells, sealed noncombustible containers, pressure cans (such as aerosol) or any dangerous substances or devices which have not otherwise been rendered harmless and suitable for incineration by neutralizing, expending or other effective means before placing such substances for disposal. Ashes shall be cooled for twenty-four (24) hours before depositing in any container. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-18. - Permanent roll-off. 
    All permanent roll-off containers shall be serviced by the collector. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-19. - Disposal of trash accumulations too large for containers. 
    Yard waste which is properly bundled or containerized in such a manner as to enable lifting the trash in a single lifting movement to place same in the compaction truck in which bundles or containers do not exceed forty (40) pounds in weight or four (4) feet in length and which are placed at curb or roadside in the manner and time as is designated by the city manager or designee will be collected. Grass, leaves and pine straw must be containerized by either using disposable or reusable containers and if properly placed for collection as above will be collected. Yard waste containing no combustible matter, or matter which will during decay give off offensive odors, may be accumulated by the owners as mulch or compost piles in the rear of the premises upon which accumulated. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-20. - Collection, disposal to be by city or collector. 
    Except as herein otherwise provided, all residents, occupants or owners premises in the city shall be required to have accumulations of solid wastes removed and disposed of by the city or the collector. It shall be the responsibility of the owners or the occupants of residences and of all buildings used for business, commercial or industrial purposes to apply for the necessary number of containers in accordance with any need therefor. The city manager or designee shall determine the number and size of containers necessary to protect the health and welfare of the citizens of the city. Spent oils or greases accumulated by garages, filling stations or similar establishments, will not be removed by the city or collector and must be removed and properly disposed of by persons licensed to provide such services. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-21. - Boxes, crates to be collapsed before placement in containers. 
    Prior to depositing solid waste or recycling for collection in containers, the owner or person shall collapse all cardboard boxes and crates. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-22. - Establishment of rates and deposits. 
    The city shall by resolution set collection rates, and may establish security deposits, for all customers served under the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement for collection of commercial, residential and multi-family solid waste and recyclable materials. These rates shall be reviewed periodically and shall be adjusted based on available data such as current cost paid to the collector, cost of solid waste disposal, administrative cost incurred by the city and any cost associated with compliance with state, county or federal environmental regulations. This resolution will be known as the solid waste rate resolution. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-23. - Billing, collection of fees for city service. 
    Garbage, trash collection and disposal service will be provided on application only. Credit reference letters from other municipalities or utilities providing similar service will be accepted in lieu of an initial deposit providing the applicant demonstrates two (2) years of continuous nondelinquent payments. Continuous nondelinquent payment shall be defined as no more than three (3) delinquencies within the last two (2) fiscal years and no delinquencies within the last three (3) months of the refund year. Previous residents who have moved from the city within the last two (2) years and have maintained a good credit standing will be exempt from initial deposit requirements. Garbage, trash collection and disposal service charges shall be billed and collected monthly. Bills are due upon receipt. If any bill for garbage and trash collection shall be and remain unpaid on and after twenty (20) days from the billing date, a penalty of ten (10) percent of said bill may be imposed and shall be added to such bill; and if the bill shall remain due and unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days from the date of the original bill, the water service may be disconnected. Service will be reconnected upon payment in full and all past due water and sewage disposal service charges plus any penalties assessed together with a water reconnection charge as established in section 20-3. When water service is suspended upon customer request, garbage and trash collection will also be suspended. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-24. - Removal of solid wastes or other debris. 
(1)  If customer has not removed extra or nonconforming solid wastes or other industrial waste, hazardous wastes or noncombustible refuse within twenty-four (24) hours after notification by the city, the city manager or designee may order such removal and all costs incurred shall be placed against the customer's utility account. 
(2)  In the event of a hurricane or similar Act of God, the city manager or designee may request the removal of temporary roll offs, loose construction material, loose yard debris or similar potential hazards at the customer's expense without notice. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-25. - Fee declared debt for city collection. 
    The amount of collection fees imposed by this article is hereby declared to be a service secured by a property owner or occupant and which inures to the benefit of the subject property and is therefore declared to be a debt due the city, and any person required under the terms of this article to have accumulations of solid waste removed and disposed of by the city shall be liable to the city for the amount of applicable collection fee therefor, and such fee shall be recoverable in any court of competent jurisdiction. If such fees are not paid within ninety (90) days of the date of billing, the city may assess the amount of such fees as a lien against the benefited property of the same extent and character as a lien granted to the city by law for special assessments for the cost of local improvement. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-26. - Frequency of city collections. 
    The city manager or designee shall determine the frequency of each customer's pickup necessary for the health and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-27. - Points of collection. 
(a)  Residential. Containers shall be placed for collection at the edge of the customer's property adjacent to a street or alley and shall be accessible without entering into a building or shelter of any type or by walking under or around a yard or property obstacle, provided however, that the city manager or designee may make exceptions to the above in the case of handicapped or infirm persons. 
(b)  Commercial. Containers shall be placed in a location approved by the city manager or designee. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-28. - Dead animals not to be placed for collection. 
    No dead animals shall be placed for collection. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-29. - Time for placing, removal of containers. 
    All garbage and recycling carts shall be placed in the manner provided in this article no earlier than 5:00 p.m. of the day preceding the day designated for collection and shall be removed not later than 7:00 p.m. on such designated day. Dumpsters and roll-off containers may remain in their permanent location. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-30. - Furnishing, maintenance, replacement of containers for collection. 
(a)  Garbage carts. The city shall furnish each residential customer a wheeled garbage cart in accordance with specifications approved by the city manager. The city shall also furnish small business establishments (i.e., commercial establishments not using containers furnished by collector) with a wheeled garbage cart as above. 
(b)  Recycling carts. The city shall furnish each residential customer a wheeled recycling cart in accordance with specifications approved by the city manager. 
(c)  Dumpsters and roll-off containers. The collector will furnish containers to all other commercial establishments and certain multifamily dwelling units. 
(d)  Other containers prohibited. No solid waste, industrial waste, noncombustible refuse or hazardous material shall be deposited or collected from any other receptacle not specified herein, without specific approval of the city manager or designee. 
(e)  Maintenance. All containers shall be kept in a sanitary condition by the customer. Any container which fails to meet such sanitary standards is declared to be a nuisance and shall be condemned and disposed of upon order of the city manager or designee. 
(f)  Replacement. The city or collector will replace at its own expense containers lost, damaged or worn through no fault of the customer. The city will replace at the customer's expense containers lost, damaged or worn through fault of the customer. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-31. - Fines. 
(a)  In addition to any other penalty or remedy available to the city stated within this Article, any person violating any provision stated within sections 7-17, 7-18, 7-19, 7-20, 7-21, 7-24, 7-27, 7-28, 7-29, and/or 7-30 of this article shall be subject to the following fines: 
(1) First offense: Written Warning (2) Second offense: $50.00 fine (3) Third offense: $125.00 fine (4) Fourth offense: $475.00 fine (5) Subsequent violations: Fine not to exceed $500.00  
(b)  Notice of the offense and fine may be given in accordance with code enforcement procedures of Article I or Article II of Chapter 5.3 of the Code of Ordinances. Failure to timely pay the fines shall result in a code enforcement action being brought by the city against the violator. 
(c)  Each day in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. Officials charged with the responsibility of enforcing this article shall provide violators with no more than one (1) written warning. In addition to the fines contained herein, the city may take any other appropriate legal action, including but not limited to injunctive action, to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(d)  The fines shall be applied to any violator's garbage, trash collection and disposal service bill, and any person violating the provisions of this article shall also be responsible for reimbursing the city for any attorney's fees and costs incurred in correcting the violation. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-32. - Requirement of franchise agreement for construction and demolition debris. 
(1)  Any person or entity who engages in providing construction and demolition debris roll off container collection service within the city shall be required to enter into a nonexclusive franchise agreement with the city to provide such service. 
(2)  In addition to the franchise agreement required hereunder, every franchisee shall obtain and maintain at all times during the franchisee's operations all applicable permits and licenses required by any public agency having jurisdiction over the operation of said business. 
(3)  The following services are excluded from the non-exclusive construction and demolition franchise requirements: 
(a)  Self haul materials, which are generated by a residential or commercial entity and delivered by that entity directly to a recycling facility, transfer station or disposal facility. 
(b)  Removal of materials from a premises by a contractor as an incidental part of a gardening, landscaping, tree trimming, cleaning, maintenance, construction or similar service offered by that contractor rather than as a hauling service, provided that the hauling is performed by the contractor itself and not a subcontraceted hauling company. 
(c)  Removal of construction and demolition debris from a construction site by the construction contractor, provided that the hauling is performed by the contractor itself and not a subcontractor hauling company. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-33. - Granting of non-exclusive franchise agreement. 
(1)  The city manager shall be authorized to grant non-exclusive franchises to qualified persons or entities in accordance with this chapter. All qualified applicants, as determined by the city manager, shall be granted a non-exclusive franchise for construction and demolition debris collection service. 
(2)  Each applicant shall be required in order to be granted a non-exclusive franchise to provide the following: 
(a)  A signed application demonstrating experience providing collection and demolition debris experience in the city or in comparable jurisdictions or other comparable business experience; 
(b)  A signed franchise agreement as specified herein and in a form approved by the city manager and the city attorney; 
(c)  Proof of insurance in the amounts specified in the franchise agreement; 
(d)  A minimum of three (3) customers that the city may contact to conduct a reference check; and 
(e)  Provide operations information including equipment description, invoice and billing system and customer service procedures and a recycling plan in a form designated by the city manager. 
(f)  The application fee as established in the solid waste rate resolution. 
(3)  The city manager shall have the discretion to deny any application for a non-exclusive franchise under any of the following circumstances: 
(a)  Failure to comply with any of the provisions set forth in subsection (2) above; 
(b)  Evidence that the applicant's franchise was previously terminated within five (5) years prior to the date of the application; 
(c)  Evidence that the applicant previously operated a construction and demolition debris collection service in the city without holding a valid franchise; or 
(d)  A finding that the applicant lacks sufficient experience, equipment or recycling plan to safely comply with the requirements of the franchise agreement. 
(e)  Any applicant whose application is denied shall have the right to appeal said denial to the council as provided under section 7-37. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-34. - Franchise terms and conditions. 
    The franchise agreement authorized by section 7-33 shall provide, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Non-exclusive right of franchisee. The agreement shall provide that the franchisee is granted a non-exclusive franchise to provide construction and demolition debris collection service within the city. 
(2)  Franchise fee. The agreement shall provide that the franchisee shall be required to pay to the city a franchise fee in the amount of fifteen (15) percent of the gross revenues generated by the franchisee from services performed within the city on the dates specified in the agreement. 
(3)  Public liability insurance. The franchise agreement shall provide that the franchisee shall carry public liability insurance in amounts determined by the city, for the death or injury of one or more persons and for property damage. Such insurance shall name the city, its officers, agents and employees as an additional insureds. 
(4)  Performance standards. The franchise agreement shall specify standards of performance that the franchisee shall be required to comply with as determined by city to insure protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(5)  Additional terms and conditions. The council shall retain the power, by resolution, to provide for the inclusion in such agreement of such additional terms and conditions as the council deems necessary to protect the interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-35. - Supervision authority. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to supervise the operations of the franchisee and the collection of construction and demolition debris. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-36. - Termination of franchise. 
(1)  The city shall have the right to terminate a non-exclusive franchise based on the city manager's determination that an event of default has occurred as defined in the franchise agreement. 
(2)  The franchisee shall have no right or authority to engage in construction and demolition debris collection, recycling or disposal operations in the city for a period of five (5) years from the date of the termination. After five (5) years, should the franchisee provide proof that the event causing the franchisee to default has been corrected, and at the sole and complete discretion of the city, the franchisee may be reinstated upon re-submittal of an application to provide non-exclusive C&D debris container collection. 
(3)  Any franchisee whose franchise is terminated by the city manager shall have the right to appeal such determination to the council as provided in section 7-37. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Sec. 7-37. - Appeal of city manager's determination. 
(1)  Any person whose application for a franchise is denied or whose franchise is terminated may appeal such decision to the council by filing with the city clerk, within ten (10) days from and after the date of denial or termination of the franchise, a written notice of appeal which shall set forth the grounds for such appeal. 
(2)  The council shall hold an appeal hearing not later than thirty (30) days following the receipt of the written request. The council shall render its decision after the close of the appeal hearing and its decision shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 9-23-13) 
Chapter 7.5 - LAND DEVELOPMENT PROCEDURES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions of this chapter derive from Ord. No. 771, § 2, adopted April 22, 1991. Section 4 of the ordinance provides as follows: 
"Section 4. That all ordinances as resolution or parts thereof, except for provisions of the "1990-2010 Comprehensive Development Plan," which may be determined to be in conflict herewith, to the extent of such conflict, are hereby repealed." 
Cross reference- Board of zoning adjustment, § 4.7-2 et seq.; development review committee, § 4.7-13 et seq.; planning and zoning commission, § 4.7-13 et seq.; buildings and construction regulations, Ch. 5; flood damage prevention, Ch. 6.5; landscaping, Ch. 8; planning and development generally, ch. 12; comprehensive development plan generally, § 12-13 et seq.; subdivisions, Ch. 16; trees and shrubs, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7.5-1. - Establishment of procedures. 
    The city council may establish and provide for the administration of procedures to ensure that property is annexed or developed consistent with city goals, compatible with surrounding properties, and consistent with service levels adopted by city council. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
ARTICLE II. - ANNEXATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 24, 2011, amended and restated former Art. II, §§ 7.5-2-7.5-6, in its entirety which pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, April 22, 1991; Ord. No. 995, §§ 64, 65, March 27, 2000) 

Sec. 7.5-2. - Purpose and intent. 
    The procedures established in this article are intended to provide for orderly incorporation of properties within the city's planning area, consistent with Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-3. - Applicability. 
    The procedures contained in this article are applicable to all minor or major voluntary annexation requests to be accomplished pursuant to section 171.044, Florida Statutes. A "minor voluntary annexation," as it is used in this chapter, means and refers to a voluntary annexation of either: 
(a)  Residential lot(s) for single-family home(s) platted by the county after November 14, 1978; 
(b)  Any single platted lot consisting of one-half acre of real property or less; or 
(c)  Any parcel of real property consisting of one-half acre of real property or less. 
    A "major voluntary annexation," as it is used in this chapter, means and refers to any voluntary annexation which is for a parcel of real property not meeting the requirements for classification as a minor voluntary annexation. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-4. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-5. - Application procedures. 
(I)  Pre-application and filing procedures. 
(a)  Pre-application conference. Before submitting an application, the applicant shall schedule a pre-application conference with the development review committee. The applicant shall obtain a copy of the pre-application form from the community development department. The city shall provide written comments to the applicant prior to the development review committee pre-application meeting. 
The comments and information provided by the City of Maitland do not constitute a waiver of any requirements contained in the City's Land Development Code; but are meant to assist in the preparation of the application for formal submittal. A pre-application conference must be held no more than six (6) months prior to filing an application. 
Following the pre-application conference, the applicant may submit an application for processing by the city. The applicant shall submit the application and supplemental materials to the community development department in quantities designated by the city. 
(b)  Sufficiency review. All applications for major or minor voluntary annexation into the city shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. Application must be submitted at least forty (40) days prior to the first or third Thursday of any month. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. Should the applicant fail to submit all information as required within five (5) days, the application will not be considered complete and will not be processed. 
(II)  Notice of planning and zoning commission hearing. After receipt of a complete petition, the city shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined in Florida Statutes, at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the planning and zoning commission public hearing date on which the petition is to be heard. Notice shall be posted on the property proposed to be annexed and in two (2) public places, as well as the city web site. Notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property. The distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point on the boundary of the property subject to the annexation petition nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addresses to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  A statement that annexation of certain property into the City has been requested; 
(b)  The legal description of the property subject to the annexation petition; and a general location map to correspond with the legal description of the property as noted on the hearing notice. This does not mandate publication of the location map in the newspaper noted above unless otherwise required by the Florida Statutes. 
(c)  The name of the owner(s) of the property subject to the petition; 
(d)  That a public hearing will be held by the Planning and Zoning Commission; 
(e)  The date, time, and location of the hearing; 
(f)  That the public is invited to attend the hearing and make comment orally or in writing; and 
(g)  The location and times during which an interested party may inspect the annexation petition. 
(III)  Planning and zoning commission public hearing. The planning and zoning commission public hearing shall be held on the first or third Thursday of the month. Any party may appear in person, or by agent or by attorney. 
(IV)  Review by development review committee. Following a public hearing by the planning and zoning commission, the development review committee shall review the petition and any public hearing testimony and shall make a recommendation to the planning and zoning commission for approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the proposed petition for annexation. The development review committee shall formulate its recommendation and make findings with regard to the following factors: 
(a)  Whether the proposed petition will have a favorable or unfavorable effect on the city's budget; 
(b)  Whether the proposed petition will diminish the service level of the city's transportation system, and, if it will, whether an adequate agreement between the property owner(s) and the city has been consummated that will provide for improvement of the city's transportation system in such a way that the proposed petition will not diminish the level of service and will incur no cost to the city; 
(c)  Whether there will be a favorable or unfavorable impact on the environment or the natural or historical resources of the city or the region as a result of the proposed petition; 
(d)  Whether the proposed petition is consistent with the comprehensive development plan; 
(e)  Whether the city is able to provide adequate public services to the affected property, if the petition is granted, and whether the petition will promote the efficient use [of] or unduly burden water, sewer, solid waste disposal, recreational facilities or other public facilities; 
(f)  Whether approval of the petition of the lands proposed for annexation is compatible with surrounding neighborhoods and land use; 
(g)  Whether the proposed petition will promote or adversely affect the public health, safety, welfare, economic order or aesthetics of the region and the city; and 
(h)  Whether the proposed petition meets the requirements of Florida Statutes regarding annexation. 
(V)  Recommendation by planning and zoning commission. Within sixty (60) days of the planning and zoning commission's public hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall review the development review committee's findings and recommendation and shall make a recommendation to the city council for approval, approval with conditions or denial of the annexation request. Before any annexation recommendation is forwarded to city council, the planning and zoning commission shall make a written finding certifying consistency with the comprehensive development plan, and that satisfactory provision and arrangement has been made concerning the factors itemized for review by the development review committee in (IV) above. 
(VI)  City council hearing and review. Upon consideration of the recommendations of the planning and zoning commission and the development review committee, the city council may elect to introduce an ordinance to annex the subject property and set a public hearing date for the proposed ordinance. The public hearing and notices shall be consistent with requirements of the Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-6. - Annexation application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the annexation application in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials must be supplied in quantities as specified by the Community Development Director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(1)  Minor voluntary annexation. All applications for a minor voluntary annexation shall include: 
(a)  Completed application form for minor annexation. A completed application form for minor annexations with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and agents(s), the statement requesting to be annexed and the zoning district(s) to be established for subject property(ies), and appropriate signatures. All owners of real property subject to the petition shall be required to execute the petition under oath taken or administered before a notary public, and each such owner shall attest to the truth of the statements on the petition or that to the best of such owner's knowledge and belief the statements on the petition are true and correct. Petitions executed under corporate property owners shall be executed under corporate seal and by an authorized vice-president or superior corporate office. Petitions executed by a partnership shall be executed by an authorized general partner. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed said parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the community development department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  List of property owners. If specific property is involved, a list of the names and mailing addresses of all property owners of real property within five hundred (500) feet of outer perimeter of property proposed for annexation, taken from most recent tax rolls in Orange or Seminole Counties. The five-hundred-foot distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point of the boundary of the subject property nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. 
(d)  Authorizations. The name, address and telephone number of any agent who is authorized to represent the owner(s) of parcels of real property proposed to be annexed in any city review proceeding; if the agent is other than the property owner(s), the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization for each from the property owner(s). 
(e)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Vicinity map. A vicinity map drawn to a noted scale and showing: 
a.  The location of the proposed annexation; 
b.  Relationships to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding area (within five (500) feet). 
2.  Survey/legal description. A boundary survey and legal description for each parcel of property subject to the petition but owned by separate and distinct persons, corporations, partnerships, or other legal entities; and prepared by a surveyor registered by the state under a surveyor's seal and certified to the city. If applicable, provide gross and net land area which may be provided on a separate sheet. 
3.  Copy of deed. A copy of a deed showing title to be vested in the name of the property owner listed on the petition form. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition for annexation shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. 
4.  Analysis. 
a.  An analysis of the degree of consistency of the proposed annexation with the city's comprehensive development plan. 
b.  An analysis regarding compatibility of the development and proposed development (of the land proposed for annexation) with surrounding neighborhoods and land uses. 
c.  An analysis determining if the annexation request is consistent with Florida Statutes for annexations. 
(2)  Major voluntary annexation. An application for a major annexation shall include everything required for a minor voluntary annexation application and shall also include: 
(a)  Additional supplemental information. 
1.  Analysis. 
a.  An analysis of the fiscal impact of the proposed annexation on the city's finances. 
b.  An analysis of the impact of any existing development and proposed development on real property subject to the petition of all levels of service, including data to illustrate that all adopted levels of service affecting the property are met or, if any service levels are not met, including maps of existing and proposed major sewer and water lines and storm water outfalls, and the proposed extensions of these systems necessitated by the annexation. Data shall include, but not limited to, traffic, stormwater drainage, water, sewer and parks, and shall be in a format acceptable to the community development director. 
c.  Of the impact of any existing development and proposed development on the real property on significant environmental, historical, or natural resource areas within the city. 
d.  Of the city's ability to provide adequate public services to the land proposed for annexation (e.g., police, fire, garbage, etc.). 
2.  Statement of benefit. A general description of the proposed annexation, explaining why the annexation is appropriate or beneficial to the City, its residents, and the owner(s) of parcels of real property subject to the petition. 
3.  Phasing plan. Estimated timetable and method of financing for each public facility improvement necessitated by the proposed annexation. 
4.  Copy of title policy. A copy of the owner's title policy or a title opinion by a member of Florida Bar for proof of ownership of subject property(ies), if requested by the City. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Secs. 7.5-7-7.5-9. - Reserved. 

ARTICLE III. - APPEAL OF ADMINISTRATIVE RULING 

Sec. 7.5-10. - Purpose and intent. 
    The procedures established in this article are intended to provide for adequate review of the interpretation and administration of the zoning code, consistent with Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-11. - Applicability. 
    The procedures contained in this article are applicable to all appeals to the board of zoning adjustment concerning interpretation or administration of the zoning code. Any person aggrieved or any officer or bureau of the governing body of the city affected by any decision of the zoning administrator concerning the zoning code may appeal the determination or interpretation to the board of zoning adjustment. Any appeal must be filed in writing within thirty (30) days after the rendering in writing of the order, requirement, decision, or determination subject to the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-12. - Stay of proceedings. 
    An appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the zoning administrator from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the board of zoning adjustment after notice of appeal is filed, that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would cause imminent peril to life and property. In such instance, proceedings or work shall not be stayed except by a restraining order which may be granted by the board of zoning adjustment or by a court of record. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-13. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. The fees for appeal are not intended to prohibit legitimate applications. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-14. - Application procedures. 
(I)  Sufficiency review. All applications for administrative appeal under this article shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. Should the applicant fail to submit all information as required within five (5) days, the application will not be considered complete and will not be accepted. If complete, the zoning administrator shall transmit to the board all application materials and any records deemed by the zoning administrator to be pertinent to the request. 
(II)  Notice of board of zoning adjustment hearing. After receipt of a complete petition, the city shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined in Florida Statutes, at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the board of zoning adjustment public hearing date on which the petition is to be heard. If the application involves a specific piece of property, a notice shall be posted on the property subject to appeal and in two (2) public places, and notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to all property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property, all at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the board of zoning adjustment public hearing. The distance for mailing notices shall be measured by a straight line from the point on the boundary of the property subject to the appeal nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addressed to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax roll in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  The name of the appellant; 
(b)  The location of the property, if applicable; 
(c)  The action requested; and 
(d)  The date, time and location of the public hearing. 
(III)  Board of zoning adjustment public hearing. The board of zoning adjustment public hearing shall be held within sixty (60) days of receipt of a complete application. Any party may appear in person, or by agent, or by attorney. The board of zoning adjustment shall render its decision to affirm the interpretation or administrative action of the zoning administrator or to grant the appeal, consistent with the powers allocated to the board by city council. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-15. - Administrative appeal application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the administrative appeal application in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials must be supplied in quantities as specified by the community development director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(a)  Completed application form for administrative appeal. A completed application form for administrative review with the name, address and telephone number of each applicant, property owner, and agent, statement indicating request, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw the application must be submitted in writing to the community development department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  List of property owners. If specific property is involved, a list of the names and mailing addresses of all property owners of real property within five hundred (500) feet of outer perimeter of property, taken from most recent tax rolls in Orange or Seminole Counties. The five-hundred-foot distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point of the boundary of the subject property nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. 
(d)  Authorizations. The name, address and telephone number of any agent who is authorized to represent the owner(s) of parcels of real property proposed in any city review proceeding; if the agent is other than the property owner(s), the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization for each from the property owner(s). 
(e)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Written statements. 
a.  Literal Citation of questioned Code section. 
b.  Applicant's requested interpretation. 
c.  Copy of administrative official's determination of Code section. 
2.  Legal description, and street address if available, for each parcel of real property subject to the petition. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Secs. 7.5-16-7.5-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMPREHENSIVE DEVELOPMENT PLAN AMENDMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 24, 2011, amended and restated former Art. IV, §§ 7.5-20-7.5-24, in its entirety which pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, April 22, 1991; Ord. No. 995, §§ 66, 67, March 27, 2000; Ord. No. 1147, § 1, June 11, 2007; Ord. No. 1209, § 1(Exh. A), April 11, 2011. 
Cross reference- Comprehensive development plan generally, § 12-13 et seq. 

Sec. 7.5-20. - Purpose and intent. 
    The procedures established in this article are intended to provide for orderly and effective change for future development and quality of life in the City, consistent with state law. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-21. - Applicability. 
    The procedures contained in this article are applicable to all requests for changes, deletions, or additions to goals, objective, policies, or standards in the city comprehensive development plan as well as for requested changes on maps in the comprehensive plan. 
    A proposal to amend the comprehensive development plan may be initiated by any member of the city council, any member of the local planning agency, or by the city manager or division or department head of the city, by filing a written proposal with the community development department as provided in this article. The written proposal shall be classified as an "application" as that term is used herein, and the proposal may be in a separate written document or as part of the minutes of the local planning agency of [or] city council. Applications filed pursuant to this paragraph shall be classified as administrative applications of the city and shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 7.5-23 and 7.5-24 hereof. 
    A proposal to amend the comprehensive development plan may also be initiated by an owner of real property within the city, a governmental entity other than the city, or others. These applicants are required to meet all the provisions of this article, except as otherwise noted. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-22. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-23. - Application procedures. 
(I)  Sufficiency review. A complete written application for an amendment to the comprehensive development plan shall be submitted to the zoning administrator by no later than the close of business on the last regular city business day in December to be considered for cycle one review and no later than the close of business by the last regular city business day in June for cycle two amendment process. Cycle two processing will commence following adoption of cycle one amendment(s), unless otherwise approved by city council. Cycle two will follow all sequential review, application material submission and processing requirements specified herein for cycle one, with the exception of exact review months for each step may be adjusted depending on the adoption date for cycle one amendment(s). 
    The zoning administrator will examine the application and request that the applicant supply additional information or clarify ambiguities, if any, in the application within five (5) working days of application submittal. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. Should the applicant fail to submit all information as required within five (5) working days, the application will not be considered complete and will not be accepted. 
(II)  Information prehearing review. Applications may be reviewed by the city administrative staff, development review committee, and the local planning agency prior to a public hearing. The review shall be considered to be for information purposes only and not part of the amendment procedure. 
(III)  Review by the development review committee. The development review committee shall review the application and provide a draft report for the local planning agency by the third Thursday in March or as soon thereafter as may reasonably be possible. The report shall include an analysis of the application according to the following factors, if applicable: 
(a)  Whether the proposed amendment will have a favorable or unfavorable effect on the city's budget or the economy of the city or the region; 
(b)  Whether the proposed amendment will diminish the service level of the city's transportation system and, if it will, whether an adequate agreement between the property owner(s) and the city has been consummated that will provide for improvement of the city's transportation system in such a way that the proposed amendment will not diminish the level of service and will incur no cost to the city; 
(c)  Whether there will be a favorable or unfavorable impact on the environment or the natural or historical resources of the city or the region as a result of the proposed amendment; 
(d)  Whether the proposed amendment is consistent with the comprehensive development plan; 
(e)  Whether the city is able to provide adequate public services to the affected property, if the amendment is granted, and whether the amendment will promote the efficient use of or decrease the service levels to unacceptable standards for water, sewer, solid waste disposal, recreational facilities, or other facilities; 
(f)  Whether the amendment is incompatible with surrounding neighborhoods and land uses; 
(g)  Whether approval of the amendment will cause the comprehensive development plan to be internally inconsistent; 
(h)  Whether the amendment will have a favorable or adverse effect on the ability of workers to find adequate housing reasonably accessible to their places of employment; 
(i)  Whether the proposed amendment will promote or adversely affect the public health, safety, welfare, economic order, or aesthetics of the region or the city; and 
(j)  The contents of any evaluation and appraisal report prepared pursuant to the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act (F.S. § 163.3161 et seq.). 
(IV)  Notice of local planning agency hearing. After receipt of a complete petition, the city shall place, a notice of the time, place, date, and purpose of the local planning agency public hearing in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined by Florida Statutes, with the first publication not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date of public hearing. 
    If the application involves a specific piece of property, a notice shall be posted on the subject property and in two (2) public places, as well as the city web site, and notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to all property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property, all at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the local planning agency public hearings. The distance for mailing notices shall be measured by a straight line from the point on the boundary of the property subject to the application nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addressed to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax roll in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  A statement that a comprehensive plan amendment has been requested; 
(b)  The legal description of the property subject to the amendment request; and a general location map to correspond with the legal description of the property as noted on the hearing notice. This does not mandate publication of the location map in the newspaper noted above unless otherwise required by Florida Statutes. 
(c)  The name of the owner(s) of the property subject to the petition; 
(d)  That a public hearing will be held by the Planning and Zoning Commission; 
(e)  The date, time, and location of the hearing; 
(f)  That the public is invited to attend the hearing and make comment orally or in writing; and 
(g)  The location and times during which an interested party may inspect the petition. 
(V)  Local planning agency public hearing. The public hearing on plan amendments received for the year's cycle shall be held by the local planning agency on the first Thursday in April, or as soon thereafter as may be reasonably possible for the city staff to schedule the hearing and prepare a report from the development review committee and as may be reasonably convenient for the local planning agency. Any party may appear at the hearing in person, or by agent or by attorney. The local planning agency shall encourage and accept oral and written comments from the applicant or the applicant's agent or attorney, the development review committee, the city administration, other governmental entities, and the general public. Letters or other written communication received by the city regarding a pending application shall be considered by the local planning agency and made part of the record. If the proposed amendment is the subject of an evaluation and appraisal report prepared pursuant to the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act (F.S. § 163.3161 et seq.), the local planning agency shall consider the report and make it part of the record. 
(VI)  Development review committee recommendations. The development review committee shall make a recommendation to the local planning agency, on the second Thursday in April or as soon thereafter as possible. The development review committee may recommend that the application be denied, approved, or approved with modifications. The recommendation shall be based on the factors outlined in section 7.5-23(III)(a) through (j), any public input received and direction from the local planning agency. 
(VII)  Local planning agency recommendation to city council. On the third Thursday in April, or as soon thereafter as possible, the local planning agency shall make a recommendation to the city council with regard to each application. The recommendation may be based upon all factors affecting the public health, safety, welfare, economic order, public interest and aesthetics, but the recommendation must also include a finding whether the proposal satisfies the following standards: 
(a)  That the proposed amendment will not have a negative effect on the city's budget; 
(b)  That the proposed amendment will not diminish the service level of the city's transportation system, or if it will, then an adequate agreement between the property owner(s) and the city has been consummated that will provide for improvement of the city's transportation system in such a way that the proposed amendment will not diminish the level of service and will incur no cost to the city; 
(c)  That there will be no negative impact on the environment as a result of the proposed amendment; 
(d)  That the proposed amendment is consistent with the comprehensive development plan; 
(e)  That the city is able to provide adequate public services to the affected property, and that service levels will not be reduced to below adopted service levels if the amendment is granted; and 
(f)  That the amendment is not incompatible with surrounding neighborhoods and land uses. 
    The recommendation of the local planning agency may be to deny an application, approve an application, or approve an application with modifications. If the recommendation of the local planning agency is for denial of a request, the minutes or a separate written document shall reflect the basis of the local planning agency's recommendation of denial. 
(VIII)  City council first public hearing. The city council shall hold a public hearing with public notice as may be required from time to time by the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act (F.S. § 163.3161 et seq.). The public hearing shall be the first Monday in May, or as soon thereafter as may be reasonably possible and convenient for the city council. The city council shall encourage and accept oral and written comments from the applicant or the applicant's agent or attorney, the development review committee, the city administration, other governmental entities, and the general public. The report of the development review committee and the local planning agency, letters or other written communications received by the city administration, and any other written comments entered into the record during the local planning agency public hearing, all regarding any pending application for amendment of the comprehensive development plan, shall be made a part of the record during the city council public hearing. 
    After completion of the public hearing, the city council may approve an application for transmittal to the state land planning agency, or deny an application. If an application is denied, the applicant shall be advised in writing within twenty (20) calendar days of the decision to deny the application. In such case, no further action need be taken by the city. 
(IX)  Transmittal of amendment to state. If an application is approved for transmittal to the state land planning agency or approved with modifications for transmittal to the state land planning agency, the proposed change shall be promptly forwarded by the community development department to the state land planning agency for review. 
(X)  City council second public hearing. After receipt of all comments forwarded to the city by the state land planning agency regarding the amendments proposed by applications reviewed pursuant to the City Code, the city council shall hold a public hearing with such public notice as may be required, from time to time, by the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act (F.S. § 163.3161 et seq.). During the public hearing, all comments received from the state local planning agency, together with comments from other governmental entities, shall be made part of the record. The city council shall encourage and accept oral and written comments from the applicant or the applicant's agent or attorney, the city administration, other governmental entities, and the general public. Letters and other written communications received by the city after the first city council public hearing shall be made part of the record during the city council public hearing. Upon final action by the city council, the applicant shall be advised in writing within twenty (20) calendar days of the final decision. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-24. - Application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the comprehensive development plan amendment application in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials must be supplied in quantities as specified by the community development director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(a)  Completed application form for CDP amendment. A completed application form for comprehensive development plan amendment with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and development plan, and appropriate signatures. All owners of real property specific to the petition shall be required to execute the petition under oath taken or administered before a notary public, and each such owner shall attest to the truth of the statements on the petition or that to the best of the owner's knowledge and belief the statements on the petition are true and correct. Petitions executed under corporate property ownership shall be executed under corporate seal and by an authorized vice-president or superior corporate office. Petitions executed by a partnership shall be executed by an authorized general partner. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property specific to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw the application must be submitted in writing by the signatory(ies) of the application to the community development department. 
Should the application for amendment to the comprehensive development plan be submitted as a text amendment that does not amend the future land use map, signatures of at least one, but not all owners of property specific to the amendment shall be required. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  List of property owners. If a future land use map change is requested a list of the names and mailing addresses of all property owners of real property within five hundred (500) feet of outer perimeter of property proposed for amendment, taken from most recent tax rolls in Orange or Seminole Counties. The five-hundred-foot distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point of the boundary of the subject property nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. 
(d)  Authorizations. The name, address and telephone number of any agent who is authorized to represent the owner(s) of parcels of real property proposed for amendment for a land use map amendment. If the agent is other than the property owner(s), the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization for each from the property owner(s). 
For a text amendment, the applicant may provide a notarized letter of authorization for an agent to represent the property owner whose signature appears on the application form pursuant to (a) Completed application form for CDP amendment above. 
(e)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Survey/legal description. A boundary survey and legal description for each parcel of property, or an exterior boundary survey if the amendment involves more than one property, for which a land use map amendment is proposed. Such survey shall be prepared by a surveyor registered by the state under a surveyor's seal with the date of certification not in excess of one year. If applicable, provide net and gross land area which may be provided on a separate sheet. 
2.  Vicinity map. A vicinity map (if the proposed amendment involves a specific property) drawn to a noted scale and showing: 
a.  The location of the subject property(ies); 
b.  Relationship to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding areas (within five hundred (500) feet). 
3.  Analysis. 
a.  An analysis of the degree of consistency of the proposed amendment with the city's comprehensive development plan and whether an internal inconsistency between provisions might be created. 
b.  An analysis of the fiscal impact of the proposed amendment on the city's finances. 
c.  An analysis of the impact of the amendment on all levels of service, including data to illustrate that all adopted levels of service affecting the property are met or, if any service levels are not met, including maps of existing and proposed major sewer and water lines and stormwater outfalls, and the proposed extensions of these systems necessitated by the annexation. Data shall include, but not limited to, traffic, stormwater drainage, water, sewer and parks, and shall be in a format acceptable to the community development director. 
d.  An analysis of the impact of the amendment on the environmental, historical, or natural resource areas within the city. 
e.  An analysis of the city's ability to provide adequate public services with regard to the amendment (e.g., police, fire, garbage, etc.). 
f.  If the application involves a specific parcel of real property, an analysis of the compatibility and impacts of the proposed amendment on surrounding neighborhoods and land uses. 
4.  Statement of appropriateness. A general description of the proposed amendment to the comprehensive development plan, explaining why the amendment is necessary or appropriate. 
5.  Phasing plan. Estimated timetable and method of financing for each public facility improvement necessitated by the Comprehensive Development Plan amendment. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Secs. 7.5-25-7.5-29. - Reserved. 

ARTICLE V. - OFF-SITE AND SHARED PARKING AND COMBINED ON-SITE PARKING 
[4]
Footnotes: 

Sec. 7.5-30. - Purpose and intent. 
    The procedures established in this article are intended to provide for an effective alternative to on-site parking where property exists within six hundred (600) feet, to satisfy parking needs consistent with quality development standards acceptable to the city. 
    The procedures established in this article are also intended to provide for an effective alternative method to establish combined on-site parking consistent with quality development standards acceptable to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-31. - Applicability. 
    The procedures contained in this article are applicable to all required off-street parking facilities which are not located on the same lot or parcel of land they are intended to serve, but which are located within six hundred (600) feet of the lot or parcel for which they are intended. 
    In addition, the procedures contained in this article are applicable to all required off-street parking facilities where the owner(s) or operator(s) of adjacent buildings or uses, or uses within the same building make collective provisions for such facilities. 
    The owner(s) or operator(s) of parcels requiring off-street parking facilities which are within six hundred (600) feet of each other may make collective provision for such facilities. The development review committee may approve shared parking facilities for developments or uses with differing or non-overlapping operating hours or different peak business periods, or excess parking spaces if the shared parking complies with items (a) through (g) below. Combined on-site parking must meet items (c) through (g) below. 
(a)  Required parking spaces reserved for accessible parking may not be located off-site. 
(b)  Shared parking spaces must be located within six hundred (600) feet of the lot or parcel they are intended to serve. 
(c)  Required parking spaces reserved for persons who require accessibility shall meet all requirements of the American's With Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) and Chapter 11 of the Florida Building Code. 
(d)  Those wishing to use shared parking as a means of satisfying off-street parking requirements must submit a shared parking study/analysis to the community development department that clearly demonstrates the feasibility of shared parking. The studies must be provided in a form established by the community development department. The analysis must address, at a minimum, the size and type of the proposed development, the composition of tenants, the anticipated rate of parking turnover and the anticipated peak parking and traffic loads for all uses that will be sharing off-street parking spaces. 
(e)  A shared parking plan shall be enforced through written agreement among all owners of record and shall be subject to approval by the city. The owner(s) shall agree to bear the expense of recording the agreement, and such agreement shall bind owners and their heirs, successors, and assigns. An attested copy of the agreement between the owner(s) of record shall be submitted to the community development department. Recordation of the agreement must take place before issuance of a building permit or certificate of occupancy for any use to be served by the shared parking area. 
(f)  When the uses or the property subject to shared parking agreement are proposed to change, the community development director or designee shall have the authority to require a revised shared parking study and shall, with the approval of the development review committee, either revoke the shared parking agreement when it is determined that it is no longer necessary to meet the parking requirements of the uses or shall require a new shared parking agreement, when the revised parking study indicates additional parking is required. 
(g)  The community development director or designee may reevaluate a parking agreement previously approved by the city under the following circumstances: 
1.  Expiration of the agreement; 
2.  When there is proposed revision to the use or property that would require additional parking under the Maitland City Code regulating parking such as, an increase in square footage of structures/buildings affected by the agreement, or increased seating, or employee counts for restaurants; or 
3.  When there is a proposed revision to the use or property that would require less parking under the Maitland City Code regulating parking such as modifications to reduce seating area for restaurants or changes in use. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-32. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. In addition to administrative fees, the applicant is responsible for all fees associated with recording any agreement required to effect an approved application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-33. - Application procedures. 
(I)  Sufficiency review. All applications under this article shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. Should the applicant fail to submit all information as required within five (5) working days, the application will not be considered complete and will not be accepted. 
(II)  Review and decision by development review committee. After receipt of a complete petition, the development review committee shall formulate its decision to approve, approve with changes, or deny the application. Such action shall be taken within twenty-one (21) days of the date the application is determined sufficient by the zoning administrator. In doing so, the development review committee shall make findings with regard to the following factors: 
(a)  Whether the proposed application will diminish the service levels adopted by the city. 
(b)  Whether there is compliance with the applicable ordinances and regulations for the proposed development. 
(c)  Whether the proposed agreement to effect the proposed application is sufficient. 
(d)  Whether circumstances exist that warrant off-site/shared parking or combined on-site parking. 
    This procedure does not apply where approval may be granted as part of a formal application review process such as for the site plan review, permitted conditional use review or planned development review processes within the City of Maitland. For these instances, the required application materials should be included as part of the respective application processes. 
(III)  Recording of agreements. No approval granted by the Development Review Committee shall be effective until all agreements required to effect the approval have been recorded with the Orange County Comptroller's Office. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-34. - Off-site and shared parking application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the off-site and shared parking application, in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials, must be supplied in quantities as specified by the community development director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(a)  Completed application form for off-site and shared parking: A completed application form for off-site and shared parking with the name, address and telephone number of applicant, property owner(s), and agent(s), the request for off-site or shared parking, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the community development department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time by the city council. 
(c)  Authorizations. The name, address and telephone number of any agent who is authorized to represent the owner(s) of parcels of real property in any city review proceeding; if the agent is other than the property owner(s), the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization for each from the property owner(s). 
(d)  Supplemental information. 
(1)  Vicinity map drawn to a noted scale and showing: 
a.  The location of the proposed parking area and site(s) to be served by the parking area; 
b.  Connections to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding areas within five hundred (500) feet. 
(2)  Site plan(s) for property(ies) subject to the application, with a north arrow and drawn to scale and to include: 
a.  Legal description and property lines drawn to scale; 
b.  Street address (if applicable); 
c.  Required and proposed off-street parking detail, number and location, loading areas, service and refuse areas; 
d.  Schematic landscape plan (if requested by the city); 
e.  Screening and buffering if requested by the city (reference, type, dimensions, and character); 
f.  The layout of bikeways and pedestrian ways (especially those linking parking area to building(s) to be served); 
g.  Locations of ingress/egress to property (existing and proposed); 
h.  Parking study/analysis that clearly demonstrates the feasibility of shared parking. The analysis must address, at a minimum, the size and type of the proposed development, the composition of tenants, the anticipated rate of parking turnover and the anticipated peak parking demand and traffic loads for all uses that will be sharing off-street parking spaces; and 
i.  Existing and proposed building(s) located on site. 
(3)  Level of service data and analysis. Data illustrating that all adopted levels of service affecting the property are met or, if any service levels are not met, schedule of improvements which will be provided to ensure that all service levels are met; and a detailed analysis of parking requirements, including time of use and function, to support request. 
(4)  Agreements. Submit copies of all agreement(s) proposed to effect application request. 
(5)  Existing building uses, listed for all buildings (if any) and intended use of each building or portion thereof. 
(6)  Signs and lighting, if any, existing and proposed locations, elevations, and typical sections. 
    Should an item listed under the category of Supplemental Information in (d) above be determined by the Community Development Director (or designee) as not applicable to a particular application, the item(s) may be waived without affecting the sufficiency of the application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 

Secs. 7.5-35-7.5-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT AMENDMENT[5]
