Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 24, 2011, repealed former Art. VI, §§ 7.5-40-7.5-46, in its entirety which pertained to permitted conditional uses and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, April 22, 1991; Ord. No. 995, § 69, March 27, 2000. Ord. No. 1224, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Feb. 13, 2012, added a new Art. VI as herein set out. 

Sec. 7.5-40. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this article is to ensure that when an amendment to a development agreement (DA) which was adopted pursuant to Section 163.3220, et. seq. Florida Statutes, is considered by the City of Maitland, that a review process is articulated within the Maitland City Code to provide for a clear and efficient review process. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1(Exh. A), 2-13-12) 
Sec. 7.5-41. - Applicability. 
    The procedures contained in this article are applicable to any amendment to a DA previously adopted by the City of Maitland pursuant to Section 163.3221, Florida Statutes. 
    When referencing a Florida statute within this article it shall include its successor provisions. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1(Exh. A), 2-13-12) 
Sec. 7.5-42. - Procedure for amendment to a development agreement (DA). 
(I)  Development review committee review and recommendation. The development review committee (DRC) shall review the DA amendment and provide a recommendation to the LPA to approve, approve with modifications or deny the DA amendment. The DRC shall make findings as to each proposed DA amendment and shall forward such findings to the LPA. 
    The findings shall be based on the following criteria: 
(a)  Whether the amendment to the DA is consistent with the City of Maitland 2030 Comprehensive Plan, or as may be amended; and 
(b)  Whether the provisions of the DA amendment are in the best interests of the public health, safety, welfare, economic order and aesthetics of the region and the community; and 
(c)  Whether the development will adversely affect the orderly development of property in the area of the parcel of land subject to the DA amendment; and 
(d)  Any findings required to be made pursuant to Section 163.3227, Florida Statutes. 
(II)  Local planning agency public hearing and recommendation. Upon consideration of the recommendations of the DRC, the LPA shall hold a public hearing. Notification of the public hearing shall be accomplished pursuant Section 163.3225, Florida Statutes. Following the public hearing, and after review of the DRC recommendation and findings, the LPA shall make its written recommendation to the city council and shall make a written finding certifying consistency with the items listed in (I) (a) through (d) above. 
(III)  City council public hearing and decision. Upon consideration of the recommendations of the LPA and the DRC, the city council shall hold a public hearing. Notification of the public hearing shall be published and mailed in accordance with Section 163.3225, Florida Statutes. Following the public hearing the city council shall approve, or approve with modifications, or deny the proposed DA amendment. This does not preclude an additional public hearing(s) as may be required by law or as may be deemed appropriate by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1(Exh. A), 2-13-12) 
Sec. 7.5-43. - Procedure for minor amendments to a development agreement. 
(I)  Review and approval by community development director. 
(a)  Minor amendments to a development agreement may be approved as a non-statutory development agreement pursuant to the city's home rule powers under the Florida Constitution and Chapter 166, Florida Statutes, after review by the community development director, provided: 
(1)  The change is substantially consistent with the overall purposes and intent of the approved development agreement; and 
(2)  The change conforms to all other applicable city ordinances and regulations; and 
(3)  The change does not require a change in any other provision of the development agreement that would require review under section 7.5-42; and 
(4)  The change is not inconsistent with the city's comprehensive development plan. 
(b)  An amendment is considered minor if it includes one or more of the following: 
(1)  Adds less than five (5) percent of the approximate structural square footage of the project, if the development agreement states an approximate maximum square footage of the project. 
(2)  Changes provisions regarding easements or utilities so that more effective service levels can be achieved. 
(3)  Corrects any scriveners' errors. 
(4)  Changes provisions which are specifically provided for as minor in the approved development agreement. 
(5)  Change time frames for development application review, as long as the modified schedule does not trigger any default dates that may exist within the agreement and the modified review time frames and all required improvements, can be accomplished without an extension of the expiration date of the agreement. 
(6)  Changes resulting from changes to any section or subsection numbers of amended Florida Statutes, Florida Administrative Code, or any other state or local law, so long as the substance of the state or local law has not changed. 
(7)  When the development agreement provides that a city official take certain action, the change adds that the city official "or his or her designee" may execute the action. 
(8)  Changes provisions that allow administrative site plan reviews by providing that site plan reviews shall be processed in accordance with Article X of Chapter 7.5. 
(9)  Extends the effective date of a current, unexpired development agreement if state law applicable to the development agreement requires such extension, so long as the developer follows the requirements of the law. 
(10)  When a development agreement requires a letter of credit or maintenance bond, the change allows other forms of security interest, so long as any surety is approved by the city staff; provided, however, that any stated amount or percentage of the security interest remains the same. 
(11)  Changes the corporate name or address of developer when such changes have been accomplished through the state. 
(12)  Changes the name of the subject property or project, unless the name of the subject property listed in the development agreement is the same as an already-platted subdivision. 
(II)  Development review committee review and recommendation. If the Community Development Director desires review and recommendation by the DRC for a determination of whether the change is minor, (s)he may require DRC to review the proposed change. The DRC shall recommend approval or denial that the change is minor. 
(III)  Decision of community development director. If the community development director determines, when applying the above criteria, that the change is minor, the amendment shall be prepared, executed, and recorded in the public records of Orange County, without necessity of any public hearings before the LPA or city council. If the community development director determines that the change is not minor, (s)he shall state reasons in writing to the applicant, and the amendment shall be reviewed in accordance with section 7.5-42. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1(Exh. A), 2-13-12) 
Sec. 7.5-44. - Periodic review of development agreements. 
    The community development director or designee shall review each development agreement in accordance with Section 163.3225, Florida Statutes, or as may be amended. A determination shall be made as to whether the developer has complied with the terms of the development agreement. 
    The development agreement may be revoked or modified by the City of Maitland in accordance with Section 163.3235, Florida Statutes, or canceled at any time in accordance with Section 163.3237, Florida Statutes; or revoked in accordance with Section 163.3241, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1(Exh. A), 2-13-12) 
Secs. 7.5.45-7.5-49. - Reserved 
ARTICLE VII. - PLANNED DEVELOPMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 24, 2011, amended former Art. VII, §§ 7.5-50-7.5-58, to read as herein set out. Former Art. VII pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, adopted April 22, 1991. 

Sec. 7.5-50. - Purpose and intent. 
    The planned development review process established in this article is intended to implement zoning amendment requests for planned developments consistent with the city's comprehensive plan and zoning regulations. The procedures will provide efficient review of zoning amendment requests for the planned development district, with particular attention to levels of service established in the city's comprehensive plan and design and performance criteria established by the city to guide development. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-51. - Applicability. 
    The procedures contained in this article are applicable to all zoning amendment requests for the planned development zoning district. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, erect or alter a building or structure or to develop, change or improve land or to change the use for which an approved final development plan is required by this article, except in accordance with an approved final development plan. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-52. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any planned development application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-53. - Planned development application procedures. 
(I)  Pre-application conference. Before submitting an application, the applicant shall schedule a pre-application conference with the Development Review Committee, to review the proposed development. The applicant shall obtain a copy of the pre-application form from the Community Development Department. The city shall provide written comments to the applicant prior to the Development Review Committee pre-application meeting. 
    The pre-application process serves as an opportunity to examine ideas and share information between the City of Maitland and an applicant for a potential development project, in a conceptual application format. The comments and information provided by the city do not constitute a waiver of any requirements contained in the city's Land Development Code; but are meant to assist in the preparation of the application for formal submittal. A pre-application conference must be held no more than six (6) months prior to filing an application for planned development. 
    Following the pre-application conference, the applicant may submit an application for a planned development which consists of a development plan submittal as well as a zoning amendment. The applicant shall submit the application and supplemental materials to the community development department in quantities designated by the city. 
    Applicants are encouraged to meet with neighborhoods and surrounding property owners/residents prior to formal submittal of an application for planned development to discuss plans for the property that will be subject to the PD zoning and to be able to understand and respond to any valid concerns via design modifications. 
    The application for planned development provides two (2) options to proceed through the application process. They are Option 1 and Option 2. 
    The Option 1 application for planned development provides the opportunity to proceed through the planned development review process and obtain rezoning and development plan approval, but does not require final development plan level information, such as final engineering and final storm water calculations, during this stage of the application process. Selecting Option 1 will not result in a waiver of any requirement stated within the Land Development Code; rather it allows the information to be submitted as part of the site plan review process following city council approval of the planned development application. 
    After the city council has approved the planned development application, the applicant must submit an application for site plan review, pursuant to section 7.5-83(II) of the Maitland City Code, to the development review committee for an administrative review. The site plan review process will require submittal of final engineering and final storm water calculations as well as other detailed application materials necessary to complete the city's technical review of the application and obtain final site plan approval. 
    The Option 2 process allows the applicant to choose to submit final development plan application review materials, including items such as final engineering and sealed and engineered final storm water calculations, listed in section 7.5-56 of the Maitland City Code. Option 2 does not require the SITE PLAN review submittal because final development plan (site plan) review materials are included in this review. 
    Both Option 1 and Option 2 will require the public hearing and public notification processes outlined in section 7.5-53(III) of the Maitland City Code. 
(II)  Sufficiency review for zoning amendment and planned development. All applications for a zoning amendment to a planned development district shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. Applications must be submitted no later than 12:00 noon at least forty (40) days prior to the first or 3rd Thursday of any month. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be processed. 
(III)  Notice of planning and zoning commission hearing. After receipt of a complete petition, the city shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined in Florida Statutes, at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the planning and zoning commission public hearing date on which the petition is to be heard. Notice shall be posted on the property subject to the petition and in two (2) public places, as well as the city web site. Notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property. The distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point on the boundary of the property subject to the planned development zoning amendment petition nearest to the point of the boundary of any surrounding property. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addressed to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax roll in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  A statement that the planned development zoning district classification has been requested for the property; 
(b)  The legal description of the property subject to the petition and a general location map to correspond with the legal description of the property as noted on the hearing notice. This does not mandate publication of the location map in the newspaper noted above unless otherwise required by Florida Statutes. 
(c)  The name of the owner(s) of the property subject to the petition; 
(d)  That a public hearing will be held by the planning and zoning commission; 
(e)  The date, time, and location of the hearing; 
(f)  Advise that the public is invited to attend the hearing and make comment orally or in writing; and 
(g)  The location and times during which an interested party may inspect the petition. 
(IV)  Planning and zoning commission public hearing. The planning and zoning commission public hearing shall be held on the first or third Thursday of the month. Any party may appear in person, or by agent or by attorney to discuss and/or comment on the petition. 
    Following the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission has the option to: 
(a)  Provide an additional review of the application by the planning and zoning commission to finalize its review comments; or 
(b)  Forward its comments to the city council without further review by the planning and zoning commission. 
    In either case, before any recommendation is forwarded to city council, the planning and zoning commission shall make a written finding, certifying consistency with the comprehensive development plan, and finding that satisfactory provision and arrangements have been made concerning the factors itemized for development review committee review. 
    The written finding shall also certify compliance with the specific rules governing planned developments as may be applicable to the application under review. 
(a)  If the planning and zoning commission chooses to review the application again; it shall declare at the public hearing that the application shall be returned following the development review committee's action on the application. After its review is complete, the planning and zoning commission shall forward a recommendation to the city council (including any conditions and findings) for approval, approval with modifications, or denial of the application. 
(b)  The planning and zoning commission may choose to provide a recommendation directly to the city council. In such cases, the planning and zoning commission shall forward instructions to the development review committee regarding the development of detailed conditions to include in the findings and recommendation being forwarded to the city council. The development review committee will then finalize the recommendation for consideration by the city council, unless the development review committee recommendation is contrary to that of the planning and zoning commission recommendation. In this case, the development review committee shall return the recommendation to the planning and zoning commission for finalization. 
(V)  Review by development review committee. Following a public hearing by the planning and zoning commission the development review committee shall review the petition and any testimony that was made at the hearing and shall provide reasonable assistance to the applicant to bring the project in compliance with the Land Development Code and other applicable regulations and agreements. The applicant may continue to work with development review committee until such time that the development review committee determines the proposal is consistent with all applicable regulations and the item is ready to be placed on the next practical planning and zoning commission or city council agenda, if the streamline approach is taken pursuant to 7.5-53.(IV). Should the applicant determine they no longer desire to work with development review committee to resolve the items, the applicant may choose to proceed to the next required planning and zoning commission or city council meeting, where staff shall advise of the applicant's decision to proceed without completing modifications required by development review committee. In all cases, the development review committee will generate and forward a written recommendation that will accompany the petition to the next step of the review process. The development review committee shall make a recommendation for approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the proposed petition. The development review committee shall formulate its recommendation and make findings with regard to the following factors: 
(a)  Ingress and egress to property and proposed structures thereon, with particular reference to automotive and pedestrian safety, connectivity and convenience, traffic flow and control, and access in case of fire or catastrophe; 
(b)  Off-street parking and loading areas, where required, with particular attention to the items in (a) above; 
(c)  The economic, noise, glare or odor effects of the proposed development on the city as a whole and on the surrounding properties; 
(d)  Refuse and service areas, with particular reference to the items in (a) and (b) above; 
(e)  Screening and buffering with reference to type, dimensions, and character; 
(f)  Signs, if any, and proposed exterior lighting with reference to glare, traffic, safety, economic effects, and compatibility and harmony with properties in the area; 
(g)  Required yards and other open space; 
(h)  General compatibility with adjacent properties and other property in the surrounding area; 
(i)  Whether there is compliance with the applicable ordinances and regulations for the proposed development; where compliance is not achieved, whether the development adversely impacts adjacent and surrounding properties and unduly burdens city operations and facilities; 
(j)  Whether the proposed development will lower the applicable levels of service below the levels adopted in the city's comprehensive development plan, and whether the proposed development is phased to be constructed at a time when the adopted service levels are met; 
(k)  Whether the time frames proposed for development are consistent with requirements of the comprehensive plan and other applicable regulations; 
(l)  Whether the phase of development in question can exist as an independent unit capable of creating an environment of substantial desirability and stability; 
(m)  Whether there is substantial compliance with the purpose and intent of the planned development district; 
(n)  Reserved. 
(o)  Whether off-site credits (incentives) proposed (if any) have been satisfactorily addressed, if applicable; 
(p)  Whether mobility strategies for a transportation concurrency exception area (TCEA) are required and have been satisfactorily addressed, if applicable; 
(q)  Whether the existing or proposed utility services and transportation systems are adequate for the proposed development; whether all adopted levels of service have been or will be adequately met; and 
(r)  Whether the proposed development plan is consistent with the comprehensive development plan. 
(s)  Within the Packwood District of Downtown Maitland, a development project of multi-family dwellings (apartments, condominiums, and townhomes); ; mixed -use projects with residential uses on the ground floor; and projects including live/work unit(s) as defined in section 21-21(III)(h)(2); shall also meet the following criteria: 
1.  For projects with frontage on major commercial street Type I - U.S. 17-92 (Orlando Avenue) and Horatio Avenue East of Orlando Avenue and street Type II secondary commercial streets for Horatio Avenue between Orlando Avenue and Maitland Avenue, and for Independence Lane, identified in Section 23-2.4.1, no less than fifty (50) percent of the ground floor square footage of a building or development site shall be allocated to retail, office and/or other commercial uses (Parking garages and any residential accessory uses such as leasing offices, clubhouses and exercise room facilities shall not be considered commercial uses for the purposes of this section.) For any allocation less than fifty (50) percent of the ground floor square footage of a building or development site, approval may only be granted based upon evidence that an allocation of fifty (50) percent or greater of the ground floor square footage as retail, office and/or other commercial uses would not be viable use within the development and evidence that the proposed allocation of residential uses will further the objectives and purposes of the Packwood District described in section 21-21 and section 23-3 of the Maitland City Code. However, in no case shall ground floor commercial square footage be approved at less than twenty-five (25) percent of a building or development site. Buildings fronting the above streets shall have a minimum clear height, measured slab to slab, of fourteen (14) feet for the ground floor. Other floors shall have a minimum clear height of nine (9) feet. 
2.  For any allocation less than twenty-five (25) percent of the ground floor square footage of a building or development site, for projects without frontage on Orlando Avenue, Horatio Avenue or Independence Lane, approval shall only be granted based upon evidence that an allocation of 25% or greater of the ground floor square footage as retail, office and/or other commercial uses would not be a viable use within the development and evidence that the proposed allocation of residential uses will further the objectives and purposes of the Packwood District described in section 21-21 and section 23-2 of the Maitland City Code. 
(t)  Within Sawmill and Waterhouse Districts, for properties fronting Street Type I - major commercial streets U.S 17-92 (Orlando Avenue) identified in section 23-2.4.1, a minimum twenty-five (25) percent of the ground floor square footage of a building or development site shall be allocated to retail, office and/or other commercial uses. (Parking garages and any residential accessory uses such as leasing offices, clubhouses and exercise rooms facilities shall not be considered commercial uses for the purposes of this section.) 
1.  For any allocation of less than twenty-five (25) percent of the ground floor square footage of a building or development site, approval shall only be granted based upon evidence that an allocation of twenty-five (25) or greater of the ground floor square footage as retail, office and/or other commercial uses would not be a viable use within the development and evidence that the proposed allocation of residential uses will further the objectives and purposes of the Sawmill and Waterhouse Districts described in section 21-21 and section 23-2 of the Maitland City Code. 
(u)  Development projects with ground-floor residential in any of the Downtown Districts that fall within the parameters described in section 7.5-53 (V)(s)(2) and (V)(t)(1) above, shall present evidence that the project furthers the purpose of sections 21-21, PD, planned development district and 23-2, Downtown Maitland Special District purpose and intent. 
(VI)  Recommendation by planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission shall make its written recommendation to the city council unless Item (IV)(b) above has been selected. As part of its recommendation to the city council, the planning and zoning commission shall make a written finding certifying consistency with the comprehensive development plan, and that satisfactory provision and arrangement has been made concerning the factors itemized for review by the development review committee in (V) above. 
(VII)  City council hearing and review. Upon consideration of the recommendations of the planning and zoning commission and the development review committee, the city council may elect to introduce an ordinance to effect the zoning amendment for the subject property and set a public hearing date for the proposed ordinance. If the request involves less than five (5) percent of the total land area of the city, the city council shall hold one (1) public hearing with official notice on the matter. If the request involves more than five (5) percent of the total land area of the city, the council shall hold two (2) public hearings on the matter. The public hearing and notices shall be consistent with requirements of the Florida Statutes. 
(VIII)  City council decision. At a regularly scheduled meeting following the introduction of the ordinance to effect the zoning amendment, the city council shall hold a public hearing and may adopt the ordinance to effect the zoning amendment and may accept, or accept with modifications, or reject the final development plan. If the city council rejects the final development plan, it shall also reject the rezoning ordinance. 
    Action by the city council to approve or to approve with conditions, or to deny an application shall be deemed final. Any person aggrieved by action of the city Council may seek recourse to the courts as provided by the laws of Florida. 
(IX)  Failure of city council to act. If a planning and zoning commission recommendation for change is not acted upon by the city council within ninety (90) days of the date of its receipt by city council, the petition upon which the recommendation is based shall be deemed to have been denied. 
(X)  Limitations. Whenever the city council has, by amendment, changed the zoning classification of property, the planning and zoning commission shall not consider any petition for rezoning of any part or all of the same property for a period of one (1) year from the effective date of the amendatory ordinance. 
    Whenever the city council has denied a petition, the city council shall not: 
(a)  Consider any further petition for the same rezoning of any part or all of the same property for a period of one (1) year from the date of such action; 
    The time limits of this subsection may be waived by the affirmative vote of four (4) members of the city council, when such action is deemed necessary to prevent injustice or to facilitate the proper development of the city. 
(XI)  If an applicant utilized Option 1, following approval of the planned development application/zoning amendment, the applicant must submit an application for site plan review by the development review committee, pursuant to the city's Land Development Code. The site plan application is an administrative review and will follow the submittal requirements outlined in section 7.5 83(II) of the Maitland City Code for site plan reviews. 
    In conjunction with the site plan review process, the development review committee shall make these additional findings with regard to the following factors: 
(a)  Whether there is substantial compliance with the preliminary development plan and PD ordinance; 
(b)  Whether the phase of development in question can exist as an independent unit capable of creating an environment of substantial desirability and stability; 
(c)  Whether the existing or proposed utility services and transportation systems are adequate for the proposed development; whether all adopted levels of service have been or will be adequately met; and that any accompanying engineering plans have been approved by the city; and 
(d)  Whether the proposed site plan is consistent with the comprehensive development plan. 
    If an applicant utilized Option 2, following approval of the planned development application/zoning amendment ordinance, an applicant may proceed to the site permitting and building permitting processes of the City of Maitland. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1305, § 5, 4-11-16 ; Ord. No. 1323, § 4, 8-14-17 ; Ord. No. 1324, § 2, 9-25-17 ) 
Sec. 7.5-54. - Administration of building permits. 
    The building official shall approve all permits for site preparation, buildings and structures in the area covered by the approved planned development final development plan application and to insure conformity with the approved application and with all other applicable ordinances and regulations. After approval of an application, the modification or alteration of any buildings, structures or land areas shall be in substantial accordance with the approved application and development plan. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-55. - Revision of development plan. 
    Minor changes to an approved planned development application and final development plan may be permitted after review and approval by the community development director, provided the changes are substantially consistent with the purposes and intent of the approved planned development and final development plan, and provided that they conform to all other applicable city ordinances and regulations. Changes are considered minor if they include the following: 
(a)  Realignment of an internal roadway or curb cut to improve traffic flow, turn movements or other safety considerations. 
(b)  Relocate parking or retention areas within the site to increase percolation or reduce runoff from the site (over and above the approved site plan). 
(c)  Add or delete less than five (5) percent of the structural square footage of the project. 
(d)  Relocate the orientation of the footprint of a building provided it maintains the same distance from the existing single-family development. 
(e)  Decrease density, height, intensity or building coverage. 
(f)  Realignment of an approved wall, fence, or hedge to avoid existing trees or attempt to resolve a problem peculiar to the site. 
(g)  Amend sign package provided it does not increase in sign area by more than ten (10) percent. 
(h)  Addition of a children's play area including construction of a fence or wall for security of the play area. 
    The community development director may, at his sole discretion, pass any of the items (a) through (h) onto the development review committee for their consideration. 
    All changes not specifically listed in this section may be considered by, and may be approved by, the development review committee as a minor change if determined to be substantially consistent with the approved development plan and development order and provided that the proposed change(s) do not result in a substantial deviation from the approved development plan and development order. Substantial deviation shall mean a change to an accepted overall development plan and development order which creates a reasonable likelihood of adverse impact to any portion of the project devoted to a specific use or to adjacent properties. Any decision rendered by the development review committee may be appealed to the city council within thirty (30) days of the date that the decision is rendered. 
    However, following consideration of the proposed revision, should the development review committee determine the change does not qualify as a minor revision, then the revision(s) shall be forwarded to the planning and zoning commission and city council for final approval. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-56. - Planned development application requirements-Option 1 and Option 2. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the planned development district zoning amendment and development plan application, in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials, must be supplied in quantities as specified on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(1)  Planned development zoning amendment and development plan. 
(a)  Completed application form for planned development. A completed application form for planned development, with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and agent(s), statement indicating the request, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. Any intent to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the community development department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  List of property owners. The names and mailing addresses of all property owners of real property within five hundred (500) feet of outer perimeter of subject property, taken from the most recent tax rolls in Orange or Seminole Counties. The five-hundred-foot distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point of the boundary of the subject property nearest to the point of the boundary of any surrounding property. 
(d)  Authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(e)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Vicinity map drawn to a noted scale and showing: 
a.  The location of the proposed planned development; 
b.  Relationships to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding areas (within five hundred (500) feet). 
OPTION 1 SUPPLEMENTAL SUBMITTAL REQUIREMENTS 
2.  Site plan drawn to a noted scale and to include: 
a.  Boundary survey and legal description of the property prepared by a surveyor registered by the State of Florida under a surveyor's seal the date of certification not in excess of one year and with gross and net land area provided, which may be on a separate sheet. 
b.  Street address (if applicable); 
c.  An arrow indicating north and noted scale; 
d.  Existing and proposed easements and rights-of-way; 
e.  Required yard and set back information; 
f.  Required off-street parking detail (number and location); 
g.  Indicate accessible parking; 
h.  Loading areas, service and refuse areas; 
i.  The layout of bikeways and pedestrian ways and connections to facilities in adjacent developments; 
j.  Any proposed streets, potential alleys and access easements and, include any connections to adjacent property(ies); 
k.  Locations of ingress/egress to property (existing and proposed); 
l.  Potential or planned internal traffic circulation patterns; 
The general layout of major roads in the project, along with potential traffic controls and any mass transit facilities to be provided; and/or mobility enhancements or strategies proposed if any; 
m.  Width, and laneage of all adjacent rights-of-way (existing and proposed); 
n.  Open space (provide anticipated range of total acreage for open space and provide a description of what areas have been counted in the calculation); 
o.  Recreation areas (if applicable); 
p.  Permeable and impermeable surface areas (describe areas counted in each category and provide anticipated range of total acreage in text form); 
q.  Existing and proposed building(s) located on site and indicate structural height and square footage; (indicate floor area ratio(s) range in text form); 
r.  Clearly identify existing and proposed land uses on site; 
s.  Items to be demolished; and 
t.  Indicate whether development is a gated community. 
3.  Grading Concept Plan/Drainage/Utility Plan to include: 
a.  General location, size and description of stormwater drainage facilities including retaining walls and elevation or grade changes in excess of two feet, sewage collection and water distribution systems including location of any proposed or existing fire hydrants; 
b.  All other existing service location and lines if available on or adjacent to the site; and 
c.  The topographic information must delineate the mean high water elevations for each water body and the one-hundred-year flood elevations throughout the site, if applicable. Jurisdictional wetland lines shall be illustrated. 
4.  Fire flow. In order for the fire department to establish gpm requirements for the proposed project, the following information shall be provided to the fire marshal prior to submitting application: 
a.  Type(s) of construction and total gross square footage for the proposed facility per the Florida Building Code; 
b.  Whether the building is protected with fire sprinklers; and 
c.  General location and provision of Fire Service Facilities such as hydrant locations and water main sizes. 
5.  Tree survey drawn at the same scale as the site plan (for applications with property one (1) acre or larger). A map of existing trees, indicating type, caliper, and character, and including all threatened species, endangered or species of special concern and all preservable trees six (6) inches or more in diameter. 
6.  Schematic landscape plan showing: 
a.  Proposed landscape areas, including berms, screening and buffers (reference general plant list, buffer types and canopy points). 
b.  Location, height and material for walkways, fences, walls and other manmade landscape features; and 
c.  Existing vegetation to be preserved. 
7.  Conceptual building elevations for all sides including structural heights, general architectural style and character, and materials list options. 
8.  Existing building uses, listed for all buildings (if any) and intended use of each building or portion thereof. 
9.  Level of service data and analysis. Data addressing adopted levels of service, and an analysis of parking requirements, including time of use, to support request. Data shall include, but not limited to, preliminary assessment of traffic impact and trip generation study, stormwater drainage, water, sewer and parks; and in a format acceptable to the community development director. 
10.  Soils Map. Soils classification map demonstrating soils on site. Soil analysis or geotechnical report by a professional soils expert shall be furnished upon request at or immediately after the pre-application meeting. 
11.  Conceptual signs and lighting. For signs include height, location, materials and overall square footage for each sign proposed; include type, height, location and illumination data, (cut sheet) for lighting proposed, if any. Indicate location and square footage of existing signage on site. 
12.  Phasing plan. A description of the priority and phasing of development including time frames and the manner in which each phase of development can exist as an independent unit capable of creating an environment of sustained desirability and stability. 
13.  Common area/facility management. A statement indicating the type of legal instruments that will be created and provisions for the management of common areas and facilities. 
14.  Reduced site plan. A reduced copy of the site plan with land use information, on 8-and-one-half-inch by eleven-inch paper suitable for copying and mailing. 
15.  Tables. 
a.  A table showing acreage ranges for each category of land use, including roads, open space and recreation. 
b.  A table of proposed gross and net density ranges for residential land uses. 
c.  A table of proposed floor area ratio ranges for the project. 
16.  Wildlife inventory plan. An inventory of wildlife species on site, including species categorized as endangered, threatened or of special concern status. A description of techniques and practices proposed to protect endangered, threatened, or species of special concern status. 
17.  Energy efficiencies. Description of proposed energy-efficient site design techniques and land development practices proposed to reduce long-term energy commitments. 
18.  List or letter identifying requested code variations or flexibility and unique characteristics or design enhancements to benefit city. 
Should an item listed under the category of Supplemental Information be determined by the Community Development Director (or designee) as not applicable to a particular application, the item(s) may be waived upon request of the applicant and authorization by the city, without affecting the sufficiency of the application.

Boundary survey and the legal description of the property prepared by a surveyor registered by the State of Florida under a surveyor's seal and including total acres of site, with gross and net land area provided, which may be on a separate sheet; and the date of certification not in excess of one year;

a.  Type of construction for the proposed facility per Florida Building Code;

e.  The hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to the Fire Marshal, or designee for review and acceptance.

Data shall include, but not be limited to, traffic, storm water drainage, water, sewer, and parks and be in a format acceptable to the community development director. Include the attached water/sewer level of service analysis signed and sealed by an engineer.

c.  Table showing specific delineation, use location, size and staging of development for each common open space, recreational area, and public or semi-public area. The amount of each space type shall be expressed as a percentage of the total site area.

as not applicable to a particular application, the item(s) may be waived upon request of the applicant and authorization by the city, without affecting the sufficiency of the application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-57. - Planned development time limitations. 
    If construction of the building(s), as determined by the building official's application of the Florida Building Code, has not begun within five (5) years after the approval of a final development plan for the first phase of the planned development, or the building permit for construction of the building(s) has become void after the five-year period has expired, the approval of the final development plan shall lapse. Upon request of the applicant prior to the lapse of approval, the city council may waive the time limitation above and grant a time extension for a period of up to one (1) year (three hundred sixty-five (365) days) when the city council deems such action is necessary to prevent injustice or to facilitate the proper development of the city. At its discretion, and for good cause, the city council may extend for one (1) additional year the period for beginning construction. If the approved final development plan lapses under this provision, the zoning administrator shall notify the property owner of the lapse of approval for the preliminary development plan and the final development plan and inform the property owner that resubmission under the procedure outlined for this district will be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1309, § 6, 6-27-16 ) 
Sec. 7.5-58, 7.5-59. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VIII. - RIGHT-OF-WAY/UTILITY EASEMENT ABANDONMENT 

Sec. 7.5-60. - Purpose and intent. 
    The procedures established in this article are intended to provide for an orderly and efficient review of public easements or rights-of-way which are desired for various reasons to be closed, vacated or abandoned. The procedures ensure coordination with utility needs and public interests, and consistency with Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-61. - Applicability. 
    The procedures in this article are applicable to any person, firm or entity, including a governmental entity other than the city, seeking to close, vacate or abandon an easement or right-of-way in the city. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-62. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-63. - Application procedures. 
(I)  Sufficiency review. All applications for a right-of-way abandonment or utility easement vacation in the city shall be submitted to the public works director. The public works director will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. Should the applicant fail to submit all information as required within five (5) days, the application will not be considered complete and will not be accepted. 
(II)  Review and recommendation by the development review committee. After receipt of a complete petition, the development review committee shall review the petition based on existing and future needs of the city, and shall make a recommendation to the city council for approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the petition. 
(III)  City council decision. Upon consideration of the recommendations of the development review committee, the city council may elect to introduce an ordinance to effect the petition. Public hearings and notices shall be consistent with requirements of Florida Statutes. 
Sec. 7.5-64. - Application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the right-of-way/utility easement abandonment application in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials must be supplied in quantities as specified by the public works director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(a)  Completed application form for right-of-way/utility abandonment. A completed application form for right-of-way/utility abandonment, with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and agent(s), statement indicating request, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the public works department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the public works department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  Applicant authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(d)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Vicinity map drawn to a noted scale and showing: 
a.  The location of the proposed easement or right-of-way; 
b.  Relationships to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding areas (within five hundred (500) feet). 
2.  Copy of plat or deed showing portion thereof for which vacation is sought. 
3.  Legal description of street, alley, or easement to be closed or vacated. 
4.  Letters of approval from all utility companies (electric, gas, cable, and telephone) and, if under administration of Orange County or the state, letters of approval from appropriate jurisdictions. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Secs. 7.5-65-7.5-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ROAD ACCESS TO STATE ROADS 

Sec. 7.5-70. - Purpose and intent. 
    The Florida Legislature has passed 335.18 through 335.188, Florida Statutes, the "State Highway System Access Management Act," which expresses the legislative intent that local governments assert an active role, in cooperation with the Florida Department of Transportation, in planning and controlling access to the Florida State Highway System. 
    In addition, the State Highway System Access Management Act authorizes local governments to require access permits from persons seeking to install additional connections to the state highway system within such local government's jurisdiction, including the responsibility to develop access-permitting standards and to grant or deny access permit applications. 
    Therefore, the city has determined that municipal regulation of connections to the public streets, roads and other rights-of-way within the city would greatly promote the public welfare and safety, assist in coordinating land use planning decisions, and aid in reducing the city's traffic congestion problem. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-71. - Applicability. 
    Any person, firm or entity, including a governmental entity other than the city, seeking to connect, alter or improve access to the state highway system within the city must first apply for and receive an access permit from the city. Such access permit shall be in addition to any permit required by the Florida Department of Transportation (DOT) as a prerequisite to connection to the State Highway System, and receipt of an access permit from the city neither relieves the recipient from the necessity to obtain a permit from DOT nor guarantees the right to connect to the state highway system. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-72. - Schedule of fees. 
    The application shall be accompanied by payment to the city of an application fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Until this fee has been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 7.5-73. - Application procedure and requirements. 
(I)  Any person, firm or entity, including a governmental entity other than the city, seeking to connect, alter or improve access to the state highway system within the city, must first file an application for access permit with the public works director. Such application in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials must be supplied in quantities as specified by the public works director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(a)  Completed application form for access permit. A completed application form for access permit, with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and agent(s) statement indicating request, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the public works department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the public works department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  Applicant authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(d)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Legal description or street address of the parcel of land on which the improvement is proposed to be placed as well as a statement of all persons owning any legal or beneficial rights in such land. 
2.  Vicinity map. A scaled sketch of the proposed improvement when completed, accurately depicting dimensions, elevations, grade, angle of intersection with right-of-way, and any curbs, gutters, sidewalks, gates, existing and proposed signals and traffic control signage, or other associated improvements. 
3.  Construction details. A statement as to what construction materials will be used in the improvement including an estimate of the duration of such construction. 
4.  Level of service data and analysis. A statement as to what type of vehicular use the improvement will be put, including estimates of average and peak vehicle trips per day over such improvement, an assessment of the resulting effects on the level of service for the roadway and the two (2) closest intersections, and the increase if any to average or peak hour vehicle trips per day over the road to which the improvement gives access. 
(II)  For the purpose of administering this section, the word "improvements" shall mean "any roadway which is a part of the state highway system within the city, whether or not publicly dedicated, for any purpose related to widening or repairing existing access". This definition is intended to include all improvements of every kind to roadways and adjacent real property which could in any way affect traffic volumes on the state highway system within the city, and should be read broadly so as to effectuate that intent. 
(III)  Following submission of the application for access permit, the director of public works (director) shall have a period of not more than ninety (90) days for staff review of the proposed connection. Should the department of public works (the department) determine that a longer review period is required to thoroughly assess the probable impact of the proposed connection upon the city, the director shall notify the applicant at least fourteen (14) business days before the expiration of the aforementioned ninety-day period that extended review will be necessary. The department shall evaluate the proposed connection in light of its probable effects upon the state highway system, traffic flow and vehicular congestion, public safety, quality of life and the natural environment within the city. 
(IV)  The following are hereby adopted as minimum standards for the department to use in evaluating access permit applications, and the department is hereby authorized to adopt such further standards as it finds necessary to achieve the ends expressed in section 7.5-72 above: 
(a)  The standards contained in the comprehensive plan for the city. 
(b)  The standards contained in the DOT manual, "Policy and Guidelines for Vehicular Connections to the State Highway System." 
(c)  The standards contained in Florida Administrative Code Rule 9J-2.055 for measuring traffic volume; specifically, "level of service" as defined in F.A.C. Rule 9J-02.055(3)(e) and "peak hour vehicle trips" by which such levels of service are computed. The department shall deny a permit for any improvement which the department estimates will result in either (1) a ten-percent or greater increase in average or peak vehicle trips per day, or (2) reduction of the level of service of the roadway to which an applicant desires to make an improvement. 
(V)  If the director finds that the proposed access will meet the requirements of this article, he shall issue a permit therefor. The director is hereby authorized and empowered to revoke any permit issued by him pursuant to this article, upon the failure of the holder thereof to comply with any provision of the article. Any decision or action made or taken by the director pursuant to this article may be appealed in writing to the city council within thirty (30) days after any such decision or action. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2, 4-22-91) 
Secs. 7.5-74-7.5-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SITE PLAN AND PERMITTED CONDITIONAL USE REVIEW PROCESS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 24, 2011, repealed former Art. X, §§ 7.5-80-7.5-89 in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. X pertained to the site plan review process and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, April 22, 1991; Ord. No. 995, §§ 71, 72, March 27, 2000. 
Cross reference- Comprehensive development plan generally, § 12-13 et seq. 

Sec. 7.5-80. - Purpose and intent. 
    The site plan and permitted conditional use review processes established in this article are intended to implement the requirements of the city's comprehensive development plan. This process will provide an efficient review process for nonresidential development, multiple family development, mixed-use development, and redevelopment. The purpose is to implement the orderly review of applications for development and redevelopment proposed in the city with particular attention to levels of service established in the comprehensive development plan, design and performance criteria established by the city for special and overlay districts (e.g. Downtown Maitland, Maitland West Side Overlay, Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District, Cultural Corridor, Horatio Avenue Special District), and compliance with the specific rules governing permitted conditional uses designated in the Maitland City Code. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-81. - Applicability. 
(I)  The site plan review procedures contained within this article are applicable to: 
(a)  All projects which involve the construction of any facility other than single-family dwellings as a principal use or major appurtenances thereto (e.g. private swimming pool, yard, fence, etc.) or duplex residential units. 
(b)  All redevelopment projects which add to the total square footage of a structure, (e.g., non-residential, multiple-family or mixed use development). 
(c)  All projects which require the site plan review process due to location within a special district or overlay district such as: 
1.  Downtown Maitland Permitted Use (no design waivers); 
2.  Downtown Maitland Permitted Use (with design waivers); 
3.  Downtown Maitland Conditional Use (with or without design waivers); 
4.  Maitland West Side Overlay with no design or development plan waivers or exceptions; 
5.  Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District (with frontage on Maitland Avenue); 
6.  Cultural Corridor District (including a change of use); 
7.  Horatio Avenue Corridor; 
8.  Applications for developments for which a Development Agreement (DA) has been approved by the city of Maitland and the Site Plan review process is required by the DA. 
(d)  Floating Zone - Public/Semi Public Uses - (Principal Use(s)). 
(II)  The permitted conditional use review procedures contained in this article are applicable to projects: 
(a)  Which contain or are proposed to contain a use designated as a permitted conditional use for the applicable district; or 
(b)  Which involve exceptions to Maitland West Side Overlay-Development Standards. 
(c)  Which increase Downtown Maitland Density/Intensity within Transit Oriented District A (TOD-A) and/or Incentives/Bonuses. 
    An approved site plan or permitted conditional use, approved through the respective processes, is required prior to the issuance of any permits. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, erect or alter a building or structure or to develop, change or improve land for which a site plan or permitted conditional use is required by this article except in accordance with an approved site plan or permitted conditional use. 
    Where there are conflicts and discrepancies with other city policies, ordinances or regulations, the more restrictive requirements shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-82. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges, expenses, and a collection process for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges, and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-83. - Application procedure. 
(I)  Pre-application and filing procedures. 
(a)  Pre-application conference. Before submitting an application, the applicant shall schedule a pre-application conference with the development review committee to review the proposed development. The applicant shall obtain a copy of the pre-application form from the community development department. The city shall provide written comments to the applicant prior to the development review committee pre-application meeting. 
The pre-application process serves as an opportunity to examine ideas and share information between the City of Maitland and an applicant for a potential development project, in a conceptual application format. The comments and information provided by the city do not constitute a waiver of any requirements contained in the City's Land Development Code; but are meant to assist in the preparation of the application for formal submittal. A pre-application conference must be held no more than six (6) months prior to filing an application. 
Following the pre-application conference, the applicant may submit an application for processing by the city. The applicant shall submit the application and supplemental materials to the community development department in quantities designated by the city. 
Applicants are encouraged to meet with neighborhoods and surrounding property owners/residents prior to formal submittal of an application to discuss plans for the property and to be able to understand and respond to any valid concerns. 
(b)  Application filed and sufficiency review. Applications for site plan or permitted conditional use approval shall be submitted to the zoning administrator or designee. Applications must be submitted at least forty (40) days prior to the first or third Thursday of any month. 
    The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be processed. 
(II)  Development review committee review-Administrative site plan review and decision process. 
(a)  The administrative site plan review process shall be required for development applications that: 
1.  Involve the construction of any facility other than single-family dwellings as a principal use or major appurtenances thereto (e.g. private swimming pool, yard, fence, etc.) or duplex residential units. 
2.  Add to the total square footage of a structure, (e.g. non-residential, multiple-family or mixed use development). 
3.  Are located within a special district or an overlay district, for example: 
a.  Downtown Maitland permitted use with no design waivers. 
b.  Maitland West Side with no exceptions or development plan waivers. 
4.  Involve projects for which a development agreement has been approved by the City of Maitland, unless specified otherwise within the D.A. 
(b)  Following its review of the application for development, the development review committee shall approve, approve with changes, or deny the application. Such action shall be taken within twenty-one (21) days of the date the application is determined sufficient by the zoning administrator. 
All development review committee decisions and recommendations shall be written, certifying consistency with the comprehensive development plan and compliance with the specific rules and specific criteria governing the special or overlay district as applicable, and addressing whether or not satisfactory provision and arrangement has been made concerning the following: 
1.  Ingress and egress to property and proposed structures thereon with particular reference to automotive and pedestrian safety and convenience, traffic flow and control, and access in case of fire or catastrophe; 
2.  Off-street parking and loading areas, where required, with particular attention to the items in 1. above, and the economic, noise, glare or odor effects on adjoining properties and properties generally in the zoning district; 
3.  Refuse and service areas, with particular reference to the items in 1. and 2. above; 
4.  Utilities, with reference to locations, availability and compatibility; 
5.  Screening and buffering with reference to type, dimensions, and character; 
6.  Signs, if any, and proposed exterior lighting with reference to glare, traffic, safety, economic effects, and compatibility and harmony with properties in the district; 
7.  Required yards and other open space; 
8.  General compatibility with adjacent properties and other property in the surrounding area; 
9.  Whether there is compliance with the applicable ordinances and regulations for the proposed development; 
10.  Whether the proposed development will lower the applicable levels of service below the levels adopted in the city's comprehensive development plan and whether the proposed development is phased to be constructed at a time when the adopted service levels are met; 
11.  Incentives and development bonuses requested if applicable; 
12.  Off-site credits requested if applicable. 
13.  Mobility strategies, if applicable, for a transportation concurrency exception area. 
(d)  The criteria listed in paragraph (b) above shall be applicable to all development review committee reviews specified within this article. 
(e)  Any person or persons, or any board, taxpayer, department, or bureau of the city jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the development review committee may petition the city council for review of the decision. The petition must be filed with the community development department within thirty (30) days of the determination of the commission. 
(III)  Planning and zoning commission review and decision process for projects within a special district or overlay district involving design or development plan waivers and applicable for areas such as those further described in (a) through (f) below. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall hold a public hearing for development applications where design or development plan waivers are requested and where the project is located within special district or overlay districts designated in the comprehensive development plan. Any party may appear in person, or by agent or by attorney. Such applications include such as: 
(a)  Maitland Avenue Corridor (with frontage on Maitland Avenue). 
(b)  Cultural Corridor (including a change of use). 
(c)  Horatio Avenue Corridor. 
(d)  Downtown Maitland permitted use (with design waivers). 
(e)  Downtown Maitland conditional use (with or without design waivers). 
(f)  Floating zone public/semi public-Principal use(s). 
(g)  Multiple family residential-New development. 
    Notice of planning and zoning commission hearing: The city shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined in Florida Statutes, at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the planning and zoning commission public hearing date on which the petition is to be heard. Notice shall be posted on the property subject to the application and in two (2) public places, as well as the city web site. Notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property. The distance shall be measured by a straight line from the boundary of the property subject to the application nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addressed to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax roll in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  A statement that a site plan or permitted conditional use has been requested; 
(b)  The legal description of the property subject to the petition; and a general location map to correspond with the legal description of the property as noted on the hearing notice. This does not mandate publication of the location map in the newspaper noted above unless otherwise required by the Florida Statutes; 
(c)  The name of the owner(s) of the property subject to the petition; 
(d)  Notification that a public hearing will be held by the planning and zoning commission; 
(e)  The date, time, and location of the hearing; 
(f)  Advice that the public is invited to attend the hearing and make comment orally or in writing; and 
(g)  The location and times during which an interested party may inspect the petition. 
    Following the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall provide instructions to the development review committee for consideration in their review of the processed application. 
    The development review committee shall review the petition and any public testimony that was made at the hearing and shall provide reasonable assistance to the applicant to bring the project in compliance with the Land Development Code and other applicable regulations and agreements. The applicant may continue to work with development review committee until such time that the development review committee determines the proposal is consistent with all applicable regulations and the item is ready to be placed on the next practical planning and zoning commission or city council agenda, if the streamline approach is taken pursuant to 7.5-83.(IV). Should the applicant determine they no longer desire to work with development review committee to resolve the items, the applicant may choose to proceed to the next required planning and zoning commission or city council meeting, where staff shall advise of the applicant's decision to proceed without completing modifications required by development review committee. In all cases, the development review committee will generate and forward a written recommendation that will accompany the petition to the next step of the review process. Upon completing its review of the application, the development review committee shall recommend approval, approval with changes or denial of the application. In doing so, the development review committee shall formulate its recommendation and make findings with regard to the criteria outlined in subsection (II)(b) above. 
    Upon consideration of the recommendations of the development review committee, the planning and zoning commission may approve, approve with conditions or deny the request. In doing so, the planning and zoning commission shall make a written finding, certifying consistency with the comprehensive development plan, and finding that satisfactory provision and arrangement has been made concerning the factors itemized for review by the development review committee referenced in subsection (II)(b) above. The written finding shall also certify compliance with the specific rules and specific criteria governing the special or overlay district or Downtown Maitland Conditional Use. 
    Any person or persons, or any board, taxpayer, department, or bureau of the city jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the commission may petition the city council for review of the decision. The petition must be filed with the community development department within thirty (30) days of the determination of the commission. 
(IV)  City council review and decision process for a permitted conditional use, exceptions to Maitland West Side Development Standards and for increases in Downtown Maitland density/intensity within transit oriented district A (TOD-A) and/or incentives/bonuses. 
    For applications which involve the application types designated below, the planning and zoning commission shall hold a public hearing on the first or third Thursday of the month. The hearing notification process shall be as written in (III) Notice of planning and zoning commission hearing above. 
(a)  Permitted conditional use (except for Downtown Maitland Conditional Use). 
(b)  Exception(s) to Maitland West Side Development Standards. 
(c)  Downtown Maitland projects within TOD-A requesting density or intensity bonuses, and those developments seeking to utilize incentives involving financial contributions made by the developer/applicant, land donations, land swaps, land dedications, use of city-owned lands, or financial obligations or continuing maintenance by the city; any allocation or rebate of tax increment financing (TIF) monies, anything requiring approval of other governmental agencies, those requiring or subject to an interlocal agreement, those involving an amendment to an existing resolution or ordinance, or impacting the city's capital improvement program, shall be processed pursuant to subsection IV; or shall pursue a D.A. with final site plan review consistent with the process listed within subsection (II) 4. within this chapter. 
    Following the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission has the option to: 
(a)  Provide an additional review of the application by the planning and zoning commission to finalize its review comments; or 
(b)  Forward its comments to the city council without further review by the planning and zoning commission. 
    In any case, before any recommendation is forwarded to city council, the planning and zoning commission shall make a written finding, certifying consistency with the comprehensive development plan, and finding that satisfactory provision and arrangement have been made concerning the factors itemized for development review committee review. 
    The written finding shall also certify compliance with the specific rules governing individual permitted conditional uses and specific criteria required in a special or overlay district as applicable to the application under review. 
(a)  If the planning and zoning commission chooses to review the application again; it shall declare at the public hearing that the application shall be returned to them following the development review committee's action on the application. After its review is complete, the planning and zoning commission shall forward a recommendation to the city council (including any conditions and findings) for approval, approval with modifications, or denial of the application. 
(b)  The planning and zoning commission may choose to provide a recommendation directly to the city council. In such cases, the planning and zoning commission shall forward instructions to the development review committee regarding the development of detailed conditions to include in the findings and recommendation being forwarded to the city council. The development review committee will then finalize the recommendation for consideration by the city council, unless the development review committee recommendation is contrary to that of the planning and zoning commission recommendation. In this case, the development review committee shall return the recommendation to the planning and zoning commission for finalization. 
    City council decision. Upon consideration of the recommendation of the planning and zoning commission, the city council may approve, approve with conditions and/or modifications or deny the request. If required by Florida Statutes, the city council shall hold a public hearing(s) prior to making a final decision. 
    Action by the city council to approve or to approve with conditions, or to deny an application shall be deemed final. Any person aggrieved by action of the city council may seek recourse to the courts as provided by the laws of Florida. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1324 , 9-25-17) 
Sec. 7.5-84. - Administration of building permits. 
    The building official shall approve all permits for site preparation, buildings and structures in the area covered by the approved site plan to insure conformity with the approved plan and with all other applicable ordinances and regulations. After approval through the site plan or permitted conditional use processes, the modification or alteration of any buildings, structures or land areas shall be in substantial accordance with those approvals. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-85. - Revisions. 
    Minor changes to an approved site plan, permitted conditional use or exception to Maitland West Side may be permitted after review and approval by the community development director, provided the changes are substantially consistent with the purposes and intent of the approved site plan or permitted conditional use, and provided that they conform to all other applicable ordinances and regulations. Changes are considered minor if they include the following: 
(a)  Realignment of an internal roadway or curb cut to improve traffic flow, turn movements or other safety considerations. 
(b)  Relocate parking or pond within the site to increase percolation or reduce runoff from the site (over and above the approved site plan). 
(c)  Add or delete less than five (5) percent of the structural square footage of the project. 
(d)  Relocate the orientation of the footprint of a building, provided it maintains the same distance from the existing single-family residential development. 
(e)  Decrease density, height, intensity or building coverage. 
(f)  Realignment of an approved wall, fence or hedge to avoid existing trees or attempt to resolve a problem peculiar to the site. 
(g)  Amend sign package provided it does not increase in sign area by more than ten (10) percent. 
(h)  Addition of a children's play area including construction of a fence or wall for security of the play area. 
    The community development director may, at his sole discretion, pass any of the items (a) through (h) onto the development review committee for their consideration.
