    All changes not specifically listed in this section may be considered by and may be approved by the development review committee as a minor change(s), if determined to be substantially consistent with the approved development plan and development order, and provided that the proposed change(s) do not result in a substantial deviation from the approved development plan and development order. Substantial deviation shall mean a change to an accepted overall development plan and development order which creates a reasonable likelihood of adverse impact to any portion of the project devoted to a specific use or to adjacent properties. Any decision rendered by the development review committee may be appealed to the city council within thirty (30) days of the date that the decision is rendered. 
    Should the development review committee determine that a proposed change is not substantially consistent with the approved development order, the development review committee in its sole discretion, may choose to forward a revision to the planning and zoning commission for review. The development review committee's determination to forward a revision to the planning and zoning commission may be based on a finding of inconsistency with approved design standards or specifications, incompatibility with the CDP, substantial deviation from the approved plan or for any other reason determined by the development review committee to require planning and zoning commission review. 
    Any decision rendered by the planning and zoning commission may be appealed to the city council within thirty (30) days of the date that the decision is rendered. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-86. - Application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the application, in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials, must be supplied in quantities as specified by the community development director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(a)  Completed application form for review. A completed application form, with the name, address and telephone number of applicant, property owner, and agent, statement indicating request, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the community development department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  List of property owners (for uses required for board reviews). The names and mailing addresses of all property owners of real property within five hundred (500) feet of outer perimeter of subject property, taken from most recent tax rolls in Orange or Seminole Counties. The five-hundred (500) foot distance shall be measured by a straight line from the boundary of the subject property nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. 
(d)  Applicant authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(e)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Vicinity map drawn to a noted scale and showing: 
a.  The location of the property subject to the petition; 
b.  Relationships to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding areas (within five hundred (500) feet). 
2.  Site plan drawn to a noted scale and to include: 
a.  Boundary survey and the legal description of the property prepared by a surveyor registered by the State of Florida under a surveyor's seal with the date of certification not in excess of one year. Provide gross and net land area which may be provided on a separate sheet. 
b.  Street address (if applicable); 
c.  North arrow and noted scale; 
d.  Required yard and setback information; 
e.  Required off-street: parking detail (number and location), loading areas, service and refuse areas; 
f.  The layout of bikeways and pedestrian ways; 
g.  Locations of ingress/egress to property (existing and proposed); 
h.  Open space (provide total acreage for open space); (provide a description of what areas have been counted in the calculation); 
i.  Recreation areas (if applicable); 
j.  Permeable surface area (describe and provide total in text form as well); 
k.  Existing and proposed building(s) located on site and indicate structural height, and, square footage; (indicate floor area ratios in text form); 
l.  Width, pavement type, and laneage of all adjacent rights-of-way; 
m.  Accessible parking, including details, location and accessible route to building with elevations; 
n.  Location and proposed dimension of sidewalk(s) and walkway(s) and connections to facilities in adjacent developments; 
o.  Any proposed streets, alleys and access easements and, include any connections to adjacent property(ies); 
p.  Internal traffic circulation patterns; 
q.  Access to all new buildings by fire/rescue apparatus shall be as required by applicable sections of the Florida Fire Prevention Code, current edition, and Chapter 6, city Fire Code; 
r.  Turning radii for fire engines shall be twenty (20) inside and forty (40) outside diameter; turning radii for ladder or aerial trucks shall be twenty-five (25) inside and fifty (50) outside, in accordance with manufacturer's specifications; 
s.  Roadways to be designed to sustain the weight of fire apparatus; minimum design; 
t.  Dead-end fire department access roads in excess of 150 feet in length shall be provided with approved provisions for the fire apparatus to turn around; and 
u.  Indicate gross and net density(ies) for residential development, floor area ratio for non-residential development and Site FAR for Downtown Maitland (if applicable). 
3.  Grading concept plan/utility service plan to include: 
a.  Proposed contour lines or point/spot elevations; and extending twenty-five (25) feet beyond the property boundary. Existing contour lines screened as background. 
b.  Location, size and description of drainage, sewage collection and water distribution systems; and including location of any proposed or existing fire hydrants. Service plans to include runoff retainage. 
c.  Existing utilities on or adjacent to the site, including connection details. 
d.  Note finished floor elevation and perimeter. 
e.  Plan(s) to include footprint of existing and proposed site improvements for evaluating the grading and drainage systems. 
All plans are to be drawn at a scale of one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet or greater. 
4.  Fire flow: 
a.  Type of construction for the proposed facility per the Florida Building Code; 
b.  Total square footage; 
c.  Whether the building is protected with fire sprinklers; 
d.  The minimum required fire flow per building shall be provided by the Fire Marshal; 
e.  Engineered hydraulic calculations shall be accomplished to prove the required fire flow is available. The minimum acceptable design pressure shall not be less than twenty-five (25) psi for these calculations. 
f.  The hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to the Fire Marshal for review and acceptance. 
5.  Landscape plan pursuant to Chapter 8 Landscape, Treescape, Streetscape: The landscape plan shall be drawn at a noted scale of at least 1? = 30' and be signed and sealed by a landscape architect. 
a.  Proposed landscape areas, including berms and buffers (reference species type, dimensions and character at planting, as well as spot elevations and contours for berms); 
b.  Species of tree, caliper and condition of preservable existing trees greater than six (6) inches DBH; 
c.  Location, height and material for walkways, fences, walls and other manmade landscape features; 
d.  Existing vegetation to be preserved (reference species type, dimensions and character); 
e.  Relocation and/or preservation management process, if applicable; 
f.  Irrigation plan (note G.P.D./usage); 
g.  An arrow indicating north; 
h.  Plan must include screening and buffering (reference, type, dimensions, and character) and interior parking and service areas. 
6.  Topography plan indicating existing contours at one-foot intervals, based on U.S. Geodetic Datum and extending twenty-five (25) feet beyond the property boundaries. The topographic map must delineate the mean high water elevations for each water body and the one-hundred-year flood elevations throughout the site, if applicable. Jurisdictional wetland lines shall be surveyed, flagged and illustrated, if applicable. Topography plan may be included on the grading/drainage plan. 
7.  Vegetation map (for applications with property one (1) acre or larger). A map of existing vegetation species, caliper, and character, and including all threatened, endangered or species of special concern and all preservable trees six (6) inches D.B.H. or more in diameter. 
8.  Building elevations for all sides including structural heights, proposed building materials list, and color rendering(s). 
9.  Existing building uses, (if any) and intended use of each building or portion thereof. 
10.  Level of service data and analysis. Data illustrating that all adopted levels of service affecting the property are met or, if any service levels are not met, schedule of improvements which will be provided to ensure that all service levels are met; and a detailed analysis of parking requirements, including time of use and function, to support request. Data shall include, but not limited to, traffic, stormwater drainage, water, sewer and parks; and in a format acceptable to the community development director. Include water/sewer level of service analysis signed and sealed by an engineer. 
11.  Soils. A soils map and detailed soils report based on the findings of a professional soils expert supporting proposed construction activity. 
12.  Signs and lighting, (existing and proposed locations, elevations, and typical sections) if any. Provide height and overall square footage for each sign proposed; provide elevations, type, height, location and illumination data for lighting proposed. 
13.  Wildlife inventory. An inventory of wildlife species on site, including species categorized as endangered, threatened or of special concern status, if applicable. A description of techniques and practices proposed to protect endangered, threatened, or species of special concern status. 
14.  Incentives and/or development bonuses requested if applicable. 
15.  Off-site credits requested if applicable. 
16.  Mobility strategies if applicable for a transportation concurrency exception area (TCEA). 
    Should an item listed under the category of supplemental information in (e) above be determined by the community development director (or designee) as not applicable to a particular application, the item(s) may be waived without affecting the sufficiency of the application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-87. - Review time limitations. 
    If construction of the building(s), as determined by the building official's application of the Florida Building Code, has not begun within two (2) year(s) following approval of a site plan according to this procedure, or if the building permit for construction of the building(s) has become void any time after the two-year time period has expired, the approval of the site plan and use designated therein shall lapse. If approval of the site plan lapses under this section, resubmission of a site plan is required and is subject to all review and approval processes, regardless of any previous approvals acquired. The building official shall notify the property owner of the lapse of approval and inform the property owner that resubmission under the site plan or permitted conditional use review procedure(s) will be necessary. 
    Upon request of the applicant for whom the site plan or permitted conditional use was granted, the city council may waive the time limitation and grant a time extension for a maximum period of one (1) year (three hundred sixty-five (365) days), when the city council deems such action is necessary to prevent injustice or to facilitate the proper development of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1309, § 6, 6-27-16 ) 
Sec. 7.5-88. - Reconstruction. 
    A building or structure or land feature that is totally or substantially destroyed may be reconstructed only in compliance with a site plan approved through this process or through an amendment of an approved site plan or permitted conditional using procedures outlined within this article. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-89. - Scale of plans. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, all plans under this article are to be drawn with a uniform scale and at a scale of one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet or greater. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 

ARTICLE XI. - SUBDIVISION PROCESS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 24, 2011, amended former Art. XI, §§ 7.5-90-7.5-100, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. XI pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, April 22, 1991; Ord. No. 995, § 73, March 27, 2000. 
Cross reference- Subdivision of land generally, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 7.5-90. - Purpose and intent. 
    Land subdivision is the first step in community development. Once land has been subdivided into streets, lots and blocks and publicly recorded, the correction of defects is costly and difficult. Subdivided land sooner or later becomes a public responsibility, in that roads, drainage and utilities must be maintained and various customary municipal services must be provided. The welfare of the entire city is directly affected by land subdivision. It is to the interest of all taxpayers and citizens, the developer and future residents that subdivisions be conceived, designed and developed in accordance with sound practice and appropriate standards. 
    The intent and purpose of these regulations is to provide for the harmonious development of the city; to secure a coordinated layout and adequate provision for traffic; and to secure adequate provision for light, air, recreation, potable water, flood prevention drainage, sewers, and other sanitary facilities and city services. 
    In addition to the minimum requirements for construction of such improvements as roads and drainage, compliance with the intent of these regulations requires that good design be practiced in subdivision planning, valuable and scenic natural features conserved and adequate open space be made available for public use. Subdivision design should be adapted to the peculiarities and opportunities of the site should utilize contemporary, imaginative design and should avoid monotonous repetition of a wasteful pattern of gridiron layouts and long, straight minor or collector streets. Size, shape and orientation of lots and blocks should be carefully considered with relation to future use of the various lots to be created. 
    It is intended that this article shall be construed liberally in the favor of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-91. - Applicability. 
    The regulations established in this article shall apply to all lands presently within the limits of the city and to any lands which may in the future be annexed to and be made a part of the city. No land shall be subdivided unless such subdivision conforms to the provisions of this article and all other applicable regulations in the city. In order to subdivide land and file a plat thereon, except merely to record the boundaries of an ownership, all requirements as set out in this article shall be met and the procedures as herein set forth shall be followed. More specifically, anyone seeking the division of land into two (2) or more lots in the city shall be required to follow the procedures established by this article. The sale or exchange of small parcels of land to or between adjoining property owners where such sale or exchange does not create additional lots shall not be considered a subdivision of land required to adhere to these procedures. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-92. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges, expenses, and a collection process for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges, and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-93. - Subdivision application procedures. 
    Pre-application conference. Before submitting an application, an applicant for subdivision approval shall schedule a pre-application conference with the development review committee, to review the proposed development. The applicant shall obtain a copy of the pre-application form from the community development department. The city shall provide written comments to the applicant prior to the development review committee pre-application meeting. 
    The pre-application process serves as an opportunity to examine ideas and share information between the City of Maitland and an applicant for a potential subdivision in a conceptual application format. The comments and information provided by the city shall not be considered to constitute a waiver of any requirements contained in the City's Land Development Code but are meant to assist in the preparation of the application for formal submittal. A pre-application conference must be held no more than six (6) months prior to filing an application for planned development. 
    Following the pre-application conference, the applicant may submit an application for a subdivision plat as applicable in this article. The applicant shall submit the application and supplemental materials to the community development department in quantities designated by the city. 
    Applicants are encouraged to meet with neighborhoods and surrounding property owners/residents to discuss plans for the property that will be subject to the subdivision plat application, to be able to understand and respond to any valid concerns. 
    Applicants may apply for subdivision plat and planned development (PD) approval at the same time, in which case the city may undertake concurrent review of both applications. Applicants choosing the Option-1 PD process shall follow the preliminary and final subdivision processes described within section. 7.5-93, unless submitting a lot split or minor subdivision plat, in which case the applicant shall follow those processes accordingly. 
    Applicants selecting Option 2-PD, outlined in section 7.5-53 shall follow the process listed in section 7.5-95, Minor subdivision approval. 
    If the proposed subdivision is to be a large one and the developer plans to construct it in phases, the nature and extent of such phases shall be clearly delineated, and the developer must show the full extent of his development and submit, for the entire development, plans and data as required by this article. 
Preliminary Subdivision Plan 
(I)  Sufficiency review generally. All applications shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. Applications must be submitted at least forty (40) days prior to the first or third Thursday of any month in which the petitioner desires the application to be heard. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. 
(II)  Notice of planning and zoning commission hearing. After receipt of a complete petition, the city shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined in Florida Statutes, at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the planning and zoning commission public hearing date on which the petition is to be heard. Notice shall be posted on the property subject to the preliminary subdivision plat application and in two (2) public places, as well as the city web site. Notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property. The distance shall be measured by a straight line from the boundary of the property subject to the application to the nearest to the point of the boundary of any surrounding property. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addressed to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax roll in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  A statement that a preliminary subdivision plan has been requested; 
(b)  A legal description of the property prepared by a surveyor registered by the state under a surveyor's seal; and a general location map to correspond with the legal description of the property as noted on the hearing notice. This does not mandate publication of the location map in the newspaper noted above unless otherwise required by Florida Statutes. 
(c)  The name of the owner(s) of the property subject to the petition; 
(d)  A statement that a public hearing will be held by the planning and zoning commission; 
(e)  The date, time, and location of the hearing; 
(f)  Advice that the public is invited to attend the hearing and make comment orally or in writing; and 
(g)  The location and times during which an interested party may inspect the petition. 
(III)  Planning and zoning commission public hearing. The planning and zoning commission public hearing shall be held on the first or third Thursday of the month. Any party may appear in person, or by agent or by attorney to address the commission regarding the subdivision. 
    Following the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission has the option to: 
(a)  Provide an additional review of the application by the planning and zoning commission to finalize its review comments; or 
(b)  Forward its comments to the city council without further review by the planning and zoning commission. 
    In either case, before any recommendation is forwarded to city council, the planning and zoning commission shall make a written finding, certifying consistency with the comprehensive development plan, and finding that satisfactory provision and arrangement have been made concerning the factors itemized for development review committee review. 
    The written finding shall also certify compliance with the specific rules governing subdivision plats/plan as may be applicable to the application under review. 
(a)  If the planning and zoning commission chooses to review the application again; it shall declare at the public hearing that the application shall be returned following the development review committee's action on the application. After its review is complete, the planning and zoning commission shall forward a recommendation to the city council (including any conditions and findings) for approval, approval with modifications, or denial of the application. 
(b)  The planning and zoning commission may choose to provide a recommendation directly to the city council. In such cases, the planning and zoning commission shall forward instructions to the development review committee regarding the development of detailed conditions to include in the findings and recommendation being forwarded to the city council. The development review committee will then finalize the recommendation for consideration by the city council, unless the development review committee recommendation is contrary to that of the planning and zoning commission recommendation. In this case, the development review committee shall return the recommendation to the planning and zoning commission for finalization. 
(IV)  Review by development review committee. Following a public hearing by the planning and zoning commission, the development review committee shall review the petition and any public hearing testimony and/or any planning and zoning comments or directions and shall provide reasonable assistance to the applicant that the project complies with the Land Development Code and other applicable regulations and agreements. The applicant may continue to work with development review committee until such time that the development review committee determines the proposal is consistent with all applicable regulations and the item is ready to be placed on the next practical planning and zoning commission or city council agenda, if the streamline approach is taken pursuant to 7.5-93.(III). Should the applicant determine they no longer desire to work with development review committee to resolve the items, the applicant may choose to proceed to the next required planning and zoning commission or city council meeting, where staff shall advise of the applicant's decision to proceed without completing modifications required by development review committee. In all cases, the development review committee will generate and forward a written recommendation that will accompany the petition to the next step of the review process. The development review committee shall make a recommendation for approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the proposed petition. The development review committee shall formulate its recommendation and make findings with regard to the following factors: 
(a)  Whether the proposed subdivision is in compliance with the applicable ordinances and regulations for the property on which it is proposed; 
(b)  Whether the proposed subdivision will lower the applicable levels of service below the levels adopted in the city's comprehensive plan and whether the proposed development is phased to be constructed at a time when the adopted service levels are met; 
(c)  Whether existing or proposed utility services and transportation systems are adequate for the proposed development; whether all adopted levels of service have been or will be adequately met; and that any accompanying engineering plans have been approved by the city; and 
(d)  Whether the proposed subdivision plan is consistent with the comprehensive development plan. 
(V)  Recommendation by Planning and Zoning Commission. The planning and zoning commission shall receive and review the development review committee's findings and recommendation unless (iii)(b) has been chosen by the planning and zoning commission. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall recommend approval of the preliminary plan and other supplementary materials as presented, or shall recommend approval with modifications, or shall recommend denial of the preliminary plan and required improvements. 
    City council decision. At a regularly scheduled meeting, the city council shall receive and review the planning and zoning commission recommendation and shall accept, accept with modifications, or reject the preliminary subdivision plan. Failure to comply with the provisions of these regulations and other applicable statutes and ordinances shall be cause for refusing to approve the preliminary plan. 
    Action by the city council to approve or to approve with conditions, or to deny an application shall be deemed final. Any person aggrieved by action of the city council may seek recourse to the courts as provided by the laws of Florida. 
    Acceptance of the preliminary plan and other required supplementary material shall not be construed as acceptance of the final plat. Rather, it shall be deemed an expression of acceptance of the layout submitted and preliminary engineering and planning on the preliminary plan as a guide to the preparations of the final plat. 
    (VI) Time limit for submission of final subdivision plat. The final subdivision plat and supplementary material must be submitted within twelve (12) months after approval of the preliminary plat in accordance with the requirements of this article and all other applicable regulations. Otherwise, such approval shall become null and void unless an extension of time is applied for in writing and granted by the city council. The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved. 
Final Subdivision Plat 
(VII)  Sufficiency review for final subdivision plat. All applications for a final subdivision plat shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted for processing. 
(VIII)  Development review committee review and determination of conformity . After receipt of a complete petition, the Development Review Committee shall review the petition and shall make a determination of conformity and make findings regarding the following: 
(a)  Whether there is substantial conformity with the preliminary subdivision plan approval; 
(b)  Whether existing or proposed utility services and transportation systems are adequate for the proposed development; whether all adopted levels of service have been or will be adequately met; and that any accompanying engineering plans have been approved by the city; and 
(c)  Whether the proposed final subdivision plat is consistent with the comprehensive development plan. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1324, 9-25-17 ) 
Sec. 7.5-94. - Determination of substantial conformity for final plat and revisions to construction drawings. 
    A final plat will be considered in substantial conformity to the approved preliminary plan and construction drawings if it reflects the preliminary plan and modifications approved by the planning and zoning commission and city council. 
    Minor changes to an approved preliminary plan and/or construction drawings may be permitted after review and approval by the community development director or designee and may be considered in substantial conformity as well, provided the changes are consistent with the comprehensive plan and conform to all other applicable ordinances and regulations. Minor changes may include the following: 
(a)  Realignment of an internal roadway or curb cut to improve traffic flow, turn movements or other safety considerations. 
(b)  Relocate parking or retention areas within the site to increase percolation or reduce runoff from the site (over and above the approved site plan). 
(c)  Add or delete less than five (5) percent of the square footage of any lot for the project or add or delete less than five (5) percent of street frontage or lot width for any lot of the project. 
(d)  Decrease density, height, intensity or permeable surface coverage. 
(e)  Realignment of an approved wall or fence, to avoid existing trees or attempt to resolve a problem peculiar to the site. 
(f)  Relocate easements or utilities to provide more effective service levels. 
(g)  Amend sign package provided it does not increase in sign area by more than ten (10) percent. 
    The community development director may, at his sole discretion, pass any of the items (a) through (g) onto the development review committee for their consideration. 
    All changes not specifically listed in this section may be considered and approved by the development review committee as a minor change(s) if determined by the development review committee in a regularly scheduled meeting to be substantially consistent with the approved preliminary subdivision plan development order. Any decision rendered by the development review committee may be appealed to the city council within thirty (30) days of the date that the decision is rendered. 
    If the development review committee determines that the plat does not meet all requirements, the applicant may submit, within sixty (60) days, a revised final plat to address the concerns of the DRC and meet the requirements without an additional fee for review. Thereafter, re-submittals will require an additional final plat fee. Deadlines may be extended by the development review committee upon receipt of a written request prior to expiration of the sixty-day re-submittal time frame. 
    All changes determined to be major changes must be approved through procedures specified for a preliminary subdivision plan process. 
    If the plat complies with all requirements, it shall be presented to the city council within thirty (30) days of determination of compliance. 
(I)  City council acceptance of final plat. At a regularly scheduled meeting, the city council shall accept or reject the final subdivision plat. Failure to comply with the provisions of these regulations and other applicable statutes and ordinances shall be cause for refusing to accept the final plat. 
(II)  Time limit for recordation and improvements. For construction and installation of municipal improvements, and prior to recording of the final at by the city, the developer shall provide a surety bond to the city issued by a bonding company from the United States Treasury's list of approved bonding companies, or such other guarantee acceptable to the city, that all required work shall be completed in full accordance with the final plat, the approved construction plans and all conditions attached thereto. 
    Approval of the final plat, among other things, shall be contingent upon presentation of the bond or other guarantee acceptable to the city prior to recording of the plat. Construction and installation of municipal improvements shall not commence prior to receipt of this bond or other guarantee by the city. Such bond, referred to as the performance bond, shall be in the amount equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the sum of engineering and construction cost, including landfill, as determined by the construction contract proposal submitted by a properly licensed contractor and confirmed by the city director of public works. 
    All required work shall be completed and ready for acceptance by the city within a period of twenty-four (24) months from the date of acceptance of the final plat by city council at its meeting outlined in (I) above. One (1) twelve-month extension may be granted at the discretion of the city council. In order to obtain the extension, the developer shall request it in writing via a letter sent to the zoning administrator at least thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the plat approval. The performance bond or other guarantee shall remain in force and effect until such time as all required improvements have been accepted by the city. 
    Should the developer fail to provide the necessary bond within the required time period and the plat not be recorded, the plat approval shall be null and void. 
(III)  Required improvements. Approval of the final plat shall be subject to the subdivider having submitted to the city plans and specifications for all improvements required by the city, these plans and specifications being approved by the appropriate city officials prior to commencement of construction and receipt of an acceptable performance bond. A professional engineer registered by the state shall design the required improvements. After required improvements have been constructed, such engineer shall submit certification to the city that the improvements have been constructed according to the approved plans and specifications. 
    Upon completion of all work under bond, the developer shall submit to the city manager or designee a statement certified and sealed by a professional engineer registered in the state stating that the work has been entirely completed, and that it conforms in all respects to the final plat and plans for required improvements and to the specifications set by these regulations. 
    Upon receipt of this certificate of completion, the director of public works shall make a final inspection of each of the contract operations on the site. If the work conforms to all plans and specifications, the city manager shall so inform the city council in writing and recommend acceptance by the city. City council action accepting the improvements shall constitute authority for release of the developer's performance bond. In the event the developer has not completed the construction of all improvements within the authorized time limitations, the city's director of finance shall, when so directed by the city manager, notify the surety company or such other organization furnishing the bond or its equivalent of pending default. 
    Prior to release of the performance bond, the developer shall provide a surety bond issued by a bonding company from the United States Treasury list of approved bonding companies or such other guarantee acceptable to the city in an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the sum of the engineering and construction costs. Such bond, referred to as the maintenance bond, shall guarantee that all required improvements dedicated to the city have been properly constructed and are guaranteed for a period of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-95. - Minor subdivision approval. 
    Where property abuts an existing standard street and no new improvements for water, sewer or drainage are required and where the proposed subdivision contains four (4) or fewer commercial lots having common access to existing public roads or ten (10) or fewer residential lots, the community development director with the concurrence of the public works director, may waive the requirement for a preliminary subdivision plan approval and permit the applicant to proceed to a final subdivision plat approval. 
    If the preliminary subdivision plan approval is waived, the processing for the final subdivision plat approval shall be the same as the preliminary plan process, e.g., the planning and zoning commission shall hold a public hearing, with public hearing notice as outlined in the preliminary subdivision plan process, etc. 
    The applicant must submit any materials as part of the final subdivision plat as may be required by the zoning administrator in addition to the required material noted in this article to administer the process and clarify the application before the applicant may be considered sufficient and complete. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-96. - Lot splits. 
    Where property meets the requirements outlined above for a minor subdivision, the proposed subdivision is for two (2) lots and the property has never been subdivided prior to the application, the community development director, with the concurrence of the public works director, may waive the requirement for preliminary subdivision plan approval and final subdivision plat approval. The lot split would be required to be approved by the development review committee within twenty-one (21) days of a completed application as outlined in this article, using the same sufficiency review process time frames as required for the preliminary plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-97. - Modifications for large-scale developments. 
    The standards and requirements of these regulations may be modified by the planning and zoning commission in the case of a plan and a program for, a complete community, or a neighborhood unit, which in the judgment of the planning and zoning commission provided adequate public spaces and improvements for the circulation, recreation, light, air and service needs of the tract when fully developed and populated, which will provide such covenants or other legal provisions as will ensure conformity to and achievement of the city plan for development, and which will ensure that such development will not constitute an economic and tax burden on the city. 
    In granting modification, the planning and zoning commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standards and requirements as modified. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-98. - Issuance of building permits prior to final approval. 
    Prior to acceptance of the subdivision improvements as set forth in section 7.5-94(III), an action which constitutes authority for release of the developer's performance bond or other acceptable guarantee, the Building Official may recommend issuance of building permits for construction of buildings or structures or parts thereof within the subdivision provided: 
(a)  The city manager and community development director approve the recommendation; 
(b)  The city has received certification from the proper health authorities of the water and sewage systems to assure availability and approval for required connections thereto; and 
(c)  The director of public works and the fire chief are satisfied as to the accessibility by emergency vehicles of the subdivision site and individual lots for which any building permits are requested. 
    Issuance of building permits under this provision and prior to acceptance of the subdivision improvements by the city council does not express or by implication constitute, final approval of any work required under this article, nor does it constitute expressed or implied authority to release the developer's performance bond or other acceptable guarantee. 
    No building, structure or part thereof shall be occupied, nor shall any certificate of occupancy be issued for the same within the subdivision unless and until formal acceptance of all required improvements have been given by the city council, and the maintenance bond or other acceptable guarantee as provided for in this article has been received by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-99. - Selling, buying land in reference to unapproved plat prohibited. 
    Any person who, being the owner or agent of the owner of any land located within the city, thereafter transfers or sells such land, or any part thereof, by reference to a plat showing a subdivision of such land before such plat has been approved by the city council and recorded in the office of the clerk of the circuit court of Orange County, Florida, and any person to whom such transfer or sale is made, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished accordingly, and the metes and bounds description in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring shall not exempt the transaction from constituting an offense hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-100. - Application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the lot split and subdivision applications, in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials, must be supplied in quantities as specified by the community development director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(1)  Lot splits. 
(a)  Completed application form for lot splits. A completed application form for a lot split, with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and agent(s), request for the lot split, and appropriate signatures shall be submitted. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the Community Development Department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw the application must be submitted in writing to the Community Development Department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  Applicant authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(d)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Vicinity map drawn to a noted scale showing: 
a.  The location of the proposed lot split; 
b.  Relationships to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding areas (within five hundred (500) feet). 
2.  Plat map suitable for recording which shows or is accompanied by the following information: 
a.  Tract boundaries with appropriate dimensions; lot split to be referenced to nearest section corner. 
b.  Boundary survey and the legal description of the property prepared by a surveyor registered by the state under a surveyor's seal. The date of certification shall not be in excess of one (1) year. Provide gross and net land area which may be provided on a separate sheet. 
c.  Certification by the registered surveyor attesting to the accuracy of the survey and that the permanent reference monuments have been established according to law. 
d.  Location and description of all permanent reference monuments. 
e.  Drawn at a scale of at least one (1) inch = one hundred (100) feet. 
f.  North arrow, noted scale, graphic scale, date, and basis of bearing (desire true bearing). 
g.  The accurate outline of all property which is to be dedicated, reserved or proposed for public use, including stormwater drainage courses and easements, and all property that may be reserved by covenants in deeds for the common use of the property owners in the subdivision, with the purposes indicated thereon. 
h.  All existing water courses, stormwater drainage ditches and bodies of water, marshes, rock outcrop, buildings, transmission lines, sewers, bridges, culverts and drain pipes, water mains, county boundary lines, city limit lines and public utility easements. 
3.  Should the plat involve a planned development or other legal instrument that provides for the inclusion of private facility(ies) such as but not limited to bikeways and pedestrian ways, pedestrian lighting, street lighting, stormwater drainage areas, wall and fences, entry features, lift stations, infrastructure, (any of which may be located within areas designated as easements, tracts, or other areas designated as private) must clearly reflect the responsibilities for construction, maintenance and replacement, on the record plat. Easements such as conservation easements shall also clearly denote maintenance responsibilities on the record plat. 
(2)  Preliminary subdivision plan . 
(a)  Completed application form for preliminary subdivision plan . A completed application form for a preliminary subdivision plan with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and agent(s), and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the Community Development Department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the Community Development Department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  List of property owners. The names and mailing addresses of all property owners of real property within five hundred (500) feet of outer perimeter of subject property, taken from most recent tax rolls in Orange or Seminole Counties. The five-hundred-foot distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point of the boundary of the subject property nearest to the point of the boundary of any surrounding property. 
(d)  Applicant authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(e)  Engineer's name. The name of registered engineer(s), if applicable, responsible for the plan and supporting data. 
(f)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Vicinity map, drawn to a noted scale and showing: 
a.  The location of the proposed subdivision; 
b.  Relationships to surrounding streets; and 
c.  Existing zoning and land use on the site and surrounding areas (within five hundred (500) feet). 
2.  Plan showing the following information: (Information can be shown on one or more sheets with a uniform scale.) The plan shall include the following: 
a.  North arrow, noted scale, graphic scale, date, and basis of bearing (desire true bearing). 
b.  Key plan, showing location of tract in reference to other areas of the city. (Not necessarily to scale.) 
c.  Proposed subdivision name or identifying title, which shall not duplicate or closely approximate the name of any other subdivision in Orange County and name of recorded owner. 
d.  Boundary survey and the legal description of the property prepared by a surveyor registered by the State of Florida under a surveyor's seal. The date of certification shall not be in excess of one year. Provide gross and net land area which may be provided on a separate sheet. 
e.  All existing streets and alleys on or adjacent to the tract, including name and right-of-way width. 
f.  All existing property lines, buildings, transmission lines, sewers, bridges, culverts and drain pipes, water mains, county boundary lines, city limit lines and any public utility easements. Items to be demolished shall be noted. 
g.  Plat of adjacent subdivisions, if any, and recordation date and, typical lot size. Adjacent unplatted land shall be indicated by the words "not platted." 
h.  Location, name where applicable, and width of any proposed streets, alleys, rights-of-way, easements and purpose of easements; proposed lot lines with dimensions; lot numbers and block designations. Indicate traffic controls and any mass transit facilities to be provided and/or mobility enhancements or strategies proposed, if any. 
i.  The location of all property which is to be dedicated, reserved or proposed for public use, including stormwater drainage and easements, and all property that may be reserved by covenants in deeds for the common use of the property owners in the subdivision, and recreation areas (if applicable). 
j.  General location of potential public improvements, such as highways or other major improvements planned by public authorities for future construction on or near the tract, if applicable. 
k.  General conditions on tract including all existing water courses, stormwater drainage ditches, and bodies of water, wetlands isolated preservable trees one (1) foot or more in diameter and other significant features. 
l.  Indicate whether development will be a gated community. 
m.  Building envelopes shall be illustrated on the proposed lots. 
n.  Indicate proposed gross and net density for residential development (if applicable). 
3.  Grading concept plan/utility service plan, to include: 
a.  General location, size and description of stormwater drainage facilities including retaining walls and elevation or grade changes in excess of two feet, sewage collection and water distribution systems including location of any proposed or existing fire hydrants; 
b.  Statements concerning stormwater distribution, method of water supply and waste disposal, all conforming to city specification; 
c.  All other existing service location lines if available on or adjacent to site tract; and 
d.  The topographic information must delineate the mean high water elevations for each water body and the one-hundred-year flood elevations throughout the site, if applicable. Jurisdictional wetland lines shall be illustrated. 
4.  Fire service: 
a.  General location and provision of Fire Service Facilities such as hydrant locations and water main sizes; 
b.  Turning radii for fire engines shall be 20 feet inside and 40 feet outside; turning radii for ladder or aerial trucks shall be 25 feet inside and 50 feet outside in accordance with manufacturer's specifications; 
c.  Roadways shall be designed to support the imposed loads of fire apparatus and shall be provided with an all weather driving surface; and 
d.  Dead-end fire department access roads in excess of 150 feet in length shall be provided with approved provisions for the fire apparatus to turn around. 
5.  Tree survey (for applications with property one (1) acre or larger) drawn at the same scale as the preliminary subdivision plan. A map of existing trees indicating, caliper and character, and including all threatened, endangered or species of special concern and all preservable trees six (6) inches or more in diameter. 
6.  Schematic landscape plan indicating: 
a.  Proposed street tree locations and additional landscaping to be provided (if applicable); 
b.  Reference general plant list; and 
c.  Existing vegetation to be preserved. 
7.  Legal instruments. Drafts of protective covenants, whereby the developer proposes to regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed development. 
8.  Level of service data and analysis. Data addressing adopted levels of service, and an analysis of parking requirements, including time of use, to support request. Data shall include, but not limited to, preliminary assessment of traffic impact and trip generation study, stormwater drainage, water, sewer and parks; and in a format acceptable to the community development director. 
9.  Soils. Soils classification map demonstrating soils on site. Soil analysis or geotechnical report by a professional soils expert shall be furnished upon request at or immediately after the pre-application meeting. 
10.  Wildlife inventory. An inventory of wildlife species on site, including species categorized as endangered, threatened or of special concern status. A description of techniques and practices proposed to protect endangered, threatened, or species of special concern status. 
Should an item listed under the category of supplemental information above be determined by the community development director (or designee) as not applicable to a particular application, the item(s) may be waived upon request of the applicant and authorization by the city, without affecting the sufficiency of the application. 
(3)  Final subdivision plat. 
(a)  Completed application form for final subdivision plat. A completed application form for final subdivision plat, with the name, address and telephone number of applicant(s), property owner(s), and agent(s), statement indicating request, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the community development department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  Applicant authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(d)  Engineer's name. The name of registered engineer(s), if applicable, responsible for the plat and supporting data. 
(e)  Plat suitable for recordation. The plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn in a format as required for filing for record in Orange County, in accordance with the design standards and provisions of Chapter 177, Florida Statutes. 
(f)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Plat plan requirements. Where necessary, the plat may be on several sheets accompanied by an index sheet showing the entire subdivision. For large subdivisions, the final plat may be submitted for approval or acceptance progressively in contiguous sections satisfactory to the planning and zoning commission. The plat shall also include the following: 
a.  North arrow, graphic scale, date, and basis of bearing, (desire true bearing). 
b.  Subdivision name or identifying title and name of recorded owner. 
c.  Boundary survey and the legal description of the property prepared by a surveyor registered in the State of Florida under a surveyor's seal. The date of certification shall not be in excess of one year. Provide gross and net land area which may be provided on a separate sheet. 
d.  Subdivision to be referenced to nearest section corner. (Coordinate with city Mapping/GIS Coordinator.) 
e.  Location and description of all permanent reference monuments and statement attesting that the permanent reference monuments have been established according to law and these regulations. 
f.  Primary control points, approved by the city public works director, or descriptions and "ties" to such control points, to which all dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data on the plat shall be referred. 
g.  Property lines of residential lots and other sites, with accurate dimensions, bearing or deflection angles, and radii, acres and central angles to all curves. Distances to be accurate to hundredths of a foot and angles to the nearest second. 
h.  The exact layout including street and alley lines and rights-of-way; street names, bearings and widths (including width along the liens of any obliquely intersecting street); lengths of arcs and radii, points of curvature and chord and length bearings; points of tangency or nontangency intersects; all easements owned by or rights-of-way provided for public utilities; all lot lines with dimensions in feet and hundredths, and with bearings of angles if other than right angles to the street and alley lines. All street names shall conform to the city's system. 
i.  The exact name, locations and width along property liens of all existing or recorded streets intersecting or paralleling the boundaries of the tract. 
j.  Lots to be numbered in consecutive numerical order and blocks to be lettered in alphabetical order. 
k.  The accurate outline of all property which is to be dedicated, reserved or proposed for public use, including stormwater drainage courses and easements, and all property that may be reserved by covenants in deeds for the common use of the property owners in the subdivision, with the purposes indicated thereon. The mean high water elevations for each water body and the one-hundred-year flood elevations, if applicable. Jurisdictional wetland lines shall be illustrated (if applicable.) 
l.  References to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land by record number, name and date and adjacent portions of which may be shown in outline form. Adjacent, unplatted land shall be indicated by the words "not platted." 
m.  Space and form for the following necessary acceptances or approvals: (1) chairman of the planning and zoning commission; (2) mayor of the city; and (3) Orange County Comptroller's Office. 
n.  Unreserved dedication (on the plat) which authorizes the city to have the right of entry perpetuity to reconstruct, repair, inspect and maintain all facilities on or in a dedicated right-of-way which may have been constructed or installed for the public good and welfare, and which may be included any or all of the following: streets, alleys, gutters, curbs, sidewalks, street signs and posts, parks and parkways; water lines, sanitary sewers, stormwater drainage ponds and associated line pipes and other stormwater elements, storm sewers and their accoutrements; utility lines to include as a minimum power, telephone, telegraph and television cable service; street lights and poles; power and transformer stations, sewage lift stations; all other facilities that shall be construed as to be for the public good and welfare. Such dedication shall be subscribed to by the legal and equitable owners of such lands, which dedications shall be checked for accuracy of description by the director of public works and attested by a notary public. 
o.  Dedications providing to the city the right to clear trees, brush or any other impediment to reconstruction, maintenance, inspection or repair of the above-listed facilities and providing prohibition against all others from planting, constructing or placing any object on the dedicated right-of-way without the explicit written permission of the director of public works of the city. 
2.  Construction details, including cross-sections and profiles of streets and any necessary stormwater drainage facilities. The profiles shall be drawn to city standard scales and elevations shall be based on a United States Coast and Geodetic Survey datum plane. Likewise, locations and elevations of all walls, fences and entrance features proposed for the subdivision to be maintained by the property owners. Typical sections showing street type and width, driveway entrances, curb and gutter, sidewalk location and width, stormwater drainage and, utility service line sizes and connection details. 
Illustrate proposed one-foot contour lines or point elevations and extending twenty-five (25) feet beyond the property boundary. Existing contour lines screened as background. Jurisdictional wetland lines shall be surveyed, flagged and illustrated (if applicable). 
Include locations, elevations, height typical sections and overall square footage for each sign proposed; provide elevations, type, height, location, typical sections and illumination data for lighting proposed. 
3.  Subsurface conditions on the tract; location and results of tests made to ascertain subsurface soil, rock and groundwater conditions; depth to groundwater unless test pits are dry at a depth of three (3) feet; location and results of soil percolation test if individual sewage systems are proposed. 
4.  Landscape plan shall be drawn at a noted scale and signed and sealed by a Landscape Architect. The landscape plan shall at a minimum clearly identify the following: 
a.  Proposed street tree locations and additional landscaping to be provided (if applicable) reference species type, dimensions at planting; 
b.  Existing vegetation to be preserved (reference species type and dimensions; 
c.  Relocation and/or preservation, if applicable. 
5.  Protective covenants, if any, in form of recording (all covenants are nondiscriminatory in regard to race, color or creed). 
6.  Tax/lien information. Provide evidence supporting that all taxes and improvement liens against the subject plats have been paid or discharged. 
7.  Level of service data and analysis. Data illustrating that all adopted levels of service, affecting the property are met, or, if any service levels are not met, schedule of improvements which will be provided to ensure that all service levels are met. 
8.  Analysis of the city's ability to provide adequate public services to the land proposed to be subdivided (e.g., police, fire, garbage, etc.). 
9.  Should the plat involve a planned development or other legal instrument that provides for the inclusion of private facility(ies) such as but not limited to bikeways and pedestrian ways, pedestrian lighting, streetlighting, stormwater drainage areas, wall and fences, entry features, lift stations, infrastructure, any of which may be located within areas designated as easements, tracts, or other areas designated as private, must clearly reflect the responsibilities for construction, maintenance and replacement, on the record plat. Easements such as conservation easements shall also clearly denote maintenance responsibilities on the record plat. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Secs. 7.5-101-7.5-109. - Reserved. 

ARTICLE XII. - VARIANCES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted October 24, 2011, amended former Art. XII, §§ 7.5-110-7.5-115 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. XII pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, adopted April 22, 1991. 
Cross reference- Board of zoning adjustment, § 4.7-2 et seq. 

Sec. 7.5-110. - Purpose and intent. 
    The procedures established in this article are intended to provide for adequate review of the terms of the zoning code to ensure that the terms of the zoning code will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of its provisions would result in unnecessary hardship. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-111. - Applicability. 
    The procedures contained in this article are applicable to all requests for waiver of one (1) or more provisions of the zoning code by any person or agency which owns the real property subject to the provisions of the code from which a waiver is requested. 
    Under no circumstances shall the board of zoning adjustment grant a variance to allow a use not permissible under the terms of this zoning code in the district involved, or any use expressly or by implication prohibited by the terms of this zoning code in such district. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-112. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges and expenses for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. The fees for a variance are not intended to prohibit legitimate applications. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-113. - Application procedures. 
(I)  Sufficiency review. All applications for a variance under this article shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. Applications must be submitted at least forty (40) days prior to the fourth Thursday of any month. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. Should the applicant fail to submit all information as required within five (5) working days, the application will not be considered complete and will not be processed. If complete, the zoning administrator shall transmit to the board all application materials and any records deemed by the zoning administrator to be pertinent to the request. 
(II)  Notice of board of zoning adjustment hearing. After receipt of a complete petition, the city shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined in Florida Statutes, at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the board of zoning adjustment public hearing date on which the petition is to be heard. A notice shall be posted on the property subject to the variance request and in two (2) public places, as well as the city web site and notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to all property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property, all at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the board of zoning adjustment public hearing. The distance for mailing notices shall be measured by a straight line from the point on the boundary of the property subject to the appeal nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addressed to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax roll in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  The name of the appellant; 
(b)  The location of the property, if applicable; and a general location map to correspond with the legal description of the property as noted on the hearing notice. This does not mandate publication of the location map in the newspaper noted above unless otherwise required by Florida Statutes. 
(c)  The action requested; and 
(d)  The date, time and location of the public hearing. 
(III)  Board of zoning adjustment public hearing. The board of zoning adjustment public hearing shall be held on the fourth Thursday of the month for which the completed application was received or, if the fourth Thursday is a holiday on which the board cannot meet or if a quorum is not achieved, within sixty (60) days of receipt of an application. Any party may appear in person, or by agent, or by attorney. The board of zoning adjustment may grant or deny the application for a variance. Before the board may grant a petition for a variance, the board must conclude that all of the following requirements have been met for the application: 
(a)  That special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the land, structure, or building involved and which are not applicable to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; 
(b)  That literal interpretation of the provisions of this zoning code would deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties in the same district under the terms of this zoning code; 
(c)  That the special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of the applicant; and 
(d)  That granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this zoning code to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district. No nonconforming use of neighboring lands, structures, or buildings in the same district, and no permitted use of lands, structures, or buildings in other district shall be considered grounds for the issuance of a variance. 
    The board of zoning adjustment shall further make a finding that the reasons set forth in the application justify the granting of the variance that will make possible the reasonable use of the land, building or structure. 
    The board of zoning adjustment shall further make a finding that the granting of the variance: 
(a)  Will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this zoning code; 
(b)  Is consistent with the comprehensive development plan; and 
(c)  Will not be injurious to the neighborhood, or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. 
    In granting any variance, the board of zoning adjustment may prescribe appropriate specific written conditions and safeguards in conformity with the zoning code. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-114. - Time limit on approval and denial. 
    A variance is valid for a period of two (2) years (seven hundred thirty (730) days) from the date of granting to the time a building permit is obtained. Any further consideration for a variance on the same property shall require the filing of a new petition when such time limitation is exceeded. Violation of such conditions and safeguards, when made a part of the terms under which the variance is granted, shall be deemed a violation of the zoning code. Should a variance application be denied, the city shall not consider an application for variance on the same property for a period of one (1) year (three hundred sixty-five (365) days) from the date of the denial. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-115. - Application requirements. 
    To be considered sufficient and complete, the variance application in conjunction with properly identified exhibits and supporting materials must be supplied in quantities as specified by the community development director on the application and shall clearly indicate the following: 
(a)  Completed application form for variance. A completed application form for variance, with the name, address and telephone number of applicant, property owner, and agent, request for variance, and appropriate signatures. If ownership of any part of or all of the real property subject to the petition shall change during the pendency of the petition, the petitioning owner who has conveyed such parcel of real property shall be required to immediately advise the community development department in writing. Any desire to amend or withdraw application must be submitted in writing to the community development department. 
(b)  Fees. The payment of all appropriate processing fees and charges, as set from time to time. 
(c)  List of property owners. The names and mailing addresses of all property owners of real property within five hundred (500) feet of outer perimeter of subject property, taken from most recent tax rolls in Orange or Seminole Counties. The five-hundred-foot distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point of the boundary of the subject property nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. 
(d)  Applicant authorization. If the applicant or agent is other than the property owner, the applicant shall provide a notarized letter of authorization from the property owner. 
(e)  Supplemental information. 
1.  Vicinity map showing location of site in relation to surrounding streets. 
2.  Site plan drawn to a noted scale and to include: 
a.  The legal description of the property; 
b.  Street address (if applicable); 
c.  North arrow and noted scale; 
d.  Required yard and set back information; 
e.  Existing and proposed building(s) located on site and indicate structural height, and, square footage; (indicate floor area); and 
f.  Plan dimensions adequately shown. 
3.  Written informational statements. 
a.  Information that special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the land, structure or building involved, and which are not applicable to other lands, structures or buildings in the same district. 
b.  Information that literal interpretation of the provisions of the zoning code would deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties in the same district under the terms of the zoning code. 
c.  Information that the special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of the applicant. 
d.  Information that granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by the zoning code to other lands, structures or buildings in the same district. No nonconforming use of neighboring lands, structures or buildings in the same district, and no permitted use of lands, structures or buildings in other districts shall be considered grounds for the issuance of a variance. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Secs. 7.5-116-7.5-119. - Reserved. 

ARTICLE XIII. - VESTED RIGHTS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), adopted October 24, 2011, amended former Art. XIII, §§ 7.5-120-7.5-124, in its entirety which pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 771, § 2, April 22, 1991. 

Sec. 7.5-120. - Purpose and intent. 
    Upon application and after review as provided herein, the city council may grant, as a special permit, an exception to the otherwise applicable provisions of the most currently effective city comprehensive development plan or any land development regulation in the City Code. The special permit shall be a development order for a specific type, level, nature, density, intensity or other form of development of a specifically described parcel of land. The special permit is not transferable, in whole or in part, to any other parcel of land or to any other person, corporation or other legal entity. The special permit may be granted whenever the city council finds that the applicant has demonstrated, pursuant to the standards set forth in this article that the applicant has a preexisting vested right to commence and complete a specific level, type, nature, density, intensity, or other form of development. The special permit may be granted with or without conditions as the evidence shall indicate to the city council may be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-121. - Applicability. 
    Any person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity, having an ownership interest in a parcel of land, may file an application for a special permit determining the applicant's right to commence and complete a specific type, level, nature, intensity, density or other form of development on that parcel of land has vested. 
    Any person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity, claiming a vested right to commence and complete any type, level, nature, intensity, or other form of development of a specific parcel of land, who does not file an application for determination under this section within two (2) years of the effective date of the amendatory ordinance that rezones [or] changes the land use of the property, or otherwise materially and adversely affects the applicant's parcel of land (or portion thereof) so as to prohibit the nature, type, level, intensity, density or other form of development, in whole or in part, shall be deemed to have waived the right to seek such a determination. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-122. - Schedule of fees. 
    The city council shall establish, by resolution, a schedule of fees, charges, expenses and a collection process for administering this article. Until all applicable fees, charges and expenses have been paid, no action shall be taken on any application. 
(Ord. No. 1219, § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 7.5-123. - Application procedure. 
(I)  Sufficiency review. Applications for vested rights shall be submitted to the zoning administrator or designee. Applications must be submitted at least forty (40) days prior to the first or third Thursday of any month in which the petitioner desires the application to be heard. The zoning administrator will review the application for sufficiency and completeness of information within five (5) working days after submission. If corrections are requested, the applicant shall have five (5) working days to make all requested changes. Incomplete applications will not be accepted. Should the applicant fail to submit all information as required within five (5) working days, the application will not be considered complete and will not be processed. 
(II)  Notice of planning and zoning commission hearing. After receipt of a complete petition, the city shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation, as defined in Florida Statutes, at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the planning and zoning commission public hearing date on which the petition is to be heard. Notice shall be posted on the property subject to the vested rights application and in two public places, as well as the city web site. Notice shall be sent by first class regular United States mail to property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the subject property. The distance shall be measured by a straight line from the point on the boundary of the property subject to the vested rights application nearest to the point of the boundary of any property within five hundred (500) feet thereof. Notice shall be deemed to have been delivered when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid thereon, and addressed to the property owner whose name is shown on the most current tax roll in Orange County or Seminole County. 
    All notices referenced in the above paragraph shall include: 
(a)  A statement that an application for vested rights has been received; 
(b)  The legal description of the property subject to the petition; and a general location map to correspond with the legal description of the property as noted on the hearing notice, if applicable.
