Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages generally, Ch. 3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Adoption of state misdemeanors. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person to commit, within the corporate limits of the city, any act which is recognized by laws of the state as a misdemeanor, and the commission of such acts is hereby forbidden. Whoever shall violate the provisions of this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by the same penalty as provided by state law but not to exceed the maximum penalty provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1971, § 12-1) 
Annotation- Municipalities may make commission of state misdemeanors ordinance violations, MacFarland v. Roberts, 74 So.2d 88 (1954); Jaramillo v. City of Homestead, 322 So.2d 496 (1975); adoption includes future enactments, State v. Smith, 189 So.2d 846 (4th DCA 1966). 
Sec. 10-2. - Bicycles; mutilating serial numbers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to mutilate any serial number on a bicycle placed thereon by the manufacturer. 
(Code 1971, § 41/4-10) 
Secs. 10-3, 10-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of §§ 10-3 and 10-4, disturbing lawful assemblies and disturbing the peace, were deleted, at the direction of the city, as being adequately covered by F.S. §§ 871.01 et seq., 856.011, and 877.03. The readers attention is directed to § 10-1 of this Code. The deleted provisions derived from Code 1971, §§ 12-2 and 12-3. 
Sec. 10-5. - Nudity, sexual conduct prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall expose to public view any of the following specified anatomical areas in an establishment serving food or beverages or dealing in alcoholic beverages: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
a.  Human genitals or pubic region; or 
b.  Any part of the human buttocks; or 
c.  Human anus; or 
d.  The areola (colored ring around the nipple) of the human female breast. That portion of the human female breast encompassed within an area falling below the horizontal line one would have to draw to intersect a point immediately above the top of the areola. This definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, providing the areola is not so exposed. 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly erect or turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to expose, exhibit, display or reveal any of the above specified anatomical areas while performing any dance, performance, exhibit or any other type of entertainment in an establishment serving food or beverages or dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager, or other employer of an establishment serving food or beverages or dealing in alcoholic beverages to any person to expose, exhibit, display or reveal any of the above specified anatomical areas while performing any dance, performance, exhibit or any other type of entertainment in an establishment serving food or beverages or dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  No person shall engage in and no person maintaining, owning, or operating an establishment serving food or beverages or dealing in alcoholic beverages shall suffer or permit any specified sexual activity. Specified sexual activity shall mean: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; or 
(2)  Display of the human anus for other than excretory functions; or 
(3)  Acts of human anilingus, bestiality, buggery, cunnilingus, coprophagy, coprophilia, fellatio, flagellation, masochism, masturbation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, sadism, sadomasochism, sapphism, sexual intercourse, sodomy, urolagnia or zooerasty; or 
(4)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus or female breast; or 
(5)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities as set forth in subsections (1) through (4). 
(e)  Reserved. 
(f)  No person shall cause and no person maintaining, owning and operating an establishment serving food or beverages or dealing in alcoholic beverages shall suffer or permit the exposition of any graphic representation, including pictures or the projection of film, which depicts less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region, cleavage of the human buttocks, human anus, or the areola of the human female breast, human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered; human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; acts of human anilingus, bestiality, buggery, cunnilingus, coprophagy, coprophilia, fellatio, flagellation, masochism, masturbation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, sadism, sadomasochism, sapphism, sexual intercourse, sodomy, urolagnia or zooerasty; fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus or female breast; excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities as set forth in subsections (1) through (4). 
(g)  Enforcement. The police chief or his designee has administration and enforcement responsibilities under the Orange County Adult Entertainment Ordinance and this chapter. Further, the provisions of this code may be enforced by: 
(1)  A suit brought by the city council in the circuit court to restrain, enjoin, or prevent a violation of this code; or 
(2)  Enforcement proceedings by the special magistrate; or 
(3)  Criminal prosecution as provided in the Florida Statutes. 
(Code 1971, § 12-4; Ord. No. 812, § 2, 7-26-93; Res. No. 5-2008, 5-12-08) 
Sec. 10-6. - Recreational lighting; hours of operation, intensity in residential areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain recreational lighting in a residential area in the city after 10:00 p.m. if such lighting exceeds five (5) footcandles up to a height of fifteen (15) feet, measured at the property line. 
(b)  In order to enforce this section, a resident of the city must file a complaint with the police department specifying the location and the circumstances of the violation. 
(c)  The police department shall investigate the alleged violation. 
(d)  If any person appears to be in violation of this section, the police shall notify said person of the violation and allow said person fifteen (15) days to remedy and correct the violation prior to issuing a citation. 
(e)  Any person accused of violating this section shall have the right to a hearing in order to determine whether or not there is probable cause to believe he has violated this section, prior to the issuance of a citation. 
(Code 1971, § 12-17) 
Cross reference- Zoning regulations, Ch. 21. 
Sec. 10-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of § 10-7, indecent or lewd conduct, deriving from Code 1971, § 12-7, were deleted at the direction of the city as being adequately covered by various sections of F.S. Ch. 847. The reader's attention is directed to § 10-1 of this Code. 
Sec. 10-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of § 10-8, accepting security or purchasing from minors, were deleted at the direction of the city as being adequately covered by F.S. 538.07 and 538.15(1)(b). Former § 10-8 derived from Code 1971, § 12-13. The reader's attention is directed to § 10-1 of this Code. 
Sec. 10-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of former § 10-9, offenses against minors, deleted at the direction of the city, had derived from Code 1971, § 12-12. 
Sec. 10-10. - Noise generally. 
    The creation of any unreasonably loud and disturbing noises in the City is prohibited, and it shall be unlawful for any person to cause, make or contribute to creating any loud or disturbing noise, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday, however the time will be extended one hour (to midnight) on Friday and Saturday nights, with the exception of train horns and whistles which will be prohibited twenty-four (24) hours per day, every day, or noises of such character, intensity and duration as to be determined to the life or health of any individual, or such noise as will unduly disturb the quiet and peace of the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 12-14; Ord. No. 995, § 85, 3-27-00; Ord. No. 1176, § 1, 2-23-09; Ord. No. 1178, § 1, 5-11-09) 
Cross references- Animals creating disturbances or nuisances, § 4-24; noise levels from film production regulated, § 5.7-15(11). 
Sec. 10-11. - Noise; specific acts prohibited. 
    The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud and disturbing noises in violation of section 10-10, but said enumerations shall not be deemed to be exclusive, namely: 
(a)  Radios, phonographs, etc. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is reasonable for convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday, however the time will be extended one hour (to midnight) on Friday and Saturday nights; in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section; provided, however, that string music, mechanical, phonograph or radio music may be provided by a vendor of alcoholic beverages, duly licensed therefor, during the hours such beverages may be lawfully dispensed, provided that it shall be unlawful for the sound of said music, mechanical, phonograph or radio, or entertainment, at any time during the hours of operation, to be audible a distance of more than fifty (50) feet from the exterior wall of the premises operated by said licensed vendor; and it shall be the responsibility of said vendor or operator to ensure that the premises operated by him comply with this provision. 
Cross reference- Hours for dispensing alcoholic beverages, §§ 3-2, 21-5(XIII). 
(b)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public for advertising or other purposes except where specific permission is received from the city manager. 
(c)  Construction or repairing of buildings. The erection (including excavating), demolition, alteration or repair of any building, when such activity requires a building permit in the city, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on weekdays, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety, or in cases where public improvements by a public entity are required for the health and safety of the community or the construction is required by special circumstances to achieve a public purpose, and then only with a permit from the building official, which permit may be granted for a period deemed appropriate by the building official for the accomplishment of the required improvements. If the building official should determine that the public health and safety will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, alteration or repair of any building or the excavation of streets and highways on weekends, or within the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays, and if he shall further determine that loss or inconvenience would result to any party in interest, he may grant permission for such work to be done during weekends, or within the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays, upon application being made at the time the permit for the work is awarded or during the progress of the work. 
(d)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same is in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital, provided conspicuous signs are displayed on such street indicating that the same is a school, church, hospital or court street. 
(e)  Hawkers, peddlers. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(f)  Drums. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale, provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed as a prohibition against the use and operation of drums as musical instruments. 
(g)  sounding of railroad train horns, exception. 
(1)  The sounding of railroad train horns and whistles ay all public railroad-highway grade crossings within the city is hereby prohibited; except that a locomotive engineer may sound the locomotive horn to provide a warning to animals, vehicle operators, pedestrians, trespassers, or crews on other trains in an emergency situation if, in the locomotive engineer's sole judgment such action is appropriate in order to prevent imminent injury, death, or property damage. Locomotive horns may be sounded when active grade crossing warning devices have malfunctioned or when grade crossing warning systems are temporarily out of service during inspection, maintenance, or testing the system. 
(2)  Signs to be posted. The city shall erect signs at all railroad-highway grade crossings within the city advising that railroad train horns and whistles shall not be sounded. The signs so erected shall be in conformance with the uniform system of traffic control devices as specified in F.S. section 316.0745. 
(3)  Traffic operations systems; implementation. The city shall implement a traffic system to secure the railroad-highway grade crossing within the city for the purpose of preventing vehicles from going around, under, or through lowered railroad gates. 
(4)  Compliance with state and federal regulations. The traffic operations system implemented by the city shall comply with and meet all state and federal safety traffic regulations and shall demonstrate that such railroad-highway grade crossings can be secured. The city shall obtain the final approval and verification by the Florida Department of Transportation and the Federal Railroad Administration that the city's traffic operations system meets all state and federal safety and traffic regulations for installation of a quiet zone. 
(Code 1971, § 12-15; Ord. No. 919, § 1, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 995, § 86, 3-27-00; Ord. No. 1176, § 1, 2-23-80) 
Sec. 10-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 10-12, Trespass, which derived from Code 1971, §§ 12-11, was deleted at the direction of the city, being adequately covered by F.S. §§ 810.08, 810.09. The reader's attention is directed to § 10-1 of this Code. 
Sec. 10-13. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 10-13, relative to vandalisism and deriving from Code 1971, § 12-16, was deleted, at the direction of the city, as being adequately covered by F.S. § 806.13. 
Sec. 10-14. - Discharging air powered weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any BB gun or other air or gas powered gun inside the corporate limits of the city without a special permit. 
(Code 1971, § 12-5; Ord. No. 1218, § 2, 9-26-11) 
State Law reference- Use of BB guns, etc., by children, F.S. § 790.22. 
Secs. 10-15-10-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STATES OF EMERGENCY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-25. - To be governed by statute when arising from violence. 
    A state of emergency arising from overt violence, or the imminent threat of such violence, may be declared in accordance with and shall be governed by Florida Statutes, Sections 870.041 through 870.048. Pursuant to and in accordance with Florida Statutes, Section 870.042, the mayor is hereby designated as the authority empowered to declare that such a state of emergency exists and to exercise the powers provided by said statutes. 
(Ord. No. 995, § 87, 3-27-00) 
Secs. 10-26-10-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STATES OF EMERGENCY DUE TO CALAMITY 

Sec. 10-36. - What constitutes. 
    A state of emergency due to calamity is hereby defined to consist of the actual existence or clear and present danger of any natural disaster or man-made calamity including but not limited to flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion, within or seriously affecting the city, and resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property. 
(Code 1971, § 2-22) 
Sec. 10-37. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Alcoholic beverage is defined as provided by Florida Statutes, Section 561.01(4). 
    Weapon is hereby defined to be: 
(1)  Any bludgeon, blackjack, slingshot, metal knuckles, switchblade knife; or 
(2)  Any tear gas bomb or other object containing a noxious gas or substance, when carried on or about the person or located in any vehicle; or 
(3)  Any other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument of like character, used or carried in such circumstances as to evidence an intent to use the same unlawfully against another. 
(Code 1971, § 2-22; Ord. No. 1218, § 3, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 10-38. - Proclamation by mayor. 
    When a state of emergency due to calamity is deemed to exist in the reasonable judgment of the mayor, or is deemed by the city council to have terminated, the mayor shall forthwith proclaim in writing the existence or termination of the same, and file a copy thereof with both the chief of police and the city clerk. The mayor shall also give prompt notice thereof to all newspapers, radio, television or other news media as he shall reasonably deem advisable. 
(Code 1971, § 2-23) 
Sec. 10-39. - Duration and termination. 
    Because of the imperative necessity for quick and official response, the state of emergency due to calamity shall commence immediately upon the mayor's proclamation and filing of copies and giving of prompt notice thereof, all as set forth in section 10-38, and shall terminate only upon similar and subsequent mayoral proclamation when made pursuant to an appropriate resolution by the city council, but in no event shall a state of emergency due to calamity, commenced at the sole instance of the mayor, extend for more than ten (10) days from its inception. If a state of emergency due to calamity continues to exist at the end of the ten (10) day period, the city council shall, by resolution, authorize the mayor to issue another state of emergency proclamation, as provided in section 10-38, subject to the right of the city council to terminate or extend such state of emergency, as it may advise. The findings of the city council on all matters pertaining to this section shall be conclusive. 
(Code 1971, § 2-24) 
Sec. 10-40. - Emergency measures. 
    Whenever the mayor or the city council proclaims or finds that a state of emergency due to calamity exists, the mayor may then, or subsequently by further proclamation, order and promulgate all or any of the emergency measures provided in this section, in whole or in part, with such limitations and conditions as he may deem appropriate, to be applicable to the whole or to any geographical area or areas of the city, and at such times as he reasonably believes advisable. Such measures shall be effective only during the period of such state of emergency, and they shall be set forth by the proclamation in substantially the same manner as the following subsections: 
(a)  Dispensing of alcoholic beverages. Until further notice from this office, all establishments licensed to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on or off premises are prohibited from selling or otherwise dispensing such alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  Possession of alcoholic beverages. Until further notice from this office, the knowing possession by any person in a public place of any container containing an alcoholic beverage is prohibited. 
(c)  Sale or transfer of flammable or explosive substances. Until further notice from this office, all persons are prohibited from knowingly purchasing, transferring, giving, distributing or exchanging any flammable or explosive substance such as but not limited to gasoline, kerosene, lighter fluid, charcoal lighter, wood alcohol, fuel oil, phosphorous, magnesium, black powder, grenade, molotov cocktail, or dynamite; except that filling stations may pour fuels into a tank properly affixed to an operable motor-driven vehicle, bike, scooter, cycle, boat or airplane, when necessary for the propulsion thereof; and except that heating substances may be delivered to residences, stores, offices and other buildings, when poured into tanks properly affixed or connected to operable heating units. 
(d)  Possession of flammable or explosive substances. Until further notice from this office the knowing possession in a public place of any container containing any flammable or explosive substances such as those enumerated in subsection (f) of this section is prohibited. 
(e)  Establishment of curfew. Until further notice from this office, all persons in the city (or in certain geographical areas thereof designated by the mayor) are prohibited from being abroad in vehicles or on foot between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except for persons actually engaged in the performance of governmental or emergency duties, doctors of medicine or dentistry and hospital personnel proceeding to or from their places of work and their patients, public service employees proceeding to or from their places of work, and on-duty operators of ambulances or other emergency vehicles. 
(f)  Public congregations. Until further notice from this office, it is prohibited for any person or persons in a public place, to refuse to obey a reasonable and lawful command of a policeman or other law enforcement official to leave the immediate area or disperse, when fairly made to prevent a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1971, § 2-26; Ord. No. 1218, § 4, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 10-41. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article, or violates any emergency measure promulgated in accordance with this article, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1971, § 2-26) 
Secs. 10-42-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEXUAL OFFENDERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Nudity, sexual conduct prohibited. 

Sec. 10-61. - Legislative findings and intent. 
(a)  The findings set forth in the recitals (whereas clauses) to this Ord. No. 1116 are hereby adopted as additional legislative findings. 
(b)  The City Council of the City of Maitland hereby adopts the provisions of Section 775.21(3)(a), Florida Statutes, which state as follows: 
    "Repeat sexual offenders, sexual offenders who use physical violence, and sexual offenders who prey on children are sexual predators who present an extreme threat to the public safety. Sexual offenders are extremely likely to use physical violence and to repeat their offenses, and most sexual offenders commit many offenses, have many more victims than are ever reported, and are prosecuted for only a fraction of their crimes. This makes the cost of sexual offender victimization to society at large, while incalculable, clearly exorbitant." 
(c)  The City Council of the City of Maitland hereby adopts the provisions of Section 947.1405(7), Florida Statutes, which provides, in pertinent part, that: 
    "It is the finding of the Legislature that the population of offenders released from state prison into the community who meet the conditional release criteria poses the greatest threat to the public safety of the groups of offenders under community supervision. Therefore, the Department of Corrections is to provide intensive supervision by experienced correctional probation officers to conditional release offenders." 
(d)  The City Council of the City of Maitland hereby finds and determines that the provisions of this article advance a legitimate public purpose and promote and protect the public health, safety, morals and welfare of the public. 
(e)  It is the desire of the City Council of the City of Maitland that the Orange County School District carefully adhere to the provisions of Section 947.1405(7), Florida Statutes, which relates to the requirement that school bus stops be located at least one thousand feet (1,000') from the persons who are the subject of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 1, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 10-62. - Prohibited residences of sexual offenders. 
    It is prohibited and unlawful for any person who has been convicted of a violation of Section 794.011, 1 [] Section 800.04, Section 827.071, or Section 847.0145, Florida Statutes, regardless of whether adjudication has been withheld, when the victim of the offense for which the conviction resulted was sixteen (16) years of age or younger at the time the offense was committed, to reside in a residence located within the City of Maitland when such residence is located within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of any school, day care center, public park, playground (such as miniparks and recreational open spaces), library or church. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 2, 8-22-05) 
Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
Sexual battery. 
Lewd or lascivious offenses committed upon or in the presence of persons less than 16 years of age. 
Sexual performance by a child. 
Selling or buying of minors. 

Sec. 10-63. - Application of ordinance/existing contracts. 
    The provisions of Section 10-62 shall not be applied to persons residing at a prohibited location on the effective date of this article such that it is not the intent of this article to impair valid, existing and bona fide contract rights; provided, however, that the provisions of Section 10-62 shall apply upon termination of any leasehold relationship arising from a landlord tenant relationship or the expiration of a lease. When a person who is the subject of this article changes residences, this article shall fully apply to such persons. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 3, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 10-64. - Community notification. 
    Once the Chief of Police of the City of Maitland is notified of a sexual offender or sexual predator residing within the City of Maitland he shall, within seven (7) days, provide notice to all residents, businesses or other establishments located within the neighborhood in which the offender resides. Notification shall be conducted in any manner deemed appropriate by the Chief of Police. Such notification shall be repeated annually so long as the sexual offender or sexual predator continues to reside within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 4, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 10-65. - Updating information. 
    In order to ensure the safety of both the sexual offender or sexual predator and the citizens of Maitland it is important that current information regarding each sexual offender or sexual predator's whereabouts and well-being be maintained; therefore, a member of the Maitland Police Department, as assigned by the Chief of Police, shall contact each known sexual offender or sexual predator residing within the City of Maitland every three (3) months to update the information required by Sections 943.0435 (12) and 775.21 (6), Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 5, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 10-66. - Field contact cards. 
    If a Maitland Police Officer encounters a subject who is a known sexual offender or sexual predator, a Field Contact Card shall be completed and forwarded to the Community Policing Division and shall contain as much of the following information as is available: 
(1)  The nature of the activity in which the sexual offender or sexual predator was involved at the time of contact; 
(2)  The location of the contact; 
(3)  The names of other persons present at contact; 
(4)  Whether the subject is visiting or has established an address in the Maitland or Orlando area; 
(5)  Whether the subject has registered with the FDLE as to his/her residency; 
(6)  The subject's place of employment including whether this employment is frequented by children; 
(7)  Whether or not the subject has obtained a recent Florida driver's license or identification card. 
    This information will assist the Community Policing Division in the filing of criminal charges, should the sexual offender or sexual predator be found to have committed a prohibited act. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no Field Contact Card will be required when a Maitland Police Officer encounters a known sexual offender or sexual predator who is reporting to the police station for the purpose of reporting as required by Sections 943.0435 (12) or Section 775.21 (6), Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 6, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 10-67. - Liability-Violation of provisions. 
    In accordance with Section 775.21(9), Florida Statutes, all elected officials, public agencies, and public employees are immune from civil liability from damages for good faith compliance with the recording and reporting requirements of this ordinance. The provisions of this article shall not be construed to create any duty, responsibility, or obligation for any elected officials, public agencies or public employees. Violation of the provisions of this article by any elected official, public agency or public employee does not constitute negligence per se. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 9, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 10-68. - Penalties. 
    As to any sexual offender or sexual predator found to have violated the provisions of this article, the City may pursue any enforcement action or legal remedy available under controlling State law and any legal remedy available to the City to include, but not be limited to, a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) unless otherwise authorized by State law or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days unless otherwise authorized by State law, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 1116, § 10, 8-22-05) 
Secs. 10-69-10-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIMULATED GAMING DEVICES 

Sec. 10-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial establishment means any establishment, whether operated for profit or not, that exchanges goods, product, services, or property of any kind for compensation or donation, or facilitates the exchange of goods, services, or property of any kind for compensation or donation in the ordinary course of trade, business, or fundraising, regardless of the land use designation assigned to the location of the commercial establishment. 
    Person means an individual, association, partnership, limited liability company, joint venture, not for profit corporation, corporation, or a director, executive, manager or officer of an association, partnership, limited liability company, joint venture, not for profit corporation, or corporation. 
    Simulated gaming device means any electronic, computerized, mechanical, or electromechanical device that, by the use or insertion of coin, bill, token, slug, form of payment, passcode, electronic or magnetic card in conjunction with the device or other reader or system connected or networked to the device or with the aid of some physical act by the user or commercial establishment representative, the device will allow an operator to use, play or operate the device such that the device displays simulated or actual games of chance, slot machine games, spinning wheels, line ups or arrangements of objects, symbols, colors, fruit, numbers or letters, or any game known as or similar to keno, roulette, faro, game at cards, poker, blackjack, "Fruit Bonus," "Triple Jack," "Mystery J&B," "Fruit Paradise," "Klondike," "Magical Odds," or "Reel of Fortune" in such a way as to display, disclose or reveal whether the user is to receive or become entitled to receive a payout, jackpot, or prize, which may include money, credits, tokens, or anything of value, or anything that may be exchanged for money, credits, tokens or anything of value, regardless of whether such payout, jackpot, or prize is made automatically from the device or other reader or system connected or networked to the device, or manually, and such device is located and used, played or operated in or at a commercial establishment in connection with the promotion, sale or purchase of good(s), product(s) or service(s). The term simulated gaming device further includes, without limitation, a "slot machine" as defined by Section 849.16, Florida Statutes. "Simulated gaming device" shall not be construed so as to preclude the lawful use or possession of: (i) reverse vending machines authorized pursuant to Section 849.16(2), Florida Statutes, (ii) amusement games or machines authorized pursuant to Section 849.161, Florida Statutes, (iii) bingo, instant bingo or pull tab machines or dispensers operated in accordance with Section 849.0931, Florida Statutes, (iv) a State of Florida lottery device authorized by Florida Statutes, or (v) any other device expressly authorized by and complying with the Florida Statutes and the Florida Administrative Code. Simulated gaming device shall not be construed to include devices not otherwise prohibited by general law that are not located in or at a commercial establishment and are used, played or operated for non-commercial purposes (i.e., not in connection with the promotion, sale or purchase of goods, products or services). 
(Ord. No. 1211, § 2, 5-23-11) 
Sec. 10-92. - Prohibition of simulated gaming device. 
    It is unlawful for any person to possess, use, play, or operate a simulated gaming device within the municipal boundaries of the city. Each individual use, play, operation or possession of a simulated gaming device shall be a separate violation of this Section. A violation of this Section shall constitute a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1211, § 3, 5-23-11) 
Sec. 10-93. - Remedies and penalties. 
    In the event that a violation of this article occurs, the City shall have the right to one or more of the following remedies or actions: 
(1)  Institute code enforcement proceedings and prosecute code violations against the violator and the property owner of the real property where the violation occurs; 
(2)  Prosecute the violator for a criminal misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court; 
(c)  Institute any appropriate action to bring about compliance or remedy, including but not limited to, instituting an action in court to enjoin violating actions, in which case the violating person shall be liable to the city for reimbursement of the city's attorneys' fees and costs concerning such action; and 
(d)  Take any other action or remedy authorized by law or in equity, in which case the violating person shall be liable to the city for reimbursement of the city's attorneys' fees and costs concerning such action. 
(Ord. No. 1211, § 4, 5-23-11) 
Chapter 11 - PARKS, RECREATION AND BOATING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Hours of operation and intensity of recreational lighting in residential areas, § 10-6; parks and recreation sites in subdivisions, § 16-45. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 11-1, 11-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 845, adopted September 26, 1994, repealed §§ 11-1, 11-2, which pertained to the use of the city's tennis and handball courts and derived from Code 1971, §§ 121/2-1, 121/2-2 and Ord. No. 568, §§ 1, 2, adopted October 9, 1980. 
Sec. 11-3. - Fort Maitland Park regulations. 
    The authorized hours for operation of Fort Maitland Park shall be 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. daily, Monday through Sunday. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to utilize Fort Maitland Park, including, but not limited to, its docks, boat launching facilities, beach area, restroom facilities, parking and recreational areas, except between the authorized hours defined above. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to park vehicles without boat trailers attached, in those areas specified for such parking. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to park in any space or area not designated for parking. This prohibition shall include parking on grassy areas and in the immediate area of the ramp itself. 
(d)  The police department shall have the authority to tow away any and all vehicles and trailers found to be in violation of any part of this section, and shall release such vehicles and trailers to the duly identified owners thereof, only upon the payment of and towing, storage and other charges incurred because of such violation. 
(e)  All persons using the Fort Maitland Park facilities as enumerated in section (a) shall conform to all rules and regulations set forth in Article II of Chapter II of the Code of Ordinances pertaining to boats, boating, and the use of waterways. 
(Ord. No. 551, § 1, 11-26-79; Ord. No. 571, § 1, 12-8-80; Ord. No. 658, § 1, 2-18-85) 
Sec. 11-4. - Park rules and regulations. 
Sec. 11-4.1. Definitions. 
    As used in this section: 
    Bike path is a designated public way intended for bicyclists, through a park or other park property. 
    Park property means all real and personal property including but not limited to land, buildings, facilities, equipment and amenities as described in the "parks" definition. 
    Parks and other areas operated and maintained by the City of Maitland Parks and Recreation Department include but are not limited to parks, playgrounds, recreation fields, museums, buildings, boat ramps, lakes, streams, canals, channels, lagoons, therein, and all public service facilities located on or in grounds, waters, building and structures in the City of Maitland, which are under the control of or assigned for upkeep, maintenance or operation by the parks and recreation department. 
    Parks and recreation director is the parks and recreation director of the City of Maitland, Florida, or his designee. 
    Special events are public or private assemblies or events that could conflict with the normal use and operation of the park. 
    Special written permit is for exceptions to established park rules and regulations and is issued by the parks and recreation department. 
Sec. 11-4.2. Enforcement of park rules. 
(a)  The rules, regulations and permits contained in this document are enforceable by all law enforcement officers and parks and recreation department personnel. 
(b)  Parents or guardians will be held strictly responsible for the actions of minors. 
(c)  Any violation of any of the provisions of this section may result in loss of park privileges and may be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
Sec. 11-4.3. Lost and found. 
    Any lost articles shall be immediately turned over to parks and recreation personnel on site. Otherwise, lost articles shall be turned into the parks and recreation department. Articles of value, i.e. cash, jewelry, weapons, etc., will be turned over to the Maitland Police Department for safe keeping. The police department will make a good faith effort to contact the owner(s). Title to the lost article will remain with the owner for six (6) months. After six (6) months, the unclaimed article will be placed in the city auction for sale or converted to use by the city when appropriate. 
Sec. 11-4.4. Park hours. 
(a)  Parks are to be opened to the public every day of the year except for emergencies. Park hours for each park shall be posted. 
(b)  Any park or park area may be closed in the interest of public welfare at the discretion of the parks and recreation director. 
(c)  Reservation of specific park facilities during normal park hours by private groups may be granted by special written permit. 
Sec. 11-4.5. Special events. 
    Special events shall require a special events permit to be issued by the police department in accordance with Chapter 14 of the City Code. 
Sec. 11-4.6. Prohibited activities in parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any one or more of the following in any park, unless specifically permitted to do so by a special written permit issued by the city manager or his designee pursuant to this chapter, except for activities of a governmental agency within the scope of its governmental authority: 
(1)  Possess, sell, give or serve any alcoholic beverage as defined by F.S. § 561.01(4). 
(2)  Carry, fire or discharge any rocket or other fireworks of any description. 
(3)  Interfere with, hinder, or oppose any park and recreation personnel in the discharge of their duties or in the enforcement of the park rules and regulations. 
(4)  Operate audio equipment at a sound level that disturbs other park patrons. 
(5)  Engage in noisy activities in violation of section 10-10 of the City Code. 
(6)  Conduct themselves in an improper manner so as to offend or disrupt park visitors. 
(7)  Change clothes except in designated facilities. 
(8)  Set a fire except in grills provided by the city. No bonfires or open fires will be permitted on Dog Island. 
(9)  Enter or remain on park property outside of posted hours. 
(10)  Enter upon any part of any park property which is under construction or closed to the general public. 
(11)  Mark, deface, tamper with, damage, displace or remove any park property. 
(12)  Search or excavate, or construct or erect any structure, or run or string any public utility on park property. 
(13)  Disturb and/or interfere with wildlife except in the interest of public welfare. 
(14)  Tamper with or remove any plant life or landscape element. 
(15)  Sell anything tangible or intangible, or solicit for any purpose. 
(16)  Distribute or circulate any written or printed matter. 
(17)  Engage in recreational activities such as football, baseball, softball, horseshoes, tennis, volleyball, badminton, or any other activity involving propelled objects such as balls, arrows, shuttlecocks, frisbees, roller skates, or skateboards except in areas not in conflict with other activities. 
(18)  Swim or wade except in designated areas. 
(19)  Swim or wade except during posted hours. 
(20)  Wear a swimsuit resulting in indecent exposure of the person or merit criticism based on conformity of swimming suits with commonly accepted standards in compliance with existing Florida State Statutes. 
(21)  Wash with or without soap or other cleaners in any swimming area. 
(22)  Scuba dive in any park waters. 
(23)  Use any device designed to artificially hold a person afloat unless supervised by a responsible party. 
(24)  Allow children under the age of twelve (12) in designated swimming areas unaccompanied by a parent or a person designated by the parent. 
(25)  Fishing where prohibited by signage. 
(26)  Boating except in accordance with Chapter 11 of the City Code. 
(27)  Litter on any park property or waters. All refuse must be deposited in receptacles provided for trash disposal. 
(28)  Post or affix any signage on park property. 
(29)  Drive or park any motor vehicle on any park property which has not been designated for such purpose. 
(30)  Drive a motor vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding ten (10) miles per hour on any park property unless a greater speed limit is posted. 
(31)  Enter or exit from any park property in any motor vehicle except on entrances and exits established for such purposes. 
(32)  Load or unload except in areas designated for that purpose. 
(33)  Use bicycles, personalized motor vehicles, roller skates or skateboards on vehicular roads and parking areas in excess of posted speed limits and on designated bike paths in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(34)  Park bicycles in such a way as to obstruct circulation of traffic paths or cause damage or harm to any park property or plant life. Where available bicycle racks must be used. 
(35)  Use human powered vehicles in conflict with traffic circulation or other park activities. 
(b)  Any aggrieved applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial of a permit under section 11-4.6 to the city council. The appeal shall be taken by the applicant within five (5) days after the receipt of the notice of denial by filing a written notice with the city manager or his designee. The city manager or his designee, shall place the appeal on the next available agenda for consideration by the city council. 
Sec. 11-4.7. Animals in city parks. 
(a)  Animals are allowed in city parks under the following conditions: 
(1)  The animal must be under the control of a responsible owner; 
(2)  The animal must be on a leash at all times; 
(3)  The animal shall not be tethered to any object at any time; 
(4)  The responsible person in control of the animal shall not permit the animal to approach within 10 feet of facilities (i.e. picnic tables, active recreation facilities, buildings, etc.) meant for human utilization; and, 
(5)  The responsible person in control of the animal shall remove any feces deposited by the animal. Failure to do so immediately shall constitute an additional violation of this section. 
(b)  No animals shall be allowed in the Lake Destiny Soccer Field, the Maitland Ballfield Complex and the Maitland Cemetery. 
(c)  Animals are allowed in the Maitland Community Park in designated areas only. 
(d)  Animals employed by any governmental agency and companions of the physically challenged are exempted from this section. 
(Ord. No. 837, § 1, 6-13-94; Ord. No. 995, § 88, 3-27-00; Ord. No. 1213, § 2, 7-11-11; Ord. No. 1218, § 5, 9-26-11) 
Secs. 11-5-11-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOATS, BOATING AND USE OF WATERWAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 11-14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 769, adopted Mar. 25, 1991, repealed former § 11-14, which pertained to definition and derived from Code 1971, § 5-1, and Ord. No. 681, § 1, adopted Dec. 9, 1985. 
Sec. 11-15. - Adoption of state law and Coast Guard regulations. 
    The provisions of Florida Statutes, Chapter 327, and United States Coast Guard Inland Navigation Rules, are hereby adopted the same as if set forth herein. 
(Code 1971, § 5-5; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-16. - Violations. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished as for a violation of this Code of Ordinances under the following provisions. For a non-moving violation, the fine shall be eighty-nine dollars ($89.00). For a moving violation, the fine shall be ninety-nine dollars ($99.00). Officers may elect to write violators a violation notice by means of a Florida Uniform Boating Citation which shall be processed through the clerk's office, or by means of a city form, Notice of Code Violation, in which case the fine shall be the same, but the appeals and/or hearing process shall be before the special magistrate of the City of Maitland during a regularly scheduled monthly hearing date. Appearing before the magistrate and being found to have committed the violation may result in additional fines, not to exceed two hundred fifty ($250.00), and an administrative cost to be determined by the magistrate. Any judgments rendered may be enforceable as a lien against property and listed as debt owed to the City of Maitland on credit reports. Failure to arrange for a hearing or pay the fine within thirty (30) days will result in the person's privilege to operate a boat being suspended and if the person is an owner or co-owner of a vessel, the chain of lakes pass may be suspended until such time as payment is made. No day pass shall be issued to any such vessel if the yearly permit has been suspended. 
(Code 1971, § 5-26; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91; Ord. No. 1188, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 11-17. - Landing seaplanes prohibited; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful to land a float or seaplane on any lake or waterway of the city except in an emergency. 
(Code 1971, § 5-21; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-18. - Molesting, tampering with, boats; setting hazardous objects adrift. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(a)  Molest, tamper with, damage, destroy, trespass upon or cast loose or set adrift any boat or boats belonging to another, or to disturb, destroy, steal, take or carry away any of the contents, fixtures or appurtenances of any boat belonging to another. 
(b)  Set adrift any object which may constitute a hazard to the safe operation of any boat or person skiing. 
(Code 1971, § 5-7) 
Sec. 11-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 769, adopted Mar. 25, 1991, repealed former § 11-19, which pertained to boats or hazardous objects adrift to be secured and derived from Code 1971, § 5-8. 
Sec. 11-20. - Temporary obstructions extending from shoreline to be lighted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit any temporary obstruction, barge, dredge, temporary pier, dock or vessel to extend further than forty (40) feet from the shoreline, or to anchor any float, vessel, buoy or other hazard to navigation more than forty (40) feet from the shoreline unless lighted between the hours of sunset and sunrise, to show the overall length of any such temporary barge, dredge, vessel or other obstruction. 
(Code 1971, § 5-16; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-21. - Regattas and other organized aquatic activities-Regulations generally. 
    Persons, or organizations, sponsoring rowing or sailing regattas, swimming meets, or other similar organized aquatic activities on the waterways of the city shall apply to the city manager for a permit, and shall furnish proof of insurance, satisfactory to the city attorney, to protect the interest of the city the participants, spectators, and the public, at least fifteen (15) days prior to such event. 
(Code 1971, § 5-20; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-22. - Same-Sponsors to provide for traffic control. 
    Persons, or organizations, sponsoring rowing or sailing regattas, swimming meets, or other similar organized aquatic activities on the waterways of the city shall notify the Maitland police department, in writing, at least fifteen (15) days prior to such event in order that appropriate arrangements for safety and navigation may be assured, and shall provide adequate traffic control, at their own expense, as may be required by the police department. 
(Code 1971, § 5-20; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-23. - Water sports. 
(a)  Vessel operators shall immediately retrieve persons who have fallen from, or voluntarily stopped, waterskiing, wakeboarding, surfboarding, kneeboarding, aquaplaning, watersleding, tubing, or riding other similar devices behind their vessels. Equipment used in such sports shall be retrieved only after such people are safely in their vessel. 
(b)  Vessel operators shall not tow anyone on waterskis, wakeboards, surfboards, kneeboards, aquaplanes, watersleds, tubes, or other similar devices, within one hundred (100) feet of the shoreline, nor in canals or under bridges. 
(c)  Waterskiers, wakeboarders, surfboarders, kneeboarders, aquaplaners, watersledders, tubers or persons using similar devices being pulled by vessels shall stay clear of the shoreline a minimum distance of one hundred (100) feet, they shall not use such devices in canals or under bridges. Operators shall not permit persons engaged in above listed activities to use safety buoys as slalom markers. 
(d)  All persons riding personal watercraft (jet skis, waveriders, motorized surfboards and other similar vessels), windsurfers, wakeboards, waterskis, surfboards being towed or free floating on boat wakes, kneeboards, aquaplanes, watersleds, tubes, or other similar devices, shall wear a properly sized, U.S. Coast Guard approved, Personal Flotation Device (PFD), Type I, II, or III. 
(e)  All boats and personal watercraft towing water skiers, wakeboarders, surfboarders, aquaplaners, sledders or tubers shall have two persons in the boat or on the personal watercraft, one facing aft and the other facing forward. 
(f)  Operators of vessels towing skiers, wakeboarders, surfboarders, aquaplaners, sledders or tubers, where practicable, shall take turns in a counterclockwise direction. 
(Code 1971, § 5-20; Ord. No. 681, § 1, 12-9-85; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91; Ord. No. 1188, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 11-24. - Boat to accompany swimmer more than 100 feet from shore. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim further from the shore than one hundred (100) feet unless accompanied by a boat. 
(Code 1971, § 5-15) 
Sec. 11-25. - Skin divers to be accompanied by boat and flag; diving in canals prohibited. 
    No person shall scuba or skin dive unless accompanied by a boat and identified by a scuba or skin diving flag. No person shall scuba or skin dive in any of the canals. 
(Code 1971, § 5-22) 
Sec. 11-26. - Regulation of slalom courses. 
    A permit for a ski-slalom course may be obtained from the city manager provided: 
(1)  An application, including a set of plans showing the location of the course and the depth of the water, is filed with the city manager. 
(2)  It does not create a navigational hazard or otherwise interfere with the public use of the waterways of the city. 
(3)  The structure is placed in a location with a minimum water depth of six (6) feet, and shall be placed a minimum of three hundred (300) feet from any shoreline that is not under the ownership or control of the permittee. 
(4)  The buoys shall be of soft rubber or vinyl, styrofoam, or plastic bottles not to exceed one gallon in capacity. 
(Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Secs. 11-27-11-34. - Reserved. 
Sec. 11-35. - Hang gliding, parachuting, parasailing, hot air ballooning, and airboating prohibited. 
    Hang gliding, parachuting, parasailing, hot air ballooning, and airboating are prohibited on the lakes and waterways of the city, except that air boats may be used in the city's official weed control program. 
(Ord. No. 658, § 2, 2-18-85; Ord. No. 681, § 1, 12-9-85; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
DIVISION 2. - WATERWAYS USER FEES 

Sec. 11-36. - Required. 
    Every owner or operator of an inboard or outboard motor vessel operating upon any waterway, either partially or wholly within the corporate limits of the city, shall be required to pay the city a user fee to offset the cost of patrolling and maintaining such waterways, and shall at all times display an appropriate valid user fee receipt on said boat, or the operator shall have in his possession a valid daily user fee receipt. 
(Code 1971, § 5-2; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-37. - Prerequisites. 
(a)  In order to use a vessel on the city's waterways, the owners shall give the make, model, horsepower, length of vessel, the State of Florida registration number, and certify that such vessel has all equipment required by the State of Florida and the City of Maitland. Owners of vessels carrying passengers for hire shall also present satisfactory evidence that said vessel has been safety inspected and found to be safe by the U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary. 
(b)  No vessel equipped with an engine that exceeds the maximum horsepower recommended by the manufacturer of the vessel shall be issued a user fee receipt. 
(Code 1971, § 5-2; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-38. - Collection agents. 
    The city manager or his designated agent is hereby authorized to collect such user fees and dispense such receipts. 
(Code 1971, § 5-2; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 11-39. - Issuance, display of receipts; shape. 
    Upon payment of the user fee required by this article, two (2) receipts shall be issued to the payer of the user fee. Those receipts shall be affixed one on each side of the bow, fore and aft of the state registration numbers. User fee decals issued the year beginning July 1, 1976, shall be triangular shape, with a square used for the year beginning July 1, 1977, and a circle for the year beginning July 1, 1978. Thereafter, these shapes shall be repeated in the same sequence during each succeeding three-year period. 
(Code 1971, § 5-3; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 11-40. - Transfer of user fee receipts. 
    Sale or transfer of ownership of a motorboat to which is attached a receipt showing payment of such user fee shall not invalidate the receipt, provided the police department or finance department is notified within ten (10) days of such change in ownership. The intention of the city council is that a user fee be paid and receipts issued for each motorboat utilizing such waterways regardless of ownership or transfer of ownership. Such receipts, however, are not transferable from one boat to another. 
(Code 1971, § 5-2; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 11-41. - User fee schedule. 
    Annual or daily user fees. A daily user fee of six dollars ($6.00) shall be paid prior to the operation of any motorboat. In lieu of the daily user fee, an annual use fee may be paid based upon the dollar amount and unit set forth in this subsection. The unit shall be calculated by adding the length of the boat in feet, rounded to the next higher whole foot, together with the manufacturer's advertised maximum horsepower of the engine or engines, at maximum RPM, rounded to the next higher whole horsepower. The total of these two (2) numbers is the number of "units" assigned to each motorboat, and will be the basis for calculating boat user fees. Length shall mean the measurement from end to end over the deck parallel to the center line excluding sheer. The user fee shall be imposed by applying the unit for each boat times the user's fee factor set forth below. 
Noncommercial 
Annual Commercial Annual Motorboat owned by city resident $0.50 $1.00 Motorboat owned by non-resident of city $0.75 $1.50  
Annual user fees paid between January 1st and June 30th shall be one-half (1/2) the aforementioned amount. 
(Code 1971, § 5-3; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 604, § 1, 7-26-82; Ord. No. 667, § 1, 6-24-85; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89; Ord. No. 1173, § 1, 10-27-08) 
Sec. 11-42. - Special provision for dealers. 
    Recognized dealers in vessels may obtain annual user fee receipts to be attached to vessels for the purpose of vessel demonstrations, sales promotion or testing without supplying identification data for individual vessels as required by section 11-37, provided they comply with Florida Statute 328.52. 
(Code 1971, § 5-3; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-43. - Application of user fee revenues. 
    All revenues received by the city from payments of daily and annual user fees shall be expended for the patrol, maintenance, and improvement of lakes or waters including the navigability on the city's waterways as well as other boating-related activities in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 5-3; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-23-81; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Sec. 11-44. - Reciprocity with City of Winter Park. 
    At such time as the City of Winter Park shall adopt and have in effect an ordinance with sufficient similarity to Chapter 11 of this Code relating to boats and containing a like reciprocity section, all motorboats for which the user fee has been duly and properly paid to the City of Winter Park shall be permitted to be operated upon any waterway within the corporate limits of the City of Maitland without the payment of any further user fee to the City of Maitland, or requirement for securing any user fee from the City of Maitland. 
(Code 1971, § 5-25; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 6-29-89; Ord. No. 743, § 1, 7-24-89) 
Secs. 11-45-11-58. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OPERATION OF BOATS 

Sec. 11-59. - Operation of power boats by minors. 
(a)  No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall operate a power-driven vessel on the waterways of the city without first obtaining a junior boating license or restricted junior boating license; from the Maitland or Winter Park police departments. Such safety certificate may be obtained by: 
(1)  Filing an application with the police department, and upon presentation of evidence that they have satisfactorily completed the basic U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary, U.S. Power Squadron, or the Florida boating safety course. These courses approved by the Lakes Advisory Board are proof completion of a boating safety course, 
(2)  Passing a practical test, administered by the police department in the operation of a power driven vessel similar in design and horsepower to the vessel such minor will regularly be operating, and, be issued a certificate of proficiency for the operation of that type vessel. 
(3)  A personal watercraft endorsement is required if the vessel to be operated is of the PWC design. This is in addition to the junior boating license. 
(b)  Such application shall be signed and verified before a person authorized to administer oaths by the father, mother, or guardian, or in the event there is no parent or guardian, by another responsible adult who is willing to assume the obligation imposed under this chapter upon a person signing the application of a minor. The application shall contain a certification by the applicant that they can swim one hundred (100) feet. 
(c)  Any negligence or willful misconduct of a minor under eighteen (18) years of age when operating a power driven vessel on the waterways of the city shall be imputed to the person who has signed the application of such minor which person shall be jointly and severally liable with such minor for any damage caused by such negligence or willful misconduct of such minor. 
(d)  If such person who signed an application of a minor shall file with the police department a verified, written request that the safety certificate of such minor so granted be canceled, or upon the death of the person who has signed the application of a minor, the department shall cancel the safety certificate of that minor, and the person, or estate of that person, who signed the application of such minor shall be relieved from liability imposed by this chapter. 
(e)  A restricted junior boating license shall be issued to any minor under fourteen (14) years of age who has fulfilled all of the requirements of this chapter. This shall entitle said minor to operate a vessel of 9.9 horse power or less without an adult present. For vessels over 9.9 horse power, an adult, someone over the age of eighteen (18) must be on board and is declared the responsible party. Under no circumstances shall this license allow the operation of a personal water craft (PWC) upon the waters of the City of Maitland unless there is a PWC endorsement. The restricted junior boating license may be upgraded to include the operation of a PWC once the operator reaches the age of fourteen (14) provided a practical operations test is also administered and passed. 
(f)  If any person is found to have been convicted of four (4) or more noncriminal infractions, or two (2) or more criminal infractions of this chapter, or the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, the police department shall suspend such person's motor boat operators' safety certificate for a period of not more than one year. Upon such suspension the certificate holder must surrender to the police department the safety certificate so suspended. 
(g)  The police department shall revoke the motor boat operators' safety certificate of any person who: 
(1)  Operates any motor vessel when such safety certificate or privilege is canceled or suspended; or 
(2)  Is found to have violated the provisions of Florida Statute 327.35, and such person shall not be eligible to be recertified for a period of three (3) years from the date of revocation. The certificate holder must surrender to the police department the safety certificate so revoked. 
(h)  When any person's safety certificate has been suspended or revoked pursuant to the provisions of this section, the police department shall not grant such person's motor boating privileges be restored except upon the reexamination of the certificate holder after the expiration of the period of suspension or revocation so prescribed. 
(Code 1971, § 5-6; Ord. No. 681, § 1, 12-9-85; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91; Ord. No. 1188, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 11-60. - Reckless or negligent operation generally. 
(a)  Power-driven vessels shall not follow a person on skis, kneeboard, surfboard, tube or similar device at a distance of less than three hundred (300) feet. 
(b)  Power-driven vessels shall stay clear of all vessels at anchor, or adrift, a minimum of one hundred (100) feet. 
(c)  Power-driven vessels shall stay clear of sailboats, sailboards, windsurfers, canoes, kayaks, rowboats, and all other nonpower-driven vessels, vessels at idle speed, vessels powered by electric trolling motors, and vessels being used for fishing a minimum of one hundred (100) feet. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a vessel operator to permit anyone to ride on the bow, gunwales, transom, outboard motor, or swim platform of any vessel under way. 
(Code 1971, § 5-22; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
State Law reference- Reckless or careless operation, F.S. § 327.33. 
Sec. 11-61. - Overloading. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate a vessel on the waterways of the city containing a number of persons in excess of the manufacturer's recommendation, or otherwise overloaded to such an extent as to render it unstable or in danger of capsizing or sinking. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate a vessel on the waterways of the city equipped with an engine whose horsepower exceeds the maximum horsepower recommended by the manufacturer of the vessel. 
(Code 1971, § 5-22; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-62. - Speed of vessels. 
(a)  The speed of vessels shall not exceed forty (40) miles per hour during daylight hours, or twenty (20) miles per hour between sunset and sunrise. 
(b)  No person shall operate a vessel at speeds which will cause a wake, bow or stern wave, or propeller wash within one hundred (100) feet of piers, boathouses, or the shoreline of any lake in the city. 
(c)  All steams [streams] and canals in the city are hereby declared "no wake zones." Vessel operators shall not proceed at such speed that a wake, bow or stern wave, or propeller wash is created by their vessel in streams or canals. 
(Ord. No. 681, § 1, 12-9-85; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 681, § 1, adopted Dec. 9, 1985, provided for the repeal of §§ 11-62-11-64, concerning boating speed near shore or other boats and in canals, as derived from Code 1971, §§ 5-9, 5-22, and added similar provisions as set out in § 11-62 above. 
Secs. 11-63, 11-64. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to § 11-62. 
Sec. 11-65. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 658, § 3, adopted Feb. 18, 1985, provided for the repeal of § 11-65 which limited the maximum horsepower of boat motors used on Lake Jackson. Such section was derived from the 1971 Code, § 5-9. 
Sec. 11-66. - Anchoring obstructing passage. 
    No person shall anchor any boat in such a position as to interfere with the access to or passage through any canal connecting lakes or bodies of water, or in any restricted channels. 
(Code 1971, § 5-22) 
Sec. 11-67. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 769, adopted Mar. 25, 1991, repealed former § 11-67, which pertained to the rules governing the passing of boats and derived from Code 1971, § 5-10. 
Sec. 11-68. - Vessels meeting in canals. 
(a)  Whenever vessels proceeding in opposite directions must pass within a canal in a constricted area, the vessel nearest a passing area shall return to that area to effect the passing, and when practicable, shall pass port to port. Vessels intending entrance to a canal shall yield the right-of-way to boats exiting the canal. In the event there is a passing area closer than the exit, the boat in the canal shall return or remain in that area to effect the passing. 
(b)  Vessels proceeding in the same direction shall not pass in canals. 
(c)  Vessels shall not be anchored, moored, or secured in any manner within any canal or under bridges, except in an emergency, in which case the police department shall be notified as soon as possible of the location of the vessel. Nothing herein shall limit the use of piers or boathouses within canals by authorized vessels, provided such use does not impede vessels transiting canal. 
(Code 1971, § 5-22; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Secs. 11-69, 11-70. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 769, adopted Mar. 25, 1991, repealed former §§ 11-69 and 11-70, which pertained to the speed of motorboats near unpowered craft and fishing boats and derived from Code 1971, §§ 5-11 and 5-12. 
Sec. 11-70.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 681, § 1, Dec. 9, 1985, provided for the repeal of §§ 11-70.1, 11-71 and 11-72, concerning required safety equipment, lights, life preservers and fire extinguishers, as derived from Code 1971, §§ 5-4, 5-13, 5-14; and Ord. No. 573, § 1, adopted Mar. 23, 1981; and enacted similar provisions codified as § 11-71. 
Sec. 11-71. - Required equipment. 
(a)  Safety equipment and lighting. Every vessel on the lakes or waterways of the city shall carry safety equipment and conform to uniform lighting requirements in accordance with the current U.S. Coast Guard Safety and Lighting Requirements and Federal Regulation, unless expressly exempt by state law. 
(b)  White lights required for certain vessels. Every vessel not under power, whether at anchor or adrift, and all vessels propelled by trolling motors, oars, paddles or sails, and all other vessels not displaying lights required by the U.S. Coast Guard Minimum Requirements for Motorboats shall display one white light visible from all directions (from three hundred sixty (360) degrees), at all times between sunset and sunrise. 
(c)  Muffling device. Every power-driven vessel shall have a muffling device so constructed and used as to muffle the noise of the exhaust so that it does not exceed a maximum sound level of ninety (90) dBA at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the vessel. 
(d)  Sound signal. Every vessel shall have a sound signal capable of a four-second to six-second blast audible for one-half (1/2) mile. 
(Ord. No. 681, § 1, 12-9-85; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
State Law reference- Boating equipment required, F.S. § 327.50. 
Sec. 11-72. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note following § 11-70.1. 
Sec. 11-73. - Damage to markers, buoys, etc.; reports of accidents and obstructions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, damage or destroy any channel markers, buoys, speed limit signs or directional signals maintained by the city in or about any of the lakes or canals within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Any person injuring or damaging any channel markers, buoys, bulkheads, docks or boathouses or involved in any collision or upset with any other craft shall report such incident to the city police department without delay. Any person having knowledge of any underwater obstruction or floating object which would endanger the safe navigation of any boat will report the location and nature of such obstruction to the city police department as soon as possible. 
(Code 1971, § 5-17) 
State Law reference- Mooring to or damaging markers, buoys, etc., F.S. § 327.42. 
Sec. 11-74. - Use of motorized craft restricted on Lake Lucien. 
    Biological data shows that Lake Lucien is the highest-quality lake within the city. In order to protect and preserve the high quality of water in Lake Lucien, and in order to promote the public health, safety, and welfare, the following regulations shall apply: It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to operate or otherwise use any motorized craft or motor-driven boat on Lake Lucien with the single exception of electrically powered (trolling) motors that have a maximum thrust capability not exceeding thirty-three (33) pounds. Nothing herein contained, however, shall be construed so as to prohibit the use of motorized or motor-driven craft on Lake Lucien by the appropriate governmental agencies or their authorized representatives in carrying out biological, hydrological, or similar research duties on Lake Lucien; nor shall this section be construed so as to prohibit the use of any motorized or motor-driven craft on Lake Lucien by any person or persons in response to an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 588, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Sec. 11-75. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1014, § 6, adopted July 23, 2001, repealed former section 11-75 in its entirety which pertained to the display of house numbers on boathouses and docks and derived from Ord. No. 681, § 1, 12-9-85. 
Sec. 11-76. - Enforcement. 
    The city police department shall have the power to enforce the regulations contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 769, § 1, 3-25-91) 
Sec. 11-77. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 995, § 89, adopted March 27, 2000, repealed former section 11-77 in its entirety which pertained to severability and derived from Ord. No. 769, § 1, adopted March 25, 1991. 
DIVISION 4. - CONSTRUCTION OF BOAT DOCKS, BOATHOUSES, BOAT RAMPS, BOARDWALKS AND SEAWALLS. 

Sec. 11-78. - Permit required. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct a boat dock, boathouse, boat ramp, boardwalk or seawall within the City of Maitland on all natural and artificial (including city-owned) bodies of water shall first apply for a City of Maitland Waterfront Structure Permit prior to the installation. No boat dock (floating or stationary), boathouse, boat ramp, boardwalk, boat slip, seawall, or other structure shall be constructed except in accordance with an approved permit issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  This division is intended for all waterfront structures. It is the intent of this chapter to ensure that on canalfront lots, lakefront lots and streamfront lots no boating hazards will be created, water pollution from stormwater runoff and other sources will be minimized, views of water from adjoining properties will not be unduly impaired, and the appearance of the shore when viewed from the water will be kept as natural as reasonably possible. The city's lakes, canals and streams are among the city's greatest assets, and it is in the public interest to require that their aesthetic appeal and water quality be maintained and enhanced when possible. 
(c)  Application shall be made to the city in a format approved by the city. A processing fee, in an amount which shall be determined from time to time by city council shall be paid at the time the application is submitted for review. Payment of the application fee shall in no way guarantee issuance of a permit, and such fee is non-refundable. 
(Ord. No. 1014, § 7, 7-23-01; Ord. No. 1189, § 1, 8-10-09) 
Sec. 11-79. - Application for permit. 
    Application forms for a permit shall be available at the permitting desk of the community development and building department. If the proposed structure is for public use, the application shall be reviewed by the appropriate city boards. Except for docks or related structures approved for public use, no permit application will be accepted unless a principal use exists on the applicant's property. Along with the waterfront structure permit application, the applicant must submit four (4) copies of a scaled drawing that provides accurately the information requested on the permit application. Where possible, the required elevations shall be determined using as a reference a certified depth gauge placed in each lake by the City of Maitland. The scaled drawing shall also include: 
(1)  The name of the lake or water body; 
(2)  An arrow indicating the northerly direction; 
(3)  An indication of the scale to which the drawings are prepared; 
(4)  All dimensions of the subject property and the dimensions and location of the proposed waterfront structure, the 100-year flood elevation, and the lake elevation (NHWE) listed in Table No. 1. Length shall be measured from the lake elevation (NHWE) listed in Table No. 1 in section 11-80 of this division. 
(5)  The point where the lake elevation (NHWE) listed on Table No. 1 in section 11-80 intersects with the shoreline and proposed construction. 
(6)  The setbacks from adjacent property lines; 
(7)  The floor elevation of the proposed boat dock, and the floor and roof elevation of any boat house or any other structure connected to the dock, relative to the lake elevation (NHWE) listed in Table No 1. section 11-80 of this division. 
(8)  Width of the water body or canal at the location of the proposed dock, if said water body or canal is less than two hundred (200) feet in width. All measurements shall be taken from the lake elevation (NHWE) listed on Table No. 1 in section 11-80 herein. 
(9)  Elevation of the top of seawalls shall be indicated on plans. The maximum elevation shall not be higher than the 100-year flood elevation listed in Table No. 1 in section 11-80 herein. 
(10)  Location of floating turbidity barriers and upland erosion controls. 
(11)  Either a piling location survey certified by the contractor, or a piling location survey prepared by a registered land surveyor, to provide evidence of proper piling location. The piling survey shall include the lake elevation (NHWE), the finish floor elevation of the waterfront Structure(s), piling layout with clearly indicated measurements of the side yard setbacks, boat dock length and distance into the water body measured from a permanent reference point. This document must be approved by the city prior to proceeding with the decking or framing. any deviation from this procedure, due to individual construction methods, must be approved in advance by the city. 
(12)  As part of a waterfront structure permit application, shorelines that do not meet the vegetation standards of section 8-14 of the Maitland City Code shall be required to be planted with native aquatic species so that no more than fifty (50) feet, or fifty (50) percent (whichever is less) of the shoreline remains clear of vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 1014, § 7, 7-23-01; Ord. No. 1189, § 2, 8-10-09) 
Sec. 11-80. - Review of application. 
    The permit application shall be processed by the city manager or designee under the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  Boat docks, boathouses, boat ramps, and boardwalks shall have a minimum side set-back from the property line abutting shoreline property of ten (10) feet, measured at the point(s) where the property lines(s) intersect the lake elevation (NHWE) listed in Table No. 1 in Section 11-80 herein, or unless approved as a part of a planned development or developers agreement or by city council on appeal:
