**See special parking provisions noted in Section 21-19a. III. Design guidelines. 
(1) Residential single-family districts RS-1, RS-2, RS-3, RS-1A, RS-D-The platting, replatting, or splitting of a lot(s) or parcel(s) which creates additional lots, for lots so created fronting a lake, canal, or creek, shall adhere to the specification as referenced in the matrix above. The minimum lot width is applied to the frontage on the lake as well as a minimum frontage at the street. 
(2) For the area defined in Ordinance No. 799 as the "Mayo Avenue Area Annexation", A 15-foot street side yard may be preserved for those residential properties that were constructed, prior to the effective annexation date, in accordance with the street side yard regulation. The "street side" yard provision of fifteen (15) feet may be applied to future additions to the existing structure (residence) along the respective "street side" yard subject to all other City of Maitland Code requirements. 
(3) For the area defined in Ordinance No. 799 as the "Mayo Avenue Area Annexation", for residential zoning districts the side yard requirement is 71/2 feet, subject to all other City of Maitland Code requirements. 
(4) For the area defined in Ordinance No. 799 as the "Mayo Avenue Area Annexation", for those residential properties that were constructed with a lot coverage which exceeded 30% prior to effective annexation date, if destroyed it may be replaced without further increase of lot coverage, subject to all other City of Maitland Code requirements. 
(5) Per every 100 linear feet of linear distance of required bufferyard 3 trees (21/2? caliper, 10' high minimum upon installation) 10 shrubs 18?-19? wide upon installation. 
(6) Once a single-family residential dwelling unit in the RS-D zoning district is permitted to be constructed to 71/2 feet from the side property line and to encroach the ten-foot side yard required for duplex units, conversion to a duplex unit will be prohibited on that lot unless and until the structure is modified to meet the side yard requirements for duplex units. 
(7) The maximum lot coverage for the RS-3 zoning district is 30% for all buildings and accessory buildings and two-story principal structures, with an additional 5% lot coverage allowable for single-story structures with no guest houses or detached accessory structures. 
(8) Buildings shall be a minimum of one hundred (100) feet from any single family residential zoning district where height exceeds thirty-five (35) feet, and additional plant heights shall be required within the required buffer yards to accommodate adjacent residential uses, where applicable. This limitation shall not apply where the single family zoning designation is non-conforming to the Future Land Use Designation as adopted in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan. 
(9) For the area defined in Ordinance No. 859 as the "Druid Annexation Area," a 15-foot "street side yard" may be preserved for those residential properties that were constructed, prior to the effective annexation date, in accordance with the street side yard regulation. The "street side yard" provision of 15 feet may be applied to future additions to the existing structure (residence) alone the respective "street side yard" subject to all other City of Maitland Code requirements. 
(10) For the area defined in Ordinance No. 859 as the "Druid Annexation Area," for those residential properties that were constructed with a lot coverage which exceeded 30% prior to effective annexation date, if destroyed may be replaced without further increase of lot coverage, subject to all other City of Maitland Code requirements. 
(11) For the area defined in Ordinance No. 859 as the "Druid Annexation Area," for residential zoning districts the side requirement is 71/2 feet, subject to all other City of Maitland Code requirements. 
(12) For properties with frontage on Maitland Avenue within the Cultural Corridor District (except front yards on Horatio Avenue and Lake Sybelia Drive) the required front yard from the back edge of curb shall be as follows: 
 For a development with proposed on-street parking, the required front yard for the building shall include a 2-foot transition zone and a 6-foot sidewalk area, for a total distance of 8 feet maximum from the back edge of curb. Areas for consideration of on-street parking shall be as indicated on the typical sections of Maitland Avenue in the Cultural Corridor which are adopted as part of this ordinance. 
 All on-street parking stalls shall be a minimum of 8 feet wide and 25 feet long. The maximum length of consecutive parking stalls shall be a total length of 75 feet and shall have a planter island located at the terminus of each parking row. Street trees shall be planted in the planter islands to allow for sufficient area to create a maximum of three parking stalls between planter islands and spaced at a maximum distance of 81 feet. 
 Where no on-street parking is proposed, the maximum required front yard for the building shall include a 2-foot transition zone, a 6-foot sidewalk area and an 8-foot parkway, for a total distance of 16 feet from the back edge of curb. Typical sections for areas where no on-street parking are proposed shall be as indicated on the typical sections of Maitland Avenue in the Cultural Corridor which are adopted as part of this ordinance. Street trees shall be planted within the 8 foot parkway and spaced at a maximum distance of 50 feet. 
 In all cases, street trees shall provide a minimum clearance of 13'4? as they overhang a street. 
 In no case shall these design requirements permit a building to be located on the right-of-way or within an easement. Should implementation of these design standards cause on-street parking, sidewalk, or parkway placement to occur on private property, right-of-way dedication or easement dedication shall be required. 
 For purposes of this section of the zoning code, back edge of curb shall be defined as: The back edge of the existing curb on Maitland Avenue, as well as existing curb on side streets in the areas affected by this zoning amendment. Should a curb not exist on a side street, then the back edge of pavement shall be utilized in the same manner as the back edge of curb. Should redevelopment of a site occur in an area where a curb does not exist, installation of a curb shall be required consistent with the streetscape design standard typical sections which are adopted as part of this ordinance. 
 Parking lots and retention ponds shall be located to the side and rear of the properties to allow for placement of the building in such locations as to define the street edge. 
(13) For lots with substandard width in RS-D1 district, air conditioning compressors and pool equipment must be a minimum of 71/2 feet from side property lines. Swimming pools must be a minimum of 8 feet from the side property lines, and pool enclosures must be a minimum of 5 feet from the side property lines. These requirements in this footnote apply only to lots with substandard lot width. 
(14) For the area defined in Ordinance No. 1086 as tracts A and B of Winfield Unit 1 according to Plat Book 34, pages 77-81 of the public records of Orange County, Florida, the side yard and street side yard requirement shall be as follows: Street side yard-25 feet. Side yard-10 feet. 10 feet for ancillary uses. Buildings in excess of one story in height within 100 feet of side or rear lot line of any single-family residential district are subject to approval through the site plan review process. 
(15) 1 bedroom D.U. = 725 sq. ft. per D.U.; 2 bedroom D.U. = 925 sq. ft. per D.U.; 3+ bedrooms = add 150 sq. ft. for each bedroom over 2 to total for 2 bedroom D.U.

The "street side yard" provision of 15 feet may be applied to future additions to the existing structure (residence) along the respective "street side yard" subject to all other city of Maitland Code requirements.

Sec. 21-7. - Districts designated. 
    The city is hereby divided into the following districts: 
(a)  RS-1, RS-1A, RS-2, RS-3, RS-4, RS-5-Single-family residential districts. 
(b)  RS-D, RS-D1-Residential single-family and duplex districts. 
(c)  UU-Undeveloped urban district. 
(d)  RG-1, RG-2, RG-3-Multiple family residential districts. 
(e)  PO-1, PO-2, PO-3-Professional office districts. 
(f)  OC, OC-1, OC-3-Office, commercial districts. 
(g)  Reserved. 
(h)  Reserved. 
(i)  PD-Planned development district (major/minor). 
(j)  CC-Cultural corridor district. 
(k)  DM-Downtown Maitland district. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 814, § 1, 8-23-93; Ord. No. 1059, § 2 4-28-03; Ord. No. 1084, § 5, 5-24-04; Ord. No. 1220, §(Exh. A, § 2), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1335, § 1(Exh. A), 8-27-18 ) 
Cross reference- Sign regulations based on zoning classifications, § 5-134 et seq. 
Sec. 21-8. - RS-1, RS-1A, RS-2, RS-3, single-family residential districts. 
(I)  Generally. These districts are intended to be single-family districts of low to medium population densities. Permitted uses are the same for all districts. Certain structures and uses are permissible as permitted conditional uses in these districts subject to restrictions and requirements intended to preserve and protect their single-family residential character. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Single-family dwelling. 
(b)  Existing citrus grove. 
(c)  Foster care homes, licensed by the HRS. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Do not involve the conduct of business on the premises; 
(3)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted to permissible principal use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; 
(4)  Are not of a nature likely to attract visitors in large number than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood; and 
(5)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of a single-family residential neighborhood. 
(b)  Noncommercial greenhouses and plant nurseries, private garages, tool houses and garden sheds, garden work counters, children's play areas and play equipment, private barbecue pits, private swimming pools, boathouses and docks, and the like. 
(c)  Guest houses. 
(d)  Child care (home), up to and including five (5) children. 
(e)  Buffer area for professional office district: Properties within the Horatio Avenue Corridor, which have direct access to Horatio Avenue, which are contiguous to properties east of US 17-92 designated as Professional Office Land Use District in the adopted Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series Map 1, and which are not within an established Quality Neighborhood Program, may be incorporated as part of a unified site plan and serve as a buffer area for the professional office district. 
(f)  Chicken-keeping. 
    The uses in (III)(e) above shall be subject to the following standards, criteria and limitations: 
(a)  A 20 foot landscape buffer shall be provided to screen the adjacent residential properties and protect the residential character of the neighborhood; 
(b)  A 10 foot required yard area shall be added to landscape buffer depth; 
(c)  Retention may be located on site if landscaped as an amenity and does not drain onto adjacent residential properties; 
(d)  Parking may be permitted on the site if items (a) through (c) above have been satisfied and all landscape areas and parking areas are consistent with Chapter 8, Landscape, Treescape, Streetscape, City of Maitland Code of Ordinances. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Storage or parking of commercial or industrial vehicles except for vehicles associated with the rendering of service to the property. 
(c)  Storage of building materials (except in connection with active construction activities on the premises). 
(d)  Mobile homes on individual lots or mobile home parks except as permitted by section 21-5(X). 
(e)  Signs, except as specifically permitted. 
(f)  Child care centers. 
(g)  Trade or service establishments or storage in connection with such establishments. 
(h)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process. 
(a)  Home occupations. 
(b)  Country or golf club, not including miniature golf course, provided lot comprises at least eighty (80) acres in one (1) parcel and that any building, accessory parking area, or structure is located at least one hundred (100) feet from any other residentially zoned property. 
(c)  Child care (home), six (6) or more children with HRS approval. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 886, § 1, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 1014, § 2, 7-23-01; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. A, § 10), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1250, § 3(A), 11-11-13 ; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-9. - UU, undeveloped urban district. 
(I)  Generally. These districts are generally characterized as areas developed or used predominantly for agricultural purposes with single-family residences as a principal use, where urban services are minimal or nonexistent, and where zoning permitting more intensive urban uses might be deemed premature. In order to promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the community without being unreasonable or arbitrary, these districts permit an orderly development which will be compatible with the goals and objectives of the city's comprehensive development plan and the general character of the city. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Single-family dwellings. 
(b)  Citrus and other fruit crops' cultivation and production. 
(c)  Truck farms. 
(d)  Mobile homes. 
(e)  Riding stables. 
(f)  Grazing and pasturing of animals, but to specifically exclude commercial-type operations and structures on the premises. 
(g)  Foster care home, licensed by HRS. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Do not involve the conduct of business on the premises; 
(3)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible principal use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; 
(4)  Are not of a nature likely to attract visitors in larger number than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood; and 
(5)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of a single-family residential neighborhood. 
(6)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of the district as it exists. 
(b)  Plant nurseries and greenhouses, excluding retail sales on the premises. 
(c)  Child care (home), up to and including five (5) children. 
(d)  Guest house. 
(e)  Tenant dwellings for year-round employees, on the basis of one (1) dwelling unit for each five (5) acres of land, providing such dwelling unit is clearly accessory to the principal use of the land. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Any new two-family and multiple-family dwellings. 
(c)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(d)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Permitted conditional uses which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process. 
(a)  Child care (home), six (6) or more children with HRS approval. 
(b)  Home occupations. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-10. - RS-4, single-family residential district. 
(I)  Generally. This district is intended to be a single-family district with allowances for professional and business office uses for properties with frontage of Maitland Avenue. Only land areas fronting arterial roads and adjacent to other areas zoned for single family use shall be zoned for this district. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Single-family dwellings. 
(b)  Professional offices with frontage on Maitland Avenue. 
(c)  Business offices with frontage on Maitland Avenue. 
(d)  Foster care homes, licensed by HRS. 
(e)  Residential scale retail: Property which has frontage on Maitland Avenue, is within the Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series, Map 1 and is also located within 1) TOD Study Area A as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, TOD Study Areas Map 1-D, or 2) is located on the east side of Maitland Avenue from Marion Way south or 3) is located on the west side of Maitland Avenue from Sandspur Road south, may have Residential scale retail. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Do not involve the conduct of business on the premises; 
(3)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted to permissible principal use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; 
(4)  Are not of a nature likely to attract visitors in large number than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood; and 
(5)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of a single-family residential neighborhood. 
(b)  Noncommercial greenhouses and plant nurseries, private garages, tool houses and garden sheds, garden work counters, children's play areas and play equipment, private barbecue pits, private swimming pools, boathouses and docks, and the like. 
(c)  Guest houses. 
(d)  Child care (home), up to and including five (5) children. 
(e)  Residential uses: Property which has frontage on Maitland Avenue, is within the Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series, Map 1 may have residential uses as accessory to office uses and where living units have a minimum of five hundred (500) square feet. 
(f)  Chicken-keeping. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Storage of building materials (except in connection with active construction activities on the premises). 
(c)  Mobile homes on individual lots or mobile home parks, except as permitted section 21-5(X). 
(d)  Signs, except as specifically permitted. 
(e)  Trade or service establishments or storage in connection with such establishments. 
(f)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(g)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process: 
(a)  Home occupations. 
(b)  Child care (home), six (6) or more children with HRS approval. 
(c)  Professional office, when property does not have frontage on Maitland Avenue. 
(d)  Business office, when property does not have frontage on Maitland Avenue. 
The uses in (II)(b) and (c) and (V)(c) and (d) above shall be subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  A landscaped bufferyard between the permitted conditional use and adjacent residential uses in other than RS-4 zoning along the entire common property line and meeting the following requirements: 
(1)  Twenty (20) feet in width. 
(2)  Per each one hundred (100) feet of linear distance of required bufferyard: 
Three (3) canopy trees (21/2-inch caliper, ten (10) feet high, minimum size upon installation) 
Ten (10) shrubs (eighteen (18) to twenty-four (24) inches high, eighteen (18) to twenty-four (24) inches wide upon installation) 
Existing trees and shrubs may be substituted for required trees and shrubs upon recommendation by the parks director that the trees and shrubs are generally healthy, expected to live at least five (5) years, and adequately meet the intent of this section, and upon approval by the planning and zoning commission. 
(3)  Eight-foot[-high] masonry wall, unless all adjacent owners of single-family property in other than RS-4 zoning agree that there is no need for the eight-foot[-high] wall. In this case, the height of the required wall may be diminished by the city as deemed necessary to provide adequate buffering while not being unnecessarily high. In any case, the wall shall be of masonry construction. 
(4)  If structures existing at the time of application for a site plan or permitted conditional use approval preclude establishment of the required bufferyard in terms of width and/or landscaping, the planning and zoning commission shall have the right to review the site plan in order to determine if landscaping and other buffering is adequate to prevent undesirable impacts on the adjacent single-family area. The city shall have the right to reject petitions that have an inadequate bufferyard width due to an existing structure and which, in the opinion of the city, do not provide adequate landscaping and buffering between adjacent single-family areas. 
(5)  If existing lots do not meet the minimum lot width requirement herein set out, the minimum lot width requirement may be met by combination of site plans with any other adjacent lot in RS-4 zoning meeting all other requirements herein and indicating the use of a single driveway for vehicular ingress/egress purposes to both lots. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the city for any combined site plan until all parking and driveway facilities are complete. 
(6)  Adequate irrigation facilities shall be installed in all landscaped areas. 
(b)  Landscaping in parking areas shall be as required in Chapter 8 of the Maitland City Code of Ordinances. 
(c)  Stormwater ponding may be provided by proper use of paving materials subject to public works approval. 
(d)  Hours of operation (including parking lot lighting and external building lights (excluding security lighting) except signs) and conduct of business involving entrance of those other than employees onto the premises shall be limited to the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(e)  No parking lot lighting shall illuminate any portion of neighboring residential lots. 
(f)  Signs shall meet the requirements of Chapter 5 of the Maitland Code of Ordinances, except that no sign shall exceed five (5) feet in height, measured from the top of the sign to the ground and shall be generally consistent with the architectural character of the building it serves. 
(g)  No odor, noise, smoke or other obnoxious effects detectable to normal human senses from outside the building. 
(h)  No electrical interferences to television or radio off the premises. 
    The city shall retain the right to impose additional restrictions to these criteria as deemed necessary to prevent these uses from having any adverse effects on surrounding properties. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 886, § 2, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. A, § 11), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1250, § 3(B), 11-11-13 ; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-10a. - RS-5, single-family residential district. 
(I)  General. This district is intended to be a single-family district of low to medium population density. Permitted uses are as described herein. Certain structures and uses are permissible as permitted conditional uses in this district subject to restrictions and requirements intended to preserve and protect the single-family residential character of this district. Areas within this district shall be limited to Winfield Unit 1 (Lots 1-110) and Winfield Unit 2 (Lots 111-224), a single-family residential subdivision, including Tracts C, D, E and G annexed into the City of Maitland effective date September 24, 1999. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Single family dwelling. 
(b)  Existing citrus grove. 
(c)  Foster care homes - Licensed by the HRS. 
III.  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Do not involve the conduct of business on the premises; 
(3)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible principal use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; 
(4)  Are not of a nature likely to attract visitors in larger number than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood; and 
(5)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of a single-family residential neighborhood. 
(b)  Noncommercial greenhouses and plant nurseries, private garages, tool houses and garden sheds, garden work counters, children's play areas and play equipment, private barbecue pits, private swimming pools and the like. 
(c)  Guest houses. 
(d)  Child care (home)-Up to and including five (5) children. 
(e)  Chicken-keeping. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure that is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Storage or parking of commercial or industrial vehicles except for vehicles associated with the rendering of service to the property. 
(c)  Storage of building materials (except in connection with active construction activities on the premises). 
(d)  Mobile homes on individual lots or mobile home parks except as permitted by section 21-5(X). 
(e)  Signs except as specifically permitted. 
(f)  Child care centers. 
(g)  Trade or service establishments or storage in connection with such establishments. 
(h)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(i)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process. 
(a)  Home occupations. 
(b)  Country or golf club, not including miniature golf course, provided lot comprises at least eighty (80) acres in one (1) parcel and that any building, accessory parking area, or structure is located at least one hundred feet (100') from any other residentially zoned property. 
(c)  Child care (home)-Six (6) or more children with HRS approval. 
(Ord. No. 1084, § 5, 5-24-04; Ord. No. 1250, § 3(C), 11-11-13 ; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-11. - RS-D, residential single-family and duplex district. 
(I)  Generally. This district is intended to be a medium density residential area permitting single-family and two-family residences and also related uses in keeping with the district. The side yard requirements noted in Matrix 1 are intended to encourage single-family dwelling units in the district. It is not the intent of the district to allow for an existing single-family structure to be converted to a duplex unit, nor for a new duplex or accessory structure to be constructed or altered, in violation of any requirements of this chapter, especially the requirement for a more restrictive side yard. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Single-family dwelling. 
(b)  Two-family dwellings. 
(c)  Existing citrus grove. 
(d)  Foster care home, licensed by HRS. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Do not involve the conduct of business on the premises; 
(3)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible principal use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; and 
(4)  Are not of a nature likely to attract visitors in larger number than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood. 
(5)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of a residential neighborhood. 
(b)  Noncommercial greenhouses and plant nurseries, private garages, tool houses and garden sheds, garden work counters, children's play areas and play equipment, private barbecue pits, private swimming pools, boathouses and docks, and the like. 
(c)  Guest houses. 
(d)  One (1) garage apartment in connection with a single-family dwelling. 
(e)  Child care (home), up to and including five (5) children. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Storage or parking of commercial or industrial vehicles except for vehicles associated with the rendering of service to the property. 
(c)  Storage of building materials (except in connection with active construction activities on the premises). 
(d)  Mobile homes on individual lots or mobile home parks except as permitted by section 21-5(X). 
(e)  Signs, except as specifically permitted. 
(f)  Trade or service establishments or storage in connection with such establishments. 
(g)  Child care center. 
(h)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(i)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process. 
(a)  Home occupations. 
(b)  Child care (home), six (6) or more children with HRS approval. 
(c)  Country or golf club, not including miniature golf course, provided lot comprises at least eight (80) acres in one (1) parcel and that any building, accessory parking area, or structure is located at least one hundred (100) feet from any other residentially zoned property.

Sec. 21-11.1. - RS-D1, residential single-family and duplex district-Special preservation. 
(I)  General. This district is intended to be a medium density residential area permitting single family and two family residences and also related uses in keeping with the district. The areas zoned in the district include smaller lots with historic homes and structures. The district is intended to encourage reinvestment and preservation of these homes, in particular the yard requirements and other design standards noted in Matrix 1. It is not the intent of the district to allow for an existing single-family structure to be converted to a duplex unit, nor for a duplex or accessory structure to be constructed or altered, in violation of any requirements of this chapter. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be:

Sec. 21-12. - RG-1, multiple-family residential district. 
(I)  Generally. This district is designed to be a low to medium density two-family and multiple-family residential area permitting up to nine (9) dwelling units per acre. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted permissible uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Two-family dwellings. 
(b)  Multiple-family dwellings. 
(c)  Foster care homes, licensed by HRS. 
(d)  Residential scale retail: Property which has frontage on Maitland Avenue, is within the Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series, Map 1 and is also located within 1) TOD Study Area A as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, TOD Study Areas Map, 1-D, or 2) is located on the east side of Maitland Avenue from Marion Way south or 3) is located on the west of Maitland Avenue from Sandspur Road south, may have Residential scale retail. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Do not involve the conduct of business on the premises (except section 21-12(III)(d); 
(3)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible principal use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; and 
(4)  Are not of a nature likely to attract visitors in larger number than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood (except section 21-12 (III)(d)); 
(5)  Are of a type that do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of a residential neighborhood. 
(b)  Noncommercial greenhouses and plant nurseries, private garages, tool houses and garden sheds, garden work counters, children's play areas and play equipment, private barbecue pits, private swimming pools, boathouses and docks, and the like. 
(c)  Child care (home), up to and including five (5) children. 
(d)  A leasing office in conjunction with a rental apartment complex all located on one parcel. 
(e)  Residential uses: Property which has frontage on Maitland Avenue, is within the Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series, Map 1 may have residential uses as accessory to office uses and where living units have a minimum of five hundred (500) square feet. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally or by reasonable implication, permitted herein. 
(b)  Storage or parking of commercial or industrial vehicles except for vehicles associated with the rendering of service to the property. 
(c)  Storage of building materials (except in connection with active construction activities on the premises). 
(d)  Mobile homes on individual lots or mobile home parks except as permitted by section 21-5(X). 
(e)  Signs, except as specifically permitted. 
(f)  Trade or service establishments or storage in connection with such establishments. 
(g)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(h)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process: 
(a)  Child care (home), six (6) or more children with HRS approval. 
(b)  Child care centers and kindergartens. 
(c)  Home occupations. 
(d)  Group dwelling or lodging house. 
(e)  Professional offices. 
(f)  Business offices. 
(g)  Dwelling unit within a professional office building for building owner or custodian. 
(h)  Group homes, licensed by HRS. 
(i)  Country or golf club, not including miniature golf course, provided lot comprises at least eighty (80) acres in one (1) parcel and that any building, accessory parking area, or structure is located at least one hundred (100) feet from any other residentially zoned property. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 886, § 4, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 1014, § 4, 7-23-01; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. A, § 12), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-13. - RG-2, RG-3 multiple-family residential districts. 
(I)  Generally. These districts are intended to permit certain areas of the City of Maitland to be used for multiple family residential units. Each district will be subject to varying dwelling unit densities and structure heights. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Multiple-family dwellings. 
(b)  Foster care homes, licensed by HRS. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Do not involve the conduct of business on the premises; 
(3)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible principal use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; and 
(4)  Are not of a nature likely to attract visitors in larger number than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood. 
(5)  Are of a type that do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of a general residential background. 
(b)  Noncommercial greenhouses and plant nurseries, private garages, tool houses and garden sheds, garden work counters, children's play areas and play equipment, private barbecue pits, private swimming pools, boathouses and docks, and the like. 
(c)  Child care (home), up to and including five (5) children. 
(d)  A leasing office in conjunction with a rental apartment complex all located on one (1) parcel. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Storage or parking of commercial or industrial vehicles except for vehicles associated with the rendering of service to the property. 
(c)  Storage of building materials (except in connection with active construction activities on the premises). 
(d)  Mobile homes on individual lots or mobile home parks except as permitted by section 21-5(X). 
(e)  Signs, except as specifically permitted. 
(f)  Trade or service establishments or storage in connection with such establishments. 
(g)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(h)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process. 
(a)  Child care (home), six (6) or more children with HRS approval. 
(b)  Child care center and kindergartens. 
(c)  Group dwelling and lodging house. 
(d)  Professional offices. 
(e)  Business offices. 
(f)  Dwelling unit within a professional office building for owner or custodian. 
(g)  Group home, licensed by HRS. 
(h)  Home occupations. 
(i)  Country or golf club, not including miniature golf course, provided lot comprises at least eighty (80) acres in one (1) parcel and that any building, accessory parking area, or structure is located at least one hundred (100) feet from any other residentially zoned property. 
(j)  Residential scale retail and/or personal service use where parcels zoned RG-3 meet the requirements set forth in Future Land Use Element, Policy 3.9.A., of the 2030 City of Maitland CDP. A mix of residential-scale retail and personal service uses within the high-density residential land use district as shown on the Future Land Use Map Series - Map 1, 2030 CDP, shall be provided for where the land use district is contiguous to a rail line and adjacent to Downtown Maitland and the development is designed to include mobility enhancements which reduce automobile trips, improve pedestrian connectivity and which provide transition to and from Downtown Maitland. Such uses shall also be limited to: 
(1)  A maximum of ten (10)percent of the upland area square footage of a project's site acreage (excluding land below the control water elevation level) may be used for residential scale retail and/or personal service use building area within a unified multi-family residential and/or office development as a permitted conditional use or through the planned development process. Residential scale retail and/or personal service uses may be stand-alone structures or be integrated into the multi-family residential and/or office structures. 
(2)  External signage and their impact on adjacent or nearby residential properties shall meet the requirements of Chapter 5 of the Maitland Code of Ordinances, except that no sign shall exceed five (5) feet in height measured from top of the sign to the ground. Architectural elements may be utilized on the face of the building to enhance building identity, but shall not include wording, and shall be neutral and non-contrasting color. Signage and architectural elements shall be generally consistent with the architectural character of the building it serves, shall be residential in scale and character, and compatible with surrounding residential properties. Such signage shall be subject to review and approval by the planning and zoning commission and the Maitland City Council. No neon, internally lit, flashing, motion (animated), changing or pole signs are permitted. 
(3)  Hours of operation for the residential-scale retail and personal service uses shall be compatible with the residential character of the neighborhood, but shall not extend beyond the hours of 7 a.m.-12 a.m. unless otherwise approved by the city. 
(4)  Performance standards shall ensure conformity and compatibility with surrounding uses and shall also include the following regulations concerning lighting, noise, vibration, odor, buffering etc.: 
a.  Lighting: Project lighting shall adhere to the lighting regulations of the City of Maitland. Lighting criteria shall include: 
1.  A photometrics plan shall be submitted at the site plan approval stage. 
2.  Use of sharp cut-off type fixtures or dark skies-type lighting shall be provided to limit spread of light in outdoor/parking areas and to minimize lighting spill over onto adjoining parcels; 
3.  Lighting on buildings shall incorporate wall-pack type fixtures that direct light to the ground. 
4.  Light placement shall incorporate CEPTD guidelines and standards to enhance safety. 
b.  Noise: The project shall be designed to adhere to the applicable noise/sound regulations of the City of Maitland. Noise control shall include but not be limited to, noise attenuation for equipment such as, shielding of A/C units and compressors; limiting non-residential truck deliveries to certain hours (7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. unless otherwise approved by the city); controlling outdoor music provided at sit-down restaurants or similar uses to conform to City of Maitland noise regulations and controlling ( hours of operation to be compatible with surrounding uses and with the residential character of the neighborhood. 
c.  Vibrations: The proposed project is to be a multi-family and/or office-use with support retail and commercial. No storage or heavy equipment use or materials handling or related activities that would create vibrations out of character with the residential portions of the project to occur on-site. 
d.  Odor: No activities shall be permitted that would create a consistent pattern of odor production that is incompatible with the residential character of the district, including the emission of pollutants and offensive fumes or gases. 
e.  Buffering: The proposed project shall, at a minimum, adhere to the City of Maitland's Landscape Code regulations including buffering between adjacent uses and properties and internal uses. 
(5)  Development on the site shall adhere to residential scale retail uses and service uses defined in section 21-23, Definitions of the Maitland City Code. Design elements of residential scale and character listed in section 21-24 shall also be followed. 
(6)  Projects within this zoning category may undergo the planned development (PD) process, and depending on the character, magnitude and location of the specific project, the city may elect to apply development standards that ensure compatibility with, and protection of existing adjoining uses. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 886, § 5, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 1014, § 5, 7-23-01; Ord. No. 1229, § 1(Exh. A), 8-13-12; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-14. - PO-1, PO-2, PO-3, professional, office districts. 
(I)  Generally. These districts are intended for professional offices and closely allied uses at the neighborhood and community levels. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. 
(a)  Research and other type laboratories not involving manufacturing and not involving odor, noise, smoke, or other obnoxious effects detectable to normal senses from off the premises nor involving electrical interference to television or radio off the premises nor involving manufacturing activities. 
(b)  Professional and business offices. 
(c)  Medical and dental clinics. 
(d)  Residential scale retail: Property which has frontage on Maitland Avenue, is within the Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series, Map 1 and is also located within 1) TOD Study Area A as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, TOD Study Areas Map, 1-D, or 2) is located on the east side of Maitland Avenue from Marion Way south or 3) is located on the west of Maitland Avenue from Sandspur Road south, may have residential scale retail. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; and 
(3)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of this district. 
(b)  Office dependent service uses where structure or unified development is over one hundred thousand (100,000) gross square feet, as long as no external signs are posted nor are they permitted to be visible exterior to the building. The gross square footage of service uses does not exceed five (5) percent of the total floor area of the structure or development, and hours of operation are limited to Monday through Friday, 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Service uses include barber or beauty shops, cafeteria, interior decorator, photographic shop, reducing salon or gymnasium, tailor, dry cleaning establishment where actual cleaning is performed elsewhere (a drop-off depot), and similar uses. 
(c)  Residential uses: Property which has frontage on Maitland Avenue, is within the Maitland Avenue Corridor Special District as shown in the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series, Map 1 may have residential uses as accessory to office uses and where living units have a minimum of five hundred (500) square feet. 
(d)  Residential uses: Property within the Professional Office Land Use Category located East of U.S. 17-92, as shown on the City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan 2030, Future Land Use Map Series, Map 1, may have residential uses as accessory to office uses, and where living units have a minimum of five hundred (500) square feet. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(c)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process. 
(a)  Banks and financial institutions, travel agencies, employment offices, and newspaper offices (but not printing establishments). 
(b)  Computer hardware services. 
(c)  Business school. 
(d)  Child care center. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. A, § 13), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-15. - OC, Office, commercial district. 
(I)  Generally. Large tracts of land are prime locations for large scale office commercial development, when easy access to major roadways with residual traffic carrying capacity is available. Only large tracts/parcels with direct access to a collector or arterial roadway and sufficient depth to meet all landscaping, buffering, parking, and on-site stormwater retention requirements should be zoned for these uses. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Motels, hotels, motor hotels. 
(b)  Restaurants, cafeterias, lounges, coffee shops, and similar eating establishments (but not drive-in restaurants). 
(c)  Professional and business offices. 
(d)  Service establishments such as barber or beauty shops, restaurants interior decorator, photographic shop, reducing salon or gymnasium, and similar establishments. 
(e)  Banks and financial institutions, travel agencies and similar establishments. 
(f)  Retail outlets for sale of wearing apparel, toys, sundries and notions, books and stationery, jewelry (including watch repair, but not pawnshops), art or antiques, office equipment, cameras or photographic supplies, florist or gift shop, similar products. Retail outlets for the sale of merchandise, including home and office furniture, sporting goods, musical instruments, television and radio (including repair incident to sales) new automobile parts and accessories, package sale of liquor, bakery, bicycles, department store, variety store, pet shop, newsstand, leather goods, or luggage store, and similar types of retail outlets. 
(g)  Theater. 
(h)  Service establishments, including laundry and dry cleaning establishment, self-service laundry, tailor or dressmaking, business school, bar or tavern for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages, and similar types of service establishments. 
(i)  Computer hardware services. 
(j)  Medical or dental clinics. 
(k)  Radio station as permitted in this section, a radio station does not have co-located main or auxiliary transmitter facilities which transmissions are intended to be received by the public. Its functions are primarily in the areas of office, marketing and programming. All promotional and remote broadcasting vehicles shall be parked behind the buildings or screened in such a manner that the vehicles are out of view from the public streets or housed and stored off-site. Any microwave antenna co-located on the site and which transmissions are not intended to be received by the public shall be considered identical to a satellite dish and shall be installed in compliance with section 21-5(XV), of the Maitland City Code. 
(l)  Mixed use buildings. 
(m)  Multiple family dwelling. 
(n)  Townhomes. 
(o)  Research uses shall include theoretical and applied research in all the sciences, product development and testing, engineering development and marketing development, provided that no such uses shall: 
(1)  Cause or result in dissemination of dust, smoke, gas or fumes, odor, noise, vibration or excessive light beyond the boundaries of the lot on which the use is conducted; menace by reason of fire, explosion, radiation or other physical hazards; harmful discharge of waste materials; or unusual traffic hazards or congestion due to type or amount of vehicles required by or attached to the use. 
(2)  Be dangerous to the comfort, peace, enjoyment, health or safety of the community or the abutting areas or tend to their disturbance or annoyance. 
(3)  Be inconsistent with the appropriate and orderly development of the city and adjacent areas. 
(p)  Light technology uses shall include manufacturing, fabricating, processing, converting, altering and assembling, and testing of products, provided that no such uses shall: 
(1)  Cause or result in dissemination of dust, smoke, gas or fumes, odor, noise, vibration or excessive light beyond the boundaries of the lot on which the, use is conducted; menace by reason of fire, explosion, radiation or other physical hazards; harmful discharge of waste materials; or unusual traffic hazards or congestion due to type or amount of vehicles required by or attached to the use. 
(2)  Be dangerous to the comfort, peace, enjoyment, health or safety of the community or the abutting areas or tend to their disturbance or annoyance. 
(3)  Be inconsistent with the appropriate and orderly development of the city and adjacent areas. 
(III)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structures which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
a.  Gift shops, souvenir shops, car rental, florist shops, and similar shops provided these users are associated with and an integral part of the motel, hotel, and/or motor hotel. 
(2)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; and 
(3)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of this district. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  New single-or, two- family dwellings. 
(c)  Manufacturing activities. 
(d)  Warehousing or storage, except in connection with a permitted or permissible use. 
(e)  Off-site advertising. 
(f)  Any use which is potentially dangerous, noxious or offensive to neighboring uses in the district or to those who pass on public ways by reason of smoke, odor, noise, glare, fumes, gas, vibration, threat of fire or explosion, emission of particulate matter, interference with radio or television reception, radiation, or likely for other reasons to be incompatible with the character of the district. 
(g)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(h)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. 
(a)  Shopping center. 
(b)  Child care center. 
(c)  Pharmacies/drugstores. Pharmacies/drugstores shall be allowed as a permitted conditional use upon application, hearing and approval as provided in Chapter 7.5, Article X of the Maitland Code of Ordinances. An application for permitted conditional use for a pharmacy/drugstore may be approved, approved with conditions, or denied. In addition to all other requirements and conditions, the application shall comply with the following standards contained herein. No permitted conditional use for a pharmacy/drugstore shall be permitted unless the application has shown evidence its ability to comply with the following use specific criteria: 
(1)  Pharmacy/drugstore shall be licensed by the State of Florida prior to operating. 
(2)  Pharmacy/drugstore shall not be located within five hundred feet (500') of the real property that comprises a public or private elementary, middle or secondary school unless approved by the city through a formal public hearing process and the city determines that the location promotes the public health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
(3)  Pharmacy/drugstore shall not be located closer than one thousand two hundred fifty feet (1,250') of the real property that comprises an actively operating pharmacy/drugstore unless approved by the city through a formal public hearing process and the city determines that the location promotes the public health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
(4)  Pharmacies/drugstores legally permitted, licensed and operating prior to September 1, 2018 shall deemed grandfathered and may expand in accordance with the applicable sections of this Code. 
(5)  If a licensed pharmacy/drugstore approved through the permitted conditional use process is discontinued or abandoned for one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days (except when government action impedes access to the premises), the use shall not be reestablished unless a new permitted conditional use application is approved by the city as outlined in Chapter 7.5, Article X of the Maitland Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 803, § 1, 1-25-93; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. A, § 3), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-16. - OC-1, office commercial district-1.

(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures. Permitted principal uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Automobile service stations. 
(b)  Service establishments such as laundry or dry cleaning pick up station or similar establishments requiring only short term parking. 
(III)  Application regulations. Regulations outlined in section 21-5(XI) shall apply to this district. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(c)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be permitted through the permitted conditional use process:

In addition to all other requirements and conditions, the application shall comply with the following standards contained herein. Pharmacy/drugstore shall not be located within five hundred feet (500') of the real property that comprises a public or private elementary, middle or secondary school unless approved by the city through a formal public hearing process and the city determines that the location promotes the public health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
3.  Pharmacy/drugstore shall not be located closer than one thousand two hundred fifty feet (1,250') of the real property that comprises an actively operating pharmacy/drugstore unless approved by the city through a formal public hearing process and the city determines that the location promotes the public health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
4.  Pharmacies/drugstores legally permitted, licensed and operating prior to September 1, 2018 shall deemed grandfathered and may expand in accordance with the applicable sections of this Code.

Sec. 21-19a. - Cultural corridor district (CC). 
(I)  General purpose and intent. The cultural corridor district is established to implement the city's comprehensive plan, which establishes the boundaries for the cultural corridor as a special district on the future land use map. The district is intended to encourage a reasonable mix of cultural and ancillary uses, with uniform design guidelines, provided existing residential areas are preserved. The regulations outlined in this district will attempt to encourage an appropriate mixture of cultural/art, historical, municipal, commercial, office, recreational and residential uses within the corridor boundaries. Emphasis in this area is placed on the compatibility of the uses and uniformity of site development, regulated by vegetated landscape buffers, enhanced pedestrian features, sign regulations and design standards for curb cuts, as well as consistency with other city regulations governing development. Any change of use or any structural changes resulting in a net increase in square footage will be required to submit an application for site plan review subject to a planning and zoning commission decision, consistent with Chapter 7.5, Article X. 
(II)  Permitted principal uses and structures: 
(a)  Neighborhood or mini-parks. 
(b)  Bird sanctuary. 
(c)  Educational institutions, public or private. The location of any such institution after the effective date Ord. No. 1092 shall not preclude the ability of establishments selling liquor, as defined in the Florida Statutes, for on-premise consumption, from locating within one thousand (1,000) feet of an educational institution, public or private, subject to all other City Code requirements. 
(d)  Art gallery, library, museum and other similar cultural facilities. 
(e)  Local government facility. 
(f)  Places of worship, religious institutions. The location of any such institution after the effective date of Ord. No. 1092 shall not preclude the ability of establishments selling liquor, as defined in the Florida Statutes, for on-premise consumption, from locating within one thousand (1,000) feet of a place of worship or religious institution, subject to all other City Code requirements. 
(g)  Community center. 
(h)  Parking lot and transit uses. 
(i)  Performance and film theaters. 
(j)  Arts and crafts studios and shops and performing art studios. 
In addition to (a) through (j) above, property which does not abut a residential land use district, has no frontage on Maitland Avenue, and which is within five hundred (500) feet of Maitland Avenue, may have the following: 
(k)  Professional and business offices including medical and dental clinics. 
In addition to (a) through (k) above, property which does not abut a residential land use district and which has frontage on Maitland Avenue, may have the following: 
(l)  Coffee shops, ice cream shops, delicatessens, and similar eating establishments (but not drive-in establishments). 
(m)  Retail establishments (cultural support facilities) for wearing apparel and accessories, toys, sundries and notions, books and stationery, coins, stamps, jewelry (including watch repair but not pawnshops), art or antiques, cameras or photographic supplies, musical instruments, florist or gift shop, art and craft supplies, and similar products. 
(n)  Interior decorator or interior design studio (including sale of related products incidental to design). 
(o)  Travel agencies and financial institutions. 
(Procedures and uses for the cultural corridor zoning district supersede any other procedures or uses outlined in this Code, including those specified in section 21-20, Floating Zones, Public/Semi-Public uses.) 
The above uses are subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  Sale, preparation, and storage shall be conducted within a completely enclosed building with allowances for the consumption of food and beverage items and minimal display of merchandise outside of the building; provided that such activity does not encroach public right-of-way. No more than twenty-five (25) percent of the enclosed floor space shall be devoted to storage. 
(b)  Products shall be sold only at retail. 
(c)  Each allowable eating establishment shall be limited to two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet in size. 
(III)  Minimum design guidelines. The uses established in this section are required to meet the following minimum design guidelines: 
(a)  In addition to and above the requirements of the sign regulations, no ground mounted or pole mounted sign shall exceed five (5) feet in height, measured from the top of the sign to the ground, or twenty-five (25) square feet in total area and shall be generally consistent with the architectural character of the building it serves. No neon or internally lit signs are permitted. Total sign area for each site shall not exceed one (1) square foot for every linear foot of building facing the street. All measurements for sign area shall be made from the outside perimeter of the sign structure. 
(b)  Sidewalks (both right-of-way and internal) and street trees shall be installed to be consistent with streetscape plan adopted in the Cultural Corridor Master Plan. 
(c)  Lighting shall be installed so as not to create a glare on adjacent properties or streets and shall not exceed twenty (20) feet in height. In addition, adequate pedestrian lighting shall be provided for all internal pedestrian areas and all lighting, including any ground-mounted lighting, and shall be uniform in style with the adopted lighting in the Cultural Corridor Master Plan. 
(d)  Parking requirements for the cultural corridor zoning district. 
  The parking requirements outlined in section 21-22 of the City Code can be reduced up to twenty (20) percent when: a) shared parking is established with another facility within five hundred (500) feet and where pedestrian access is provided; or, b) when a donor city parking facility is within five hundred (500) feet with pedestrian access. 
  Parking requirements outlined in section 21-22 of the City Code may be reduced by up to thirteen (13) percent for office use facilities that establish retail/cultural service uses. 
  Parking requirements outlined in section 21-22 of the City Code can be reduced up to twenty (20) percent for bank properties converting to office or retail/cultural service uses. 
  Up to ten (10) percent reduction in parking requirements as outlined in section 21-22 of the City Code may be granted for office and bank uses dedicating pedestrian easements consistent with the master plan. 
  To help ensure that properties are brought up to design standards parking requirements may be allowed to be reduced by thirteen (13) to twenty (20) percent from the requirements established in section 21-22 of the City Code when a property owner makes the necessary site improvements to meet site design standards such as landscaping and streetscape improvements and to eliminate all nonconforming parking spaces and a sufficient public donor site is available to accommodate peak overflow periods. The percentage range provides flexibility based on the proximity and size of donor parking facility, and specific site conditions and property uses. In order to qualify for any parking reduction all site design standards must be met. 
(e)  All applicable standards and regulations shall be met. 
(IV)  Permitted accessory uses and structures. Permitted accessory uses and structures shall be uses and structures which: 
(a)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures. 
(b)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership. 
(c)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of this district. 
(d)  Residential uses above the first floor on or first floors where gross square footage of residential use does not exceed twenty (20) percent of the gross floor area on site; and where living units have a minimum of five hundred (500) square feet. 
(V)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Warehousing or storage, except in connection with a permitted or permissible use. 
(c)  Off-site advertising. 
(d)  Any use which is potentially dangerous, noxious, or offensive outside the property lines by reason of odor, smoke, noise, glare, fumes, gas, vibration, threat of fire or explosion, emission of particulate matter, interference with radio or television reception, radiation or likely for other reasons to be incompatible with the character of the district. 
(e)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(f)  Cannabis farm. 
(VI)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures permitted if approved through the permitted conditional use process shall be: 
    None. 
(Ord. No. 814, § 3, 8-23-93; Ord. No. 887, §§ 1, 2, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 898, § 1, 6-10-96; Ord. No. 1092, § 1, 8-9-04; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. A, § 9), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-19b. - Downtown Maitland Zoning District (DMZD). 
(I)  Generally . The purpose of this district is to support the Downtown Maitland Future Land Use Map Designation as adopted in the city comprehensive development plan and to permit a concentrated mix of uses including government, office, commercial, and multi-family residential activities. 
(II)  Applicability . 
(a)  In addition to the specific standards provided herein, development and redevelopment within the Downtown Maitland Zoning District shall also be regulated by the applicable portions of sections 21-5, 21-6, 21-23, and 23-2. Where any provision of section 21-19b, and any other section of this Code regulating the Downtown Maitland Zoning District, are in conflict with any standards, regulations, or processes of the Downtown Maitland Master Plan adopted by Ordinance 939 in October 1997, as may be amended from time to time, the regulations, standards and processes governing the Downtown Maitland Zoning District contained herein and elsewhere in this Code, shall prevail. 
(b)  Waivers requested from section 21-6 (schedule of district regulations adopted) and section 21-19b.1. (Matrix 2 Downtown Maitland District Regulations) are subject to review processes noted under section 23-2.2 (Flexibility in design standards application (design waivers)). 
(c)  For properties zoned planned development (PD) that are located within the Downtown Maitland Land Use District and the DMSD, when amendments to approved planned developments are requested, the Downtown Maitland District Regulations and Design Standards maybe applicable if the district regulations and design standards are consistent with the PD regulations of section 21-21 and the definition of planned development in section 21-23. Application of these elements shall be subject to the percentage of modification listed within section 23-2.1(b). 
(d)  Nothing in this chapter prevents applicants from requesting a rezoning to planned development. During the planned development review process, the downtown Maitland district regulations and design standards may be applicable if the district regulations and design standards are consistent with the PD regulations of section 21-21 and the definition of planned development in section 21-23. 
(III)  Permitted principal uses and structures; permitted accessory uses and structures; prohibited uses and structures; and permitted conditional uses . 
(a)  Table 21-19b.1. (DMZD Use Table) lists the permitted, accessory, conditional and prohibited uses and structures within the Downtown Maitland Zoning District. Within "Downtown Maitland," drive-through establishments, shall only be allowed as conditional uses approved consistent with section 21-5 (XVI). 
(b)  The DMZD Use Table supersedes the standards, provisions, and requirements of section 21-20 Floating Zone, public/semi-public uses for properties zoned DMZD. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 1), 5-14-12)

*** Development projects for multi-family dwellings (apartments, condominiums, and townhomes); mixed use projects with ground floor residential uses; and projects including live/work unit(s) as defined in section 21-21(III)(h)(2); may be permitted in Downtown Maitland via rezoning to planned development subject to approval by the city council pursuant to section 21-21 and Chapter 7.5, Article VII, Planned Development, of the Maitland City Code.
