**** Pharmacy/drugstore uses may be permitted through the conditional use permit process, as indicated above. In addition to all other requirements and conditions, the application shall comply with the following standards contained herein. No conditional use for a pharmacy/drugstore may be permitted unless the application has shown evidence its ability to comply with the use specific criteria as outlined below: 
1.  Pharmacy/drugstore shall be licensed by the State of Florida prior to operating. 
2.  Pharmacy/drugstore shall not be located within five hundred (500) feet of the real property that comprises a public or private elementary, middle or secondary school unless approved by the city through a formal public hearing process and the city determines that the location promotes the public health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
3.  Pharmacy/drugstore shall not be located closer than one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) feet of the real property that comprises an actively operating pharmacy/drugstore unless approved by the city through a formal public hearing process and the city determines that the location promotes the public health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
4.  Pharmacies/drugstores legally permitted, licensed and operating prior to September 1, 2018 shall deemed grandfathered and may expand in accordance with the applicable sections of this Code. 
5.  If a licensed pharmacy/drugstore approved through the permitted conditional use process is discontinued or abandoned for one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days (except when government action impedes access to the premises), the use shall not be reestablished unless a new permitted conditional use application is approved by the city as outlined in Chapter 7.5, Article X of the Maitland Code of Ordinances. 
Notes: 
Other accessory uses . Accessory uses and structures other than those listed above may be permitted subject to the following: 
(a)  The use is customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to the permitted or permissible use and structures. 
(b)  The use is located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership. 
(c)  Does not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of this district. 
Other prohibited uses and structures. Other prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. Any use which is potentially dangerous, noxious, or offensive outside the property lines by reason of odor, smoke, noise, glare, fumes, gas, vibration, threat of fire or explosion, emission of particulate matter, interference with radio or television reception, and radiation. 
(b)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(c)  Cannabis farm. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 1), 5-14-12; Ord. No. 1228, § 1(Exh. A, § 1), 5-14-12; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1305, § 2, 4-11-16 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-20. - Floating zone, public/semipublic uses. 
(I)  Generally. This zone is intended to implement the location and design requirements established by the comprehensive development plan for public and semipublic uses. Where infrastructure and traffic levels of service are adequate and where the use is compatible with surrounding uses, then public or semipublic uses may be constructed according to design standards consistent with the city's comprehensive plan and regulations, and consistent with any special criteria established to ensure compatibility with surrounding areas. Unlike other zones, the uses are considered according to land use districts in the future land use map. 
(II)  Permitted principal use and structures. 
(a)  Residential land use districts. 
(1)  Neighborhood or mini-parks. 
(2)  Educational institutions, public or private, which have a gross square footage no greater than the minimum living area specifications according to the zoning district in which they are located (where access is only to a local street or greater, light does not spill over into residential areas, and the property is not within one thousand (1,000) feet of any established use for the sale of liquor, as defined in the Florida Statutes for on-premises consumption of liquor). 
(3)  Educational institutions, public or private (where access is only to collector street or greater, light does not spill over into residential areas, and the property is not within one thousand (1,000) feet of any established use for the sale of liquor, as defined in the Florida Statutes for on-premises consumption of liquor). The distance separation provisions of this section shall not apply to uses within, nor when measured from applicable uses in, the Downtown Maitland area as referenced on the Future Land Use Map Series-Map 1 of the 2001-2020 City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan as may be amended from time to time. 
(4)  Utilities, power substations, and similar uses. 
(b)  Nonresidential land use districts. 
(1)  Everything allowed in (II)(a), above. 
(2)  Art gallery, library, museum and other similar cultural facilities. 
(3)  Local government facility. 
    For permitted principal uses, the site plan review process is required with final approval by the planning and zoning commission. 
(III)  Permitted accessory use and structures. Permitted accessory use and structures shall be: 
(a)  Uses and structure which: 
(1)  Are customarily accessory and clearly incidental and subordinate to permitted or permissible uses and structures; 
(2)  Are located on the same lot as the permitted or permissible use or structure, or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership; and 
(3)  Do not involve operations or structures not in keeping with the character of this district. 
(IV)  Prohibited uses and structures. Prohibited uses and structures shall be: 
(a)  Any use or structure which is not specifically, provisionally, or by reasonable implication permitted herein. 
(b)  Non-medical marijuana sales. 
(c)  Cannabis farm. 
(V)  Permitted conditional uses. Uses and structures which may be allowed through the permitted conditional use process. 
(a)  Residential land use districts. 
(1)  Community park. 
(2)  Places of worship, religious institutions where only access is through a collector road or greater classification roadway and the use is not within one thousand (1,000) feet of any established use for the sale of liquor, as defined in the Florida Statutes for on-premise consumption of liquor. The distance separation provisions of this section shall not apply to uses within, nor when measured from applicable uses in, the Downtown Maitland area as referenced on the Future Land Use Map Series-Map 1 of the 2001-2020 City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan as may be amended from time to time. 
Where access is through a local street, then the lot area for the entire development shall not exceed two hundred (200) percent of the minimum lot area for the respective zoning district. 
(3)  Nursing home, ACLF, extended care facility (where density is consistent with zoning district). 
(4)  Bird sanctuary. 
(5)  Grief counseling center, where the only access is through collector roads or greater classification roadway and the minimum lot size is eight-tenths (0.8) acres. Such center shall meet landscape buffer requirements, which may be increased at the sole discretion of the city, to adequately buffer adjacent residential properties. Buffers shall include a masonry wall compatible with the character of the adjacent residential property (a minimum of six foot height) adjacent to residential property. Architectural site plan and elevations, together with photographs of adjacent residential uses, shall be included for review of the city during the permitted conditional use application review process. 
Signage shall meet requirements of Chapter 5 of the Maitland Code of ordinances, except that no sign shall exceed five (5) feet in height, measured from top of the sign to the ground. Architectural elements may be utilized on the face of the building to enhance building identity, but shall not include wording, and shall be a neutral and non-contrasting color. Signage and architectural elements shall be generally consistent with the architectural character of the building it serves, shall be residential scale and character, compatible with surrounding residential properties and are subject to review and approval by the planning and zoning commission and Maitland City Council. No neon, internally lit, flashing, motion (animated), changing, or pole signs are permitted. 
(b)  Nonresidential land use districts. 
(1)  Community park. 
(2)  Places of worship, religious institutions, not within one thousand (1,000) feet of any established use for the sale of liquor, as defined in the Florida Statutes for on-premise consumption of liquor. The distance separation provisions of this section shall not apply to uses within, nor when measured from applicable uses in, the Downtown Maitland area as referenced on the Future Land Use Map Series-Map 1 of the 2001-2020 City of Maitland Comprehensive Development Plan as may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  Nursing home, ACLF, extended care facility. 
(4)  Cemeteries, memorial gardens, crematoria. 
(5)  Community center. 
(6)  County, state or federal facility. 
(7)  Hospital. 
(8)  Institutional care facility. 
(9)  Parking lot, bus terminal and similar transit uses. 
(10)  College, university. 
(VI)  Design criteria. 
(a)  Minimum lot area and lot width shall conform to the most stringent zoning district in which the proposed use is being developed or which it abuts. 
(b)  Front, side and rear yards shall conform to the requirements of the most stringent zoning district (for each) which the proposed use is being developed or abuts. 
(c)  Maximum lot coverage, permeable surface, height and story requirements shall be consistent with the requirements of the applicable zoning district. 
(d)  All standards established by the comprehensive plan shall apply and be met by any proposed development. The planned development process shall be required if the proposed development is greater than one-half (1/2) acre in size and requests waiver of any service or design standards. 
(e)  Where state agency design criteria are more stringent than the city requirement then these criteria may be required. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 1094, §§ 2-4, 9-13-04; Ord. No. 1142, § 1, 12-11-06; Ord. No. 1265, § 1, 11-10-14 ; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 8-27-18 ) 
Sec. 21-21. - PD, planned development district. 
I.  Generally. It is the purpose of this district to permit planned developments which are intended: 
(a)  To encourage the development of land as planned communities and developments providing a variety of complementary and compatible residential, commercial, and industrial use or combination of uses. 
(b)  To allow diversification of uses, structures, and open spaces in a manner compatible with existing and permitted land use on abutting properties. 
(c)  To encourage flexible and creative concepts of site planning. 
(d)  To provide for an efficient use of land resulting in smaller networks of utilities and streets thereby lowering development and housing costs. 
(e)  To permit more effective adaptation of development to the natural soils, vegetation and topography of an area. 
(f)  To preserve the natural amenities and environmental assets of the land by encouraging the preservation and improvement of scenic and functional open areas. 
(g)  To encourage an increase in the amount and useability of open space areas by permitting a more economical and concentrated use of building areas than would be possible through conventional subdivision practices. 
(h)  To insure that development will occur according to limitations of use, design, density, coverage, and phasing stipulated on an approved final development plan. 
(i)  To encourage large scale, multiple-use planned developments which can aid the city in controlling the tempo and sequence of growth by maintaining a balance of land uses in conjunction with the growth of municipal facilities and services needed to serve the new population. 
(j)  To encourage economic viability within the Packwood District of Downtown Maitland as the focal point of the Downtown revitalization area, including the City's Town Center. The district is located generally from Lake Lily Park north to Sybelia Avenue and is intended to create a pedestrian-oriented mix of public and private spaces, the combination of which will promote walkability and activation of the retail core area of the city's downtown. 
(k)  To revitalize the areas within the Sawmill and Waterhouse Districts of Downtown Maitland as these districts serve as the northern and southern entries to Downtown Maitland and are intended to achieve the vision of an architecturally pleasing corridor with a mix of uses and safe, walkable pedestrian access. 
(II)  Permitted uses. Each land use shall be complementary to and compatible with the project concept or theme for the total planned development district. 
(a)  Residential units, including single-family attached and detached dwellings, tow-family dwellings, and multiple-family dwellings. 
(b)  Churches, schools, community or club buildings, and similar public and semipublic facilities. 
(c)  Nonresidential uses, including commercial or retail uses, industrial uses, offices, clinics, and professional uses provided the following criteria are met: 
(1)  The location is in appropriate relation to other land uses. 
(2)  The proposed uses are compatible with the goals and objectives of the city's comprehensive development plan. 
(III)  Development standards for planned development. The development standards for planned development are as follows: 
(a)  Relation to zoning districts. An approved PD shall be considered to be a separate zoning district in which a final development plan approved for each phase establishes the restrictions, regulations, and district description according to which the development shall occur. Upon approval of the preliminary development plan, the official zoning map shall be changed to indicate the area as PD. Each final development plan as approved by the city council shall be filed and maintained within the community development department with a copy to the building official. 
(b)  Density/intensity. The density/intensity based on gross residential/commercial acreage permitted in each PD development shall be established by the city council upon recommendation of the planning and zoning commission. The criteria for establishing the appropriate density/intensity includes existing surrounding density/intensity, density/intensity permitted by the existing zoning classification, adequacy of existing and proposed public facilities and services, conformance with the adopted city comprehensive plan, and site characteristics, but in no case shall it exceed the maximum density/intensity of the most dense/intense zoning district in the appropriate land use district. 
(c)  Dimensional, bulk and height restrictions. The location of all proposed building sites shall be as shown on the final section plat or site plan subject to the minimum lot sizes, setback lines, lot coverage, and minimum floor areas as specified in the final development plan as approved by the city council. Buildings or structures shall not exceed the floor area ratio established in the CDP. 
(d)  Access and parking. All streets, and access ways shall be designed to effectively relate to the major transportation plan as shown in the comprehensive development plan of the city. Off-street parking shall be provided for each land use as established by the off-street parking regulations of the Maitland Code of Ordinances and shall meet landscaping requirements as specified in the landscape ordinance for off street parking and other vehicular use areas established in the Maitland Code of Ordinances. Vehicular access from individual lots or dwelling units onto public arterial or collector streets within or adjacent to the development is prohibited. 
(e)  Perimeter requirements. The city council, following a recommendation of the planning and zoning commission, may impose one (1) or both of the following requirements in order to protect the privacy of existing adjoining uses: 
(1)  Structures, parking lots, buildings and streets located at the perimeter of the development shall be permanently screened in a manner which sufficiently protects the privacy and amenities of the adjacent existing uses. 
(2)  Wide setbacks from the perimeter line may be imposed to protect privacy of adjacent existing uses. 
(f)  Stormwater drainage systems. Provisions shall be made for one-hundred-percent on-site drainage retention/detention and special disposition of stormwater drainage when such drainage could substantially harm a natural body of water. Approval of self-contained stormwater drainage systems shall adhere to the procedures outlined in the Maitland Code of Ordinances. 
(g)  Maitland West Side Design Standards. Any exceptions to the Maitland West Side Design Standards, including block configurations, access standards, pedestrian connection requirements and lot layout requirements shall be made through the exception process described in section 7.5-81. 
(h)  Sawmill, Packwood and Waterhouse Districts within Downtown Maitland. 
(1)  Consideration of petitions for PD zoning development projects including, ground floor residential development within the Sawmill, Packwood and Waterhouse Districts, shall be subject to additional criteria provided in the Maitland City Code, Chapter 7.5, Article VII, Planned Development, and section 21-19(b), and section 23-2, Downtown Maitland Special District. The location of ground-floor residential uses within each district will be evaluated based upon compatibility with surrounding uses, character of the surrounding areas, street type, road visibility, street frontage, access, and the purpose and intent of each district. 
(2)  A "live/work unit" is a single unit, that is part of a PD zoning development project within these districts, that consists of both a commercial/office component and residential component occupied by the same resident. A live/work unit shall be considered a residential use only. No live/work unit, or any portion of a live/work unit, shall be considered a commercial use in whole or in part. However, the commercial/office component of the live/work unit shall be restricted to uses consistent with those specified within the DMZD zoning district. The live/work unit shall be evaluated consistent with the criteria noted in (h)(1) above. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. A, § 5), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1305, § 3, 4-11-16 ) 
Sec. 21-22. - Off-street parking and loading. 
    It is the intent of this zoning code that the public interest, welfare, and safety requires that every building and use erected or instituted after the effective date of this zoning code shall be provided with adequate off-street parking facilities for the use of occupants, employees, visitors, customers, or patrons. It is also the intent of this zoning code that the public interest, welfare, and safety require that certain uses provide adequate off-street loading facilities. Such off-street parking and off-street loading facilities shall be maintained and continued so long as the main use continues. 
(1)  Generally. Off-street parking facilities shall be provided as set out herein. Required off-street parking areas for three (3) or more automobiles shall have individual spaces marked, and shall be so designed, maintained and regulated that no parking or maneuvering incidental to parking shall be on any public street, walk or alley, and so that any automobile may be parked and unparked without moving another. Building existing as of the effective date of this zoning code may be modernized, altered, or repaired without providing additional off-street parking or off-street loading facilities, providing there is no increase in floor area, volume, capacity or space occupied. Where a building or use existed as of the effective date of this zoning code and such building or use is enlarged in floor area, volume, capacity, or space occupied, off-street parking and off-street loading as herein specified shall be provided for the additional floor area, volume, capacity, or space so created or used. 
Change in use of a building or use existing as of the effective date of this zoning code shall require additional off-street parking and off-street loading facilities to the extent that requirements for such facilities exceed the off-street parking and off-street loading requirements which would have been required for the previous use had the regulations of this zoning code been applicable thereto. 
The required off-street parking facilities shall be: 
(a)  Identified as to purpose and location when not clearly evident. 
(b)  Unless otherwise requested by the applicant and approved by the city manager, surfaced with asphalt, bituminous, or concrete material and maintained in a smooth, well-grade condition. Single-family and two-family residences are exempt from this requirement. Driveways, access aisles, and parking spaces for public and private schools offering academic courses and for churches may be surfaced with grass or lawn. 
(c)  Drained so as not to cause any nuisance on adjacent property. 
(d)  So lighted (if required or desired) as to prevent glare or excessive light on adjacent property. 
(e)  Arranged for convenient access and to minimize hazard to the safety of pedestrians and vehicles. For this purpose, the parking shall conform to the minimum standards as noted in the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Transportation and Traffic Engineering Handbook, Second Edition or as may be amended from time to time. All parking shall be a standard size (nine (9) feet wide by eighteen (18) feet long with twenty-four (24) foot aisle widths, is acceptable if ninety (90) degree stalls are proposed). Up to fifteen (15) percent of the spaces required by city regulations may be designed for compact vehicles (minimum eight (8) feet wide by sixteen (16) feet long) if designated appropriately on site. 
(f)  Off-street parking for individual uses shall either be consistent with the following off-street parking requirements or an applicant may prepare and submit an alternative parking study using professionally accepted methods for review and approval by the development review committee:
