Sec. 23-1.5.2. - Building placement. 
    The following requirements are for non-residential and attached residential buildings. Buildings shall orient the primary facade towards the street. This includes the main entrances and windows to face the street. 
(a)  Building frontages located on a "main" street or "primary" streets shall occupy no less than fifty (50) percent of a buildings street frontage entrance. Up to one-third ( 1/3 ) of the required percentage may consist of arcades or frontage walls. The frontage wall shall be a minimum height of eighteen (18) inches with a maximum height of twenty-four (24) inches and a minimum width of eight (8)-twelve (12) inches. The wall shall be constructed of stone, brick, wrought iron, or stucco. If the knee wall is constructed with wrought iron, the minimum width standards shall not apply. The material shall complement the primary building's architecture. 

(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.5.3. - Open space. 
    Open space requirements may be met by existing landscape that meets the city's landscape standards, pedestrian connections, additional public space, and enhanced storm water facilities as amenities. See definition of "open space, Wekiva Area" [section 21-23]. 
Sec. 23-1.5.4. - Public space. 
    Any development greater than four (4) acres in size shall provide five (5) percent of the total building square footage area for public space. The public space can be restricted to the building providing the public space and is not required to be open to the general public. The public space requirements -shall be met by providing any of the following: 
(a)  Green. A space available for unstructured recreation. A green is landscaped with lawns and trees, including existing or natural vegetation and paths and trails. 
(b)  Square. An area that includes paved walks, lawns, trees, and ornamental structures such as fountains and gazebos. 
(c)  Outdoor seating. An area with tables and chairs, potentially covered umbrella seating. This area can also function as an outdoor cafe that is open to the public for eating and/or drinking. 
(d)  Courtyards. An area that may have landscape, hardscape, and/or fountains which provide a seated area. 
(e)  Community garden, garden plots. An area available to residents for small scale cultivation. 
(f)  Plaza. A space at the intersection of streets devoted to civic purposes and temporary commercial activities, such as craft shows, farmers markets, etc. 

(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.5.5. - Stormwater. 
    Additional design standards. For stormwater facilities to be permitted to count toward the minimum open space requirements of these regulations, stormwater facilities shall be required to meet the following minimum design standards: 

(a)  Stormwater facilities (ponds and/or depressions) shall be designed and utilized as site amenities along entrances and street frontages or incorporated with buffers between incompatible uses. 
(b)  Stormwater facilities should be designed and permitted so as not to require fencing. If fencing is required, a green or black vinyl/painted finish is required. Walls or other railings for structured stormwater 'boxes' must be decorative. Max. Fence Height: four (4) ft.. 
(c)  Subject to the requirements of St. Johns River Management District, other governmental agencies, and a consideration of safety related issues. Stormwater facilities that are located in the front of a property shall be prohibited from having fencing unless it can be demonstrated to be necessary due to the configuration and topography of the lot. The determination of necessity in this circumstance shall be made by the city council as a part of the evaluation of a design waiver to the Maitland West Side Design Standards. 
(d)  Wet stormwater detention/retention facilities adjoining public streets shall include a water feature such as a fountain or spray jet, and shall be planted with appropriate aquatic materials as specified in Table 23-1.5.5.1 Approved Aquatic Plant Materials List. Detention/Retention along the front of a property shall be designed with curvilinear edges - not as a straight "box." Retention embankments shall be planted with one (1) tree per fifty (50) linear feet of retention perimeter measured from top of slope. Trees shall be suitable for wet locations as identified in Table 23-1.5.5.1 Approved Aquatic Plant Materials List. 
(e)  Dry retention areas shall be planted with grass, and unless maintained as an open lawn swale, shall be screened from view with a continuous hedge of shrubs on thirty-six-inch centers around at least seventy-five (75) percent of the perimeter at the top of the slope. 
(f)  Dry retention areas may also be constructed as a multi-use facility if utilizing low impact design standards. The applicant must identify the methods being used to be considered acceptable for obtaining open space credit for the dry retention design.

Sec. 23-1.5.6. - Pedestrian connections. 
    If a property is eligible to develop a portion of a trail system, bikeway system that are linked to additional parcels and development, of the trail or bikeway may count towards the open space requirement. The standards for this are located in the pedestrian connectivity section of section 23-1. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.6. - General building design standards. 
    The following standards apply to all buildings that are located within the Maitland West Side development area. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.6.1. - Screening requirements. 
(a)  Loading docks truck parking, outdoor storage, HVAC equipment, trash dumpsters, trash compactors, and other service functions shall not be visible from any street or sidewalk or adjacent residential area. These facilities may be incorporated into the overall design of the principal building using screening walls of compatible material, style, color, texture, pattern, trim and details whether these service functions are attached or detached from the principal building. 
(b)  The screening wall shall be one foot higher than the largest object being screened, but not more than eight feet high, on all sides where access is not needed. An opaque gate, with the same height as the wall, shall be included where access is needed. 
(c)  Mechanical equipment at ground level shall be placed away from view from any streets, sidewalks and residential areas. The mechanical equipment shall be screened from view by fencing, vegetation, or parapet walls (if located on a roof) using the same materials as the principal building, i.e., stone, brick or stucco. The screening shall be at least equal to the width and height of the equipment to be screened from view. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 

Sec. 23-1.6.2. - Building façade. 
    New buildings shall provide a foundation or base, typically from ground to bottom of the lower windowsills, with changes in volume or material. A clear visual division shall be maintained between the ground level floor and upper floors with either a cornice line or awning from twelve (12) feet to sixteen (16) feet above base floor elevation or grade, whichever applies to the proposed development. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.6.3. - Building features. 
    All new buildings shall utilize at least three of the following design features to provide visual relief along all elevations of the building: 
(a)  Divisions or breaks in materials or textures (materials should be drawn from a common palette). 
(b)  Window bays. 
(c)  Separate entrances and entry treatments, porticoes extending at least five (5) feet. 
(d)  Variation in roof lines. 
(e)  Awnings installed in increments of fifteen (15) feet or less. 
(f)  Dormers. 
(g)  Canopies, extending at least five (5) feet. 
(h)  Overhang extending at least five (5) feet. 
(i)  Recessed entries (at least three (3) feet from the primary facade). 
(j)  Protruding entries (at least three (3) feet from the primary facade). 
(k)  Covered porch entries. 

(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.6.4. - Public entrance. 
    New buildings that are open to the public shall have an entrance for pedestrians from the street to the building interior. This entrance shall be designed to be a distinctive and prominent element of the architectural design, and shall be open to the public during business hours. Buildings shall incorporate lighting and changes in mass, surface or finish which places an emphasis to the entrance. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.6.5. - Parking structure. 
    The following urban standards shall apply to parking structures: 
(a)  The entrances to structured parking should be from "secondary" streets only. 
(b)  Direct pedestrian access from parking garages to any adjacent street shall be provided. 
(c)  The exterior facades of all parking garages fronting on any street shall be designed to achieve an architectural unity with the block. 
(d)  Parking garages shall comply with all building design standards for building facade, scale, building features and lighting, compatibility, and placement on the site. 
(e)  The city may approve other design alternatives, such as liner buildings around the outer edge of the garage. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-1.6.6. - Additional Main Street standards. 
    The Main Street designated area in Maitland West Side, as defined in section 23-1.4.2, Network Pattern, should provide the following design elements: Storefront character and building orientation. 
(I)  Storefront character. New buildings shall be designed to create a storefront character. Storefront character shall be met by providing all of the following architectural features, along the street building frontage as applicable. 
(a)  Corner building entrances on corner lots. 
(b)  Regularly spaced and similar-shaped windows with window hoods or trim (all building stories). 
(c)  Large display windows on the ground floor. Facades of all buildings facing streets, parks and plazas shall have windows covering a minimum of forty (40) percent and a maximum eighty (80) percent of the surface area of the ground floor of each storefront's linear frontage. Blank walls shall not occupy over fifty (50) percent of a street-facing frontage and shall not exceed thirty (30) ft. without being interrupted by a window or entry. Mirrored glass, obscured glass and glass block cannot be used in meeting this requirement. 
(d)  The bottom edge of display windows on the ground floor facades shall be no more than thirty (30) inches above finished floor level. 
(II)  Building orientation. The primary building entrances shall be visible and directly accessible from a street. Building massing such as tower elements shall be used to call-out the location of building entries. 

(III)  Mass and scale. New building shall be constructed such that no more than sixty (60) ft. of horizontal distance of wall shall be constructed without architectural relief a minimum of thirty (30) ft. wide and three (3) ft. deep for building walls and frontage walls facing the street for nonresidential and attached residential buildings. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11) 
Sec. 23-2. - Downtown Maitland Special District purpose and intent. 
    The function of the Downtown Maitland Special District is to guide future development and redevelopment toward creating an attractive urban pattern that balances the pedestrian and traffic needs of residents, and to encourage, but not require, mixed-use development by generally desiring residential use development to be provided above commercial and/or office use, while it protects and enhances the original pattern of development consistent with the goals of the City's Comprehensive Plan, Downtown Master Plan, and the Downtown Maitland Revitalization Plan. 
    Downtown Maitland extends generally from Maitland Boulevard on the north to the CSX Railroad Overpass on the South and includes three sub-districts referred to as the Sawmill, Packwood, and Waterhouse Districts. The Packwood District is the focal point of the Downtown Maitland revitalization area and includes the City's Town Center and Core Area. 
    The intent of the Packwood District is to encourage economic viability by creating a mixture of public and private uses to promote walkability and activation of the retail core of the City's Downtown. The Packwood District represents the heart of the city and is intended for a vigorous mixture of commercial and residential uses that create a magnetic gathering place for citizens. It will contain a concentration of commercial, civic and cultural uses, interspersed with mixed use developments and urban open spaces. Buildings will be positioned close to the street to encourage pedestrian activity and to create a Main Street Urban Pattern. Design components central to the intent include clustering of buildings, buildings with distinctive storefronts, balconies and inviting entrances, as well as outdoor seating and cafes that interact with the street. Buildings will have diverse architectural types which incorporate decorative elements and attractive roof elements. 
    The Sawmill and Waterhouse Districts serve as the northern and southern entries to Downtown Maitland and are intended to achieve the vision of a pedestrian-oriented, mixed-use area. The Sawmill District represents the north gateway to the City and includes Maitland's SunRail station. The focus of this district is to create a transit- supportive place. The area will be based upon transit- oriented principles, such as a pedestrian and bicycle friendly environment with a compact and functional mix of uses. Design components central to the intent include: a mix of residential, employment and supporting retail and service uses, high densities/intensities around the transit station, and compact development form, (grouping of buildings to allow for easy pedestrian access between buildings). Building architecture will include façade treatments that reduce building scale to include gables, covered walks, awnings, storefront windows and building interaction with the sidewalk system. 
    The Waterhouse district represents the southern gateway to the City. The focus of the district is a safe, compact, pedestrian-friendly mixed use business district that serves neighborhoods within walking distance. Design components central to the intent include buildings with distinctive store fronts, balconies, and entrances that connect with the street, buildings with decorative elements and roofs which encourage a variety of street views, and diverse architectural styles. 
    Additional criteria have been established for ground-floor residential development within the Packwood, Sawmill and Waterhouse Districts to promote economic viability and to achieve a mixture of uses for Downtown Maitland. (Refer to section 21-21 Planned Development and Chapter 7.5 Article VII). The location of ground-floor residential within each district will be evaluated based upon compatibility with surrounding uses, the character of the surrounding areas, street types, road visibility, street frontage, access, and the purpose and intent of each district. 
    The design and land development standards are intended to be flexible and encourage design diversity and variation. The criteria for development in the district will ensure that the architectural integrity and details of existing significant structures are maintained, and will affirm the appropriateness of new development into the historic fabric of the area. 
(Ord. No. 1220, § 1(Exh. B), 10-24-11; Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 5), 5-14-12; Ord. No. 1305, § 4, 4-11-16 ) 

Sec. 23-2.1. - District designation. 
(a)  Purpose . The Downtown Maitland Special District serves as an overlay district and includes all real property shown within Downtown Maitland Future Land Use Designation as adopted in the city comprehensive development plan (CDP). 
(b)  Applicability . Where any provision of section 23-2 is in conflict with any standards or regulations within the Downtown Maitland Master Plan adopted by Ordinance 939 in October 1997, as may be amended from time to time, the standards contained herein shall prevail. All new development within the Downtown Maitland Special District shall comply with the standards contained in sections 21-6 and [23-2.3]. The entire development shall be brought into compliance with the standards if: 
(1)  The total building floor area on a building site is being increased by more than thirty (30) percent; or 
(2)  More than fifty (50) percent of the total building floor area on a building site is being replaced; or 
(3)  There is a combination of building floor area increase and building floor area replacement exceeding fifty (50) percent of the original building floor area on a development site; or 
(4)  Existing buildings are being redeveloped and the cost of redevelopment is greater than fifty (50) percent of the assessed value of all the buildings on the development site prior to the improvements. 
(c)  Architecture review . The city's development review committee (DRC) may obtain assistance from a design professional when reviewing development proposals for compliance with the architectural standards contained in this section. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.2. - Flexibility in design standards application (design waivers). 
    It is recognized that because of the individual unique characteristics or circumstances of any given development, flexibility in the application of development requirements may be warranted in certain situations. Waivers from the standards provided in sections 21-6 and 23-2, including all subsections within, and/or the standards contained in the Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual shall be specifically requested and delineated by the applicant and submitted to the city staff as part of the pre-application process. If an applicant requests multiple waivers, each waiver shall be evaluated independently. Land use waivers are not permitted under this section, and waivers are not applicable to properties zoned planned development. 
(a)  Waivers may be reviewed and/or approved by DRC, the planning and zoning commission, and city council as set forth below. 
(1)  DRC shall review and approve requests for waivers up to ten (10) percent of any dimensional requirement. 
(2)  Waivers of ten (10) percent or more of a dimensional requirement, and waivers of non-dimensional requirements, shall be reviewed and approved by the planning and zoning commission in accordance with the procedures established in section 7.5-83(III). 
(3)  Waivers involving activities such as financial contributions, land swaps, financial obligations, or continuing maintenance by the city, shall be reviewed by the city council in accordance with the procedures established in sub-section 7.5-83(IV)(c). Refer to sub-section 7.5-83(IV)(c) for additional examples. 
(b)  A waiver may be granted by the approving authority if it finds that strict application of requirements of section 21-6, section 23-2, or the standards manual is not warranted and that granting a waiver will fulfill the intent of this LDC. The approving authority shall apply all the following criteria, when applicable, to determine if the applicant has justified a request for a waiver to a dimensional requirement and if granting the proposed waiver will fulfill the intent of this LDC: 
(1)  The request is consistent with the CDP and generally consistent with the purpose of the LDC and the Downtown Maitland Master Plan. 
(2)  The proposed waiver will not have a material negative impact on adjacent uses, or the applicant proposes to mitigate the negative impact to be created by the waiver. 
(3)  Compliance with the requirement is technically impractical or undesirable based on site conditions, or approval of the waiver will result in superior design. 
(4)  The request would not have a material negative effect the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(5)  The applicant may provide other information in addition to that listed above to justify a request for a waiver and demonstrate that granting the proposed waiver will fulfill the intent of this LDC and the comprehensive development plan. 
(c)  The burden of presenting evidence sufficient to satisfy the applicable criteria set forth in this section as well as the burden of persuasion on those issues, remains with the applicant seeking the waiver. 
(d)  In granting a waiver, the approving authority may impose such reasonable conditions as will ensure that the use of the property to which the waiver applies will be reasonably compatible with the surrounding properties, including visual screening. 
(e)  As an exception to sub-section 21-5(I)(d)(1), waivers may be granted even if nonconforming structures will be enlarged or altered as a result of the waiver. 
(f)  A granted waiver and any conditions attached to it shall be entered on the face of or attached to the development order or permit and development plan. 
(g)  A proposed modification to an approved waiver shall be added to the approved waiver and considered in the aggregate. The total waiver (approved waiver plus proposed modification) shall determine the approving authority per subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.3. - Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual. 
    The Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual (also known as the Pattern Book in the city's CDP) shall be used to guide the future development and redevelopment of the Downtown Maitland Special District toward creating an attractive urban pattern that balances the pedestrian and traffic needs of residents, while it protects and enhances the original pattern of development consistent with the goals of the city's comprehensive plan, downtown master plan, and the Downtown Maitland Revitalization Plan. The Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual functions as a supplement to these regulations and provides: 
(1)  Additional detailed design standards for building form and architecture related to windows and doors, building materials, building colors and roof design as well as streetscape furnishing, 
(2)  Visual examples, fundamental design principles and comprehensive direction for the implementation of the regulations included within section 23-2, and 
(3)  Parking standards, including single-use parking ratios and shared parking standards without the necessity of providing additional parking studies. The Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual shall be adopted, or modified, by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.4. - Circulation. 
Sec. 23-2.4.1. - Streets. 
    Figure VI-1 of the Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual shows the various street types within the Downtown Maitland Zoning District. The following sub-sections contain the design standards for streets in the downtown. Developers are encouraged to modify the design of the street along the entire block, from intersection to intersection, for design consistency. If the developer is not modifying the entire block, relocating the curb will not be required; however, adequate area for parkway and sidewalk must be provided consistent with the following standards. 
(I)  Street type I-Major commercial streets . 
There are two (2) major commercial streets in the downtown: Orlando Avenue and Horatio Avenue (East of Orlando Avenue).

Travel lane width shall not exceed twelve (12) feet for one- (1)- way traffic and eighteen (18) feet for two- (2)- way traffic (nine (9) feet per lane minimum).

(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.4.2. - Network patterns: site access and circulation. 
    Shared access and circulation systems shall be designed to minimize curb cuts, provide direct access between adjacent uses and improve traffic circulation. 
(a)  Joint access driveways and cross-access easements are required between sites to reduce the number of access points and driveway area, and to increase the amount of landscaping. 
(b)  Access driveway width shall be limited to twelve (12) feet for one- (1)- way driveways and twenty (20) feet for two- (2)- way driveways. The crossing area connecting the sidewalk over the access driveway shall be distinct from the pavement and consistent with the required street furnishings as required in the Downtown Maitland Design Standards Manual. If a median is provided between two (2) driveways, then the crosswalk must continue through the median. 
(c)  When it is feasible to provide vehicular access to a commercial site from a secondary street or access road, without negatively impacting abutting single-family residential uses, it shall be required unless city council grants an exception to such requirement in association with the approval of a design waiver as provided in section 23-2.2. 
(d)  Projects shall be designed to create a balanced transportation system that invites pedestrians, bicyclists, and transit riders, as well as motor vehicles, and provides a system of connections to maximize choices for all modes of travel. 
(e)  Non-residential and mixed-use developments with a gross floor area of fifty thousand (50,000) gross square feet or more which are adjacent to a street that is or may be used as a transit route, shall coordinate with Lynx and, if recommended by Lynx and required by the city, shall provide access for an on-site public transit stop. The public transit stop shall include a bus pullout and shelter. Please refer to the Downtown Maitland Design Standards Manual, street furnishings, for bus shelter design. 
(f)  The number of curb cuts along the street frontage shall be limited. In areas such as the Orlando Avenue corridor, the vehicular entrances are encouraged to be from side streets and rear access roads. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.4.3. - Parking garages. 
    The design of a public garage shall adhere to the following standards. 
(a)  Vehicle entrances to structured parking garages shall be located away from primary pedestrian activity areas. 
(b)  Pedestrian access to parking garages shall be provided directly from adjacent streets. 
(c)  When fronting pedestrian-oriented spaces, at least seventy-five (75) percent of ground floor parking garage frontage, exclusive of entrance driveways, stairwells and pedestrian entryways, shall consist of active uses other than parking, such as residential (where allowed through the PD process), offices, retail, personal services, civic uses, and entertainment businesses. The city may approve other design alternatives, such as a liner building around the outer edge of the garage, designed to achieve this intent. 
(d)  The space provided for active uses shall be at least thirty (30) feet deep along its entire length. 
(e)  Parking garages shall comply with all building design standards for building facade, scale, building features and lighting, compatibility and placement on the site, as provided in sections 21-6, 23-2.4, 23-2.5, and 23-2.6 of this Code and the Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual. 
(f)  Parking garages are exempt from the floor height requirements of subsection 21-6(II)(e)(3)c., and the step back requirements of subsection 21-6(II)(e)(3). 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12; Ord. No. 1305, § 4, 4-11-16 ) 
Sec. 23-2.4.4. - Pedestrian and bicycle circulation. 
(I)  Pedestrian circulation/access . Pedestrian connections will be required as follows: 
(a)  Along Orlando Avenue, direct pedestrian access shall be provided from the principal entrance of the building to the sidewalk on the closest public right-of-way. 
(b)  Additional/secondary pedestrian access to businesses may be provided from the parking facilities directly to the ground floor uses, either through rear building entrances, sidewalks along the perimeter of buildings, or by pedestrian alleyways or pathways, which connect the rear parking lots to the sidewalks along the front street. Pedestrian alleyways and pathways shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet wide. 
(c)  Pedestrian circulation within the development shall be differentiated from driving surfaces through a change in materials and elevation, and shall provide locations for protection from the weather. 
(d)  Crosswalks are required wherever pedestrian circulation intersects a vehicular area. 
(II)  Bicycle circulation and access . The following standards will promote the continued use of bicycles as a viable means of transportation. 
(a)  All new development is required to provide connections to the city's bike and pedestrian path system if feasible. 
(b)  Bicycle racks shall be permanently fixed to the surface through mechanical fasteners or through the use of concrete footings. 
(c)  The provision and design of bicycle racks shall be in accordance with the standards in the Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.5. - Site design and lot layout. 
Sec. 23-2.5.1. - Block/lot layout. 
(a)  Applicants may be required to create streets or access easements through their developments to interconnect the local traffic in the area, rather than creating self-contained developments. 
(b)  The internal design of a development shall accommodate pedestrian circulation throughout. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.5.2. - Building placement and orientation. 
    Building orientation refers to the location of the primary and secondary facades and entrances to a building. 
(a)  Buildings pads shall meet the required build-to-line/setbacks and building frontage requirements to reinforce street edges along all public rights-of-way. 
(b)  Buildings shall orient toward the public right-of-way. 
(c)  If a site fronts on more than one (1) public right-of-way, such as a corner or double frontage lot, the development shall be designed to respond to both rights-of-way. If not feasible, the placement and orientation of the building shall be determined by the city on a case-by-case basis. 
(d)  Outparcels shall not be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.5.3. - Activity area. 
    The following standards apply to structures within the activity area. 
(a)  The use of arcades, galleries, or other integral architectural features that provide protection from the elements shall be required within the activity area along Independence Avenue. 
(b)  Arcades and galleries must provide a twelve- (12)- foot minimum vertical clearance on the first floor. 
(c)  The minimum depth for arcades and galleries shall be eight (8) feet. 
(d)  Floors above an arcade or gallery shall be allowed to encroach into the activity area for the entire depth of the arcade or gallery. 
(e)  Buildings may be setback up to twenty (20) feet from the build-to-line for the provision of pedestrian forecourts, courtyards, plazas, cafes, or other public gathering places. The additional setback shall not be applied to more than fifty (50) percent of the building width. A low street wall shall be installed at the required build-to-line or along the sidewalk for the length of the recess to maintain continuity along the street front (see street wall standards section, subsection 23-2.5.6(IV)(c)(1)). 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.5.4. - Service areas/utilities. 
(a)  Utility lines of all kinds shall be installed and constructed in accordance with section 5-20. 
(b)  Nonresidential delivery and loading areas, areas for outdoor storage, trash collection, and mechanical equipment shall be located away from property lines abutting residential areas. 
(c)  Loading areas or docks, outdoor storage, waste disposal, mechanical equipment, satellite dishes, truck parking, and other service support equipment shall be located behind the building line and shall be fully screened from the view of adjacent properties. 
(d)  Areas for outdoor storage, trash collection, and loading shall be incorporated into the primary building design and construction for these areas shall be of materials of comparable quality and appearance as that of the primary building. 
(e)  Shopping cart storage shall be located inside the building or shall be screened by a four- (4)- foot wall consistent with the building architecture and materials. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.5.5. - Stormwater design. 
    Per subsection 21-6(II)(i), all developments within an area permitted for a regional pond shall connect to the regional pond. For sites that are eligible for providing on-site stormwater management, the following standards shall be met: 
(a)  Underground storage and exfiltration are encouraged. 
(b)  All retention areas shall be incorporated into the overall design of the project. 
(c)  Ponds shall not be located adjacent to public rights-of-way; they shall be located to the side or rear of a development. 
(d)  Wet stormwater areas shall be designed as amenities. Features such as fountains or aerators shall be required to accent the ponds and provide adequate aeration to prevent stagnation and fish kills. 
(e)  Landscaping is required to soften the visual appearance of the ponds edges. Native trees and shrubs shall be used to landscape the littoral zone. No exotic invasive plants are permitted. 
(f)  Subject to the requirements of St. Johns River Water Management District, other governmental agencies, and a consideration of safety related issues, stormwater facilities shall be prohibited from having fencing unless it can be demonstrated to be necessary due to the configuration and topography of the lot. The determination of necessity in this circumstance shall be made by the appropriate decision making authority as a part of the evaluation of a design waiver to these standards. 
(g)  Whether stormwater is provided onsite or offsite, developers are encouraged to use low impact design concepts such as rain water harvesting, green roofs, bio-swales, rain gardens, parking lot water capture and pervious pavement. The goal of encouraging the use of these mechanisms is to reduce stormwater runoff, capture contaminants closer to the source and reduce the use of potable water for irrigation and grey water activities. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.5.6. - Landscaping and screening standards. 
(I)  General Requirements . 
(a)  A minimum of one (1) tree shall be planted or preserved for every five thousand (5,000) square feet of site area. Trees planted as part of the parking lot and/or buffer yard landscaping requirements may count toward this requirement. In lieu of providing the trees on-site, applicants may choose to pay into the city's tree fund. 
(b)  Plant materials for landscaping, buffering and screening shall be chosen from the Florida-Friendly Plant Database (Central Florida Region). This database which is maintained by the University of Florida, Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences (UF/IFAS) may be accessed on-line at: www.floridayards.org/fyplants/index.php. 
(c)  Additional plants may be approved by the city's arborist upon written request. All proposed trees and plant materials shall be graded as Nursery Grade No. 1 or better as outlined by the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Division of Plant Industry Grades and Standards for Nursery Plants (latest edition as revised from time to time). 
(d)  To minimize water consumption, the use of vegetative ground cover with low-water demand is encouraged rather than turf. 
(1)  No more than thirty (30) percent of the site landscaping shall be planted with sod if it is a high water use species (St. Augustine). 
(2)  No more than fifty (50) percent shall be planted with a low water use sod species. 
(3)  Sod shall not be used in areas less than four (4) feet in width. 
(e)  Palm trees shall be limited to forty (40) percent of the total tree requirement. 
(f)  Canopy trees that are planted closer than six (6) feet from a curb and/or sidewalk shall be planted with a root barrier control method that is approved by the city public works director. 
(g)  All plant containers shall be irrigated with micro irrigation on a separate, dedicated irrigation zone. Refer to chapter 8, article VI and chapter 20, article IV of the city's land development code for irrigation requirements. 
(II)  Parkway landscaping . Parkways shall include the following landscaping materials, which shall not be counted toward the required on-site landscaping. 
(a)  Street trees . The following street trees are required to be planted within the parkway.

Accent plants must be in scale with the sizes of surrounding plantings and must be significant in size to provide visual impact at planting. Sod is not allowed within the parkway areas.

(III)  Activity area landscaping . 
(a)  Street types I and II . The activity areas along street types I and II, are intended to be used for pedestrian activity and, if not occupied with arcades or galleries, they shall be used as an extension of the sidewalk, as outdoor seating area, or for street furniture. Landscaping in this area, if provided, shall be in the form of containers and/or planter boxes in scale and consistent with the building mass and architecture. Activity areas in front of uses that do not require pedestrian interaction along the facade (e.g. churches, offices, multifamily) shall meet the requirements for street type III. 
(b)  Street type III . Activity areas along a street type III shall be landscaped with a combination of intermediate trees, palms, shrubs, vines and/or ground covers subject to the size and spacing requirements of sections 23-2.5.6.(II)(a) and (b). 
(IV)  Parking lot landscaping and screening . Parking lot design (layout, landscaping, buffering and screening) shall minimize direct views of parked vehicles from streets and sidewalks; and, avoid spill-over light, glare, noise and exhaust fumes onto adjacent properties. 
(a)  Landscape strips between parking aisles . Large parking lots shall be visually and functionally segmented into smaller lots with landscaped islands and strips. Parking lots with more than two (2) head-to-head rows of parking shall include a continuous six- (6)- foot wide landscape strip between the parking spaces (parallel to the drive aisle). The strip shall be provided every other double row of parking. The following trees shall be planted within the landscape strip. 
Tree Type Spacing* Caliper Height* Spread Clearance Minimum Soil Volume Intermediate 30' 4" 10'-12' 4' 14' vehicular 8' pedestrian 300 CF; 8' root diameter Palm Trees 
(clusters of 3) 30' NA 14' clear trunk NA NA NA  
* Varies depending on species 
(b)  Landscape islands . No more than ten (10) consecutive parking stalls are permitted without a landscape island at least eight (8) feet wide (measured from back of curb) and extending the entire length of the parking stall. A minimum of one (1) canopy tree or either two (2) intermediate trees or three (3) palm trees shall be planted in each landscape island. The trees must meet the caliper, height, spread, clearance and soil volume noted in the previous sections. A minimum of five (5) shrubs per one hundred and forty-four (144) square feet of landscape area shall also be planted in the landscape island. The remainder shall be filled with a combination of mulch and ground cover. 
(c)  Parking lot perimeter screening . The landscaping within the parking lot perimeter along the side and rear property lines shall meet the requirements of section 8-15(c). The parking lot perimeter landscaping along the front property line may be located within the activity area and shall meet the following requirements. 
(1)  Street wall . In order to minimize direct views of parked vehicles from streets and sidewalks, a street wall shall be provided along the perimeter of surface parking lots fronting on public streets or alleys. The street wall shall meet the following standards: 
a.  Decorative street walls shall be constructed of wrought iron, brick, masonry, stone or other decorative materials matching the building materials and style. The use of cast stone squares to match the sidewalk is encouraged. 
b.  Chain link and wood street walls shall be prohibited. 
c.  The wall shall be a minimum of three (3) feet and a maximum of five (5) feet in height. Walls greater than three (3) feet in height above grade shall be no more than fifty (50) percent solid. 
d.  The wall may be located anywhere within the width of the activity area but shall in no case allow for less than a two- (2)- foot wide strip of landscaping. 
e.  Street walls shall incorporate raised lintels to protect existing trees and bridge over their existing root system. 
f.  The quality of the street wall materials shall match or exceed the quality of materials used for the building construction. The finish used on the street wall shall match or compliment the finishes on the building. 
(2)  Landscaping . Ground cover, hedges or shrubs shall be installed on both sides of the wall. On the inside of the wall, either intermediate or palm trees shall be planted (see section 23-2.5.6.(d)(1), for tree specifications). 
(V)  Buffers . The buffer yard requirements contained in section 8-13, buffer yard landscape regulations, shall only apply to development abutting residentially-zoned sites, and only along the property line shared by the two (2) uses. No buffers shall be required between any other uses, unless specifically required as part of a conditional use approval. 
(VI)  Stormwater pond landscaping . If an on-site retention pond is approved by the city, it shall be designed to include a minimum ten- (10)- foot wide landscape buffer along the pond's perimeter. The buffer shall include one (1) canopy tree or a cluster of three (3) understory trees for every fifty (50) linear feet of landscape buffer. This landscape buffer must not interfere with the required maintenance shelf. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.5.7. - Parking lot lighting. 
    In addition to perimeter streets lights requirements that were provided in the Downtown Maitland Development Standards Manual, the followings parking lot lighting standards are applicable. 
(a)  Light fixtures shall be designed so that light is directed onto the parking area and away from neighboring residential lots. 
(b)  Light fixtures shall be equipped with dark sky light shields. 
(c)  Lighting fixtures in parking lots adjacent to residential zones shall not exceed twenty (20) feet in height as measured from the adjacent grade to the top of the light fixture. 
(d)  Parking lot lighting fixture design shall be complimentary to the street light design as required in the Downtown Maitland Design Standards Manual. 
(e)  Tree and site lighting locations shall not be in conflict. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.6. - Building form and architecture. 
Sec. 23-2.6.1. - Building frontage. 
(a)  In order to create a continuous urban form along all streets, the following minimum building frontage requirements shall be met. The standards are stated as percentage of the building width at the build-to-line to the lot width. 
 Packwood = seventy-five (75) percent 
 Waterhouse = fifty (50) percent 
 Sawmill = fifty (50) percent 
Sites with multiple street frontages shall meet the frontage requirement along all streets. If not feasible, waivers will be considered by the city on a case-by-case basis based on site location and street priorities. 
(b)  Front facades along street types I and II shall limit the number of gaps along the block face. Should a vehicular access be necessary due to lack of access to rear parking from a secondary street, an alley, or an adjacent property (shared use agreement necessary), a gateway, arch or similar feature shall be provided to preserve the block continuity. The width of the driveway shall not exceed twelve (12) feet for one- (1)- way traffic and twenty (20) feet for two- (2)- way traffic. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.7. - Development incentives. 
    The city provides the following opportunities for development incentives to encourage development and redevelopment activity within the Downtown Maitland Zoning District and the Downtown Maitland Special District. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12; Ord. No. 1323, § 2, 8-14-17 ) 
Sec. 23-2.7.1. - Incentives program. 
(a)  Expedited review and application process . Section 7.5-83(II) provides an expedited review and application process for Downtown Maitland. A CRA staff person is available to assist applicants through the development review, permitting process, and/or development agreement process, if necessary. Applications for incentives that involve payments into trust funds or purchases of credits require either the execution of a development agreement with final site plan review or approval as provided in subsection 7.5-83(IV)(c). Refer to subsection 7.5-83(IV)(c) for additional process standards. 
(b)  Off-site infrastructure . Applicants may apply for off-site accommodation of their required open space, pervious surface, and/or parking (see section VI(b) of the Development Standards Manual). Off-site infrastructure may be accommodated at a city facility or an off-site private property, if available. 
Eligibility for participation in the provision of infrastructure off-site shall be requested during the pre-application meeting, prior to any formal development review procedures. Eligibility requires the availability of the appropriate capacity at the designated donor site. Once eligibility is determined and the required on-site capacities established, the developer may reserve the capacity not fulfilled on-site. The developer must submit proof of off-site capacity, in the form of an agreement between the developer and the owner of the donor site, at the time of application for development approval. The agreement is subject to city approval and shall run with the land. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12) 
Sec. 23-2.7.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1323 , § 2, adopted August 14, 2017, repealed § 23-2.7.2, which pertained to bonus programs and derived from Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12; Ord. No. 1305, § 4, 4-11-16 . 
Sec. 23-2.8. - Downtown Maitland sign standards. 
(a)  Monument signs . 
    No reader boards are allowed. All signs must include visible street number address. 
(b)  For properties with commercial retail uses under forty thousand (40,000) square feet gross building area . 
 Signs can be internally or externally lit. 
 Sign area shall be a maximum of thirty-six (36) square feet per face. 
 Maximum height of sign shall be eight (8) feet. 
 A minimum of two (2) feet tall masonry or stone base is required. 
(c)  For properties w/commercial retail uses over forty thousand (40,000) square feet gross building area . 
 Signs can be internally or externally lit. 
 Sign area shall be a maximum of seventy-two (72) square feet per face. 
 Maximum height of sign shall be twelve (12) feet. 
 Signs shall be masonry or stone only. 
 A minimum of two (2) feet tall masonry or stone base is required. 
(d)  For office uses under twenty thousand (20,000) square feet gross building area . 
 Sign area shall be a maximum of thirty-six (36) square feet per face. 
 Maximum height of sign shall be eight (8) feet. 
 A minimum of two (2) feet tall masonry or stone base is required. 
 Signs shall be externally illuminated only. 
(e)  For office uses over twenty thousand (20,000) square feet gross building area . 
 Sign area shall be a maximum of seventy-two (72) square feet per face. 
 Maximum height of sign shall be twelve (12) feet. 
 Signs shall be masonry or stone only. 
 Signs shall be externally illuminated only. 
(f)  For residential uses . 
 Sign area shall be a maximum of thirty-six (36) square feet per face when total dwelling units are one hundred (100) or less. 
 Sign area shall be a maximum of seventy-two (72) square feet per face when total dwelling units are over one hundred (100). 
 Maximum height of sign shall be eight (8) feet when total dwelling units are one hundred (100) or less. 
 Maximum height of sign shall be twelve (12) feet when total dwelling units are over one hundred (100). 
 One (1) face per street front. 
 Signs shall be perpendicular to the streets. No "v" signs allowed. 
 Signs shall be externally illuminated only. 
 Signs shall be masonry or stone only. 
(g)  Signs erected on buildings (including canopy, awning) . 
 Maximum allowable sign copy area for signs erected on buildings (including canopy, awning) = one and one-half (1-1/2) square feet per every linear foot of street frontage. This maximum allowable copy area may be increased by ten (10) percent for any buildings higher than thirty-five (35) feet. 
 No window signs are allowed other than lettering of numbers for addresses or legally required notices. 
(1)  Wall, arcade, blade (attached to building) . 
 Maximum size = eighty (80) square feet. Minimum twelve (12) feet above sidewalk. 
(2)  Canopy, awning . 
 Maximum sign size = thirty (30) percent of awning face area. 
 No pole or pylon signs are allowed. 
(Ord. No. 1227, § 2(Exh. A, § 6), 5-14-12)
